reviewText: Hyper Light Drifter is kind of like that girl you're really into. She's beautiful, and you can't take your eyes off of her and everytime you see her you feel this rush of joy and happiness go through your body. When you listen to her speak you hang onto every word because whatever she says is always important to you. The beginning of this relationship that you find yourself in is one of the greatest experiences that you've been through and you want to see what every day brings. Then, at night, when you're both asleep she wakes up and shoves her entire hand up your ♥♥♥. It's the most painful thing you can go through but when it ends you're cool with it and you want to experience more of your life with her. Then she shoves her hand up your ♥♥♥ again.\n\nThis game is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing fun but hard at times 10/10

reviewText:
You know what?

I was so ready to give this game a negative review.

Sure, the style, atmosphere and music are jaw-dropping. However, the gameplay (specifically the combat) didn't really click with me until I defeated the first boss after ~50 tries (yes, really that many). The combat was just not what I signed up for. I was expecting 2D Zelda with more fluid combat, but I got was a top down Souls game. Expect to get stunlocked, die in a split-second and generally get this ♥♥♥♥ kicked out of you.

After I came to terms with that, I actually started having fun.

reviewText:
REVIEW OF BETA: FINAL RELEASE MAY DIFFER

Hyper Light Drifter is a MERCILESS action adventure game, somewhere between a post-apocalyptic Zelda and a cyberpunk thriller. There are no instructions, no warnings, and the game does not hold your hand - it just throws you into a trial by fire, and I constantly felt that I was just barely holding on.

The game gives you two weapons (at a time), a sword, the ability to rapidly dodge short distances, and precious few hit points, and then brings on wave after wave of enemies, all with strong AI that are not afraid to flank you or attack you en masse. Multiple enemy types with various strengths and weaknesses constantly joined forces to put me into harrowing positions that I could just barely eek may way through. Any gamer who has ever watched a game and incredulously thought, Why are they lining up and attacking one at a time? No one would ever do that
date: will love this game. The challenge level is real, even in (for lack of a better description) platforming elements, where the player's blink/teleport/dodge is utilized like a real game element, and not just a press x to not die" style safety button. reviewText:
You will buy this game, and for the first few hours you'll hate yourself because your hands won't do what your brain wants fast enough, the only thing keeping you playing being the intriguing storytelling, neat visuals and great soundtrack...

...untill it all clicks together, when your brain finaly fuses with your controller about half way through the game, the tight controls will allow you to take on the unfairest of fights in a blink, leading you to the game's end in under 10 hours.

But you will need more.
You'll keep playing, untill you find all the viciously hidden collectibles thanks to subtle visual hints left by the game.

At this point, once you've collected most of them and bought every upgrades, the game is too easy. You've lost the thrill for the challenge.

That's when you'll try New Game + mode where you replay the game with all abilities unlocked from the beginning...but your health is capped at 40% which means enemies will kill you in two regular hits or one single heavy attack. Bosses one shot as well in this mode.


People often compare this game's difficulty in NG+ mode with Dark souls. It's nothing like it. It's much fairer.

You don't have to guess what enemies do. You don't have to die at least one time against each boss because their attacks are unpredictible. When an enemy is about to attack, you know what it will do and where. This game doesn't test your guess work, or your patience against die-and-retry kinds of boss. It tests your reflexes and quick decision making because yes, all attacks are easily predictible, but rarely over 0.25s in advance.


One last thing : to fully apreciate this game, you have to know that the guy behind its idea was born with several life-threatening heart defects. This is why despite its esoteric, borderline childish art style, the game doesn't shy away from heart/blood or even death symbolisms so keep an eye out for those.

...Now that i think about it, this game is almost a life lesson.

One last (but important) thing, playing with a controller is much easier.

reviewText:
This game is pretty freakin' swell, but it's probably not for everyone.

It may look like some artsy Zelda clone, but that isn't the case. People have been saying it's like Dark Souls, and while I can see why they would say that, I don't think that's really accurate, either.

This game is all about timing and finese. If you try to button mash through combat against anything but the most basic of enemy, you're gonna get wrecked. Likewise, you can't just spam health items to cheese the combat because using a health item during combat is probably going to have the opposite effect from what you were hoping. Healing doesn't happen instantly, and trying to heal in combat leaves you open. The enemies will take advantage and punish you.

You've got your standard sword, which is your basic melee attack. You also get a gun fairly early, and it really comes in handy on certain enemies.  There's an evade roll that you're gonna get real familiar with, and it is used for both setting up counter attacks as well as exploring and uncovering secrets.

This game has a lot of secrets, by the way. You'll want to check any walls that look odd, and keep an eye out for platforms that might be on the very edge of the screen, only showing a few pixels. It's also not uncommon for secret areas to have other secret areas inside them. It might be worth noting that some of these hidden areas are manditory for progressing through the game, so if you hate exploring you'll probably end up using a walkthrough. Like a silly little casual.

As you collect currency, mainly from all the secret areas you'll come across, you can buy various upgrades in town. There are vendors for different types of skills. One vendor sells various sword upgrades, another sells gun upgrades, and one has evade roll upgrades. There are a couple others around, too.

I do have one issue with the game, and that is the fact that there is no dialogue or text at all in the story. The story is told to you via pictures. I feel like it wasn't the best choice for this game, because the story is really weird, and very hard to understand. I was lost before the intro cutscene finished. It makes it hard to get invested in the story when it's basically nonsense. Keep in mind I'm not saying this is a strike against the game, I'm saying it's something I personally didn't like.

Still, this is a really fun game with neat aesthetics and intense combat.

You should probably get it.

Unless you're a smelly casual.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER
I don't write a lot of reviews so I know my review might be bad, but I had to for Hyper Light Drifter. It probably says I have 12 hours in this game, but at the time of writing this review, 7 of those hours are from the release build and the rest from the preview build.

Edit Reason: I forgot to talk about how it runs.. Sorry..
Edit Reason 2: Reworded a few things.

Kick Starter:
As a kick starter backer, this game has given more that I expected. The preview build of the game was amazing and hyped me up for the release. And I wasn't let down at all.

So What Is It?:
Many reviews already tell you what the game is like so, I'll keep it simple. Hyper Light Difter is a top down, action adventure, pixel art master piece. The mechanics (which involve sword play, dashing and ranged weapons) are rock solid and never fault you for unknown reasons. The atmoshpere and sound design are honestly one of the best experiences i've had in a long time, the story is super interesting and cryptic (this is a bonus or a flaw depending on how you like your stories) and lastly the game feels SO good to play.

Anything Else?:
The game's difficulty gives me a dark souls 1 vibe, PLEASE don't misunderstand what I mean by this.

What I mean is; the game is hard but fair, deaths that happen are your fault. Very very rarely will something kill you and leave you thinking there is no way I could have saw that coming." Apart from experiencing a boss for the first time

reviewText:
I just finished the game.

The game feels like a hybrid between Legend of Zelda and Dark Souls but what I love about this game is that it doesn't requrie level upping or heart pieces to strengthen your character. Improvement comes from you and learning how to use the skills and equpment is what grants you strength. You can play through it without any optional upgrades at all, I think.

You cna also play the stages in any order but it's usually recommended to get the multi-dash upgrade first for an easier time.

There's also platforming here which is a delight for me who grew up with platformers.

The game is very atmospheric with it's gorgeous pixel visuals and animations but I do feel apathetic playing it most of the time. I can't find any emotional attachments to any of the characters because it's a silent game. Pure visual story telling would work if the story was simple but I get the feeling that it's far more complex than it seems. There's even a bit of time travel here from what I understand. This might just be my own preference because I can't stand narratives in games with silent protagonists.

My only real con about this game is that it feels kinda' short or I just found an exploit and ripped right through the game.  There's a little too many health packs lying around too.  I also thought that he'd have more attacks from what I saw from the game's previews but my memory is a little hazy on that.

There's also a new game plus which limits the HP bar severely and only the truly daring would go through with that handicap. I suppose this addresses the game's length and I might attempt it at some point but I'm a little burnt out.

Overall, it was a great experience but I think it get's overshadowed easily by other games with a more captivating narrative or mystery.

reviewText:
At the time of this writing (mid-April of 2016), Hyper Light Drifter is easily my favorite new release of 2016 so far, and will surely have a spot on my list of my top 10 games of the year.

This is just a wonderful game all around. This is some of the finest, most memorable world building I've experienced in a game in a long time, all of it done without a single word. Just absolutely beauitful art, incredible ambience, and boundless creativity. It's a world I didn't want to leave. I completed the game just about 10 minutes ago, and that makes me sad.

It's also an incredibly exciting gameplay experience. The combat is technical wizardry. It feels punchy, responsive, and satisfying. It's a challenging, fair game that strikes that perfect middle ground of not being easy in the slightest, yet never feeling frustrating. The game is just a delight all around. Developer Heart Machine has arrived on the scene in a big way with Hyper Light Drifter, and I can't wait to see what they do next.

Pick this one up without hesitation. This game is wonderful...a stellar example of what makes this medium so special.

reviewText:
Overview:Hyper Light Drifter is a 2D action-adventure RPG game inspired by and made as an homage to 8-bit and 16-bit classics from the 80s and 90s. The game consists of fast-paced, real-time strategic-combat gameplay. The game is developed and published by Heart Machine, made using GameMaker: Studio. It’s available for PC, OS X and is planned to be available for PlayStation 4 and Xbox One in the future. It is a very special game.


Story:This game’s story has to be fully inferred. There’s no dialogue, only imagery; this takes after SNES’ games’ tendencies to not have any dialogue. The Drifter (our protagonist) is ill, he coughs up blood constantly, implying his impending death. The protagonist’s illness is inspired by the game’s creator’s own battle with heart disease. Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind is a major inspiration for the game’s world. Hidden around the game is ancient technology forgotten by the world’s inhabitants, The Drifter sets out on a journey to find a cure for his illness and in his journey is revealed the secrets of this ancient technology. However, his adventure is not without obstacles. There are many enemies throughout the game, four main bosses to the North; South; East; and West; as well as some other bosses in some locations of the game.

The narrative through imagery is extremely atmospherical, which in turn conveys different emotions. There are some NPCs in the game which have certain stories to tell, most of which deal with themes such as hardship and needing help from the good-hearted protagonist. Although it’s a bit difficult to understand the story in its entirety, the game manages to leave you feeling like you’ve just been through quite the adventure by the time you finish it.


Gameplay:The gameplay is extremely fun, it is also challenging. The Drifter uses an energy sword for melee attacks, ranged weapons like guns, and AoE attacks. The enemies in the game become more abundant and progressively harder to defeat, forcing the player to experiment with different tactics. The game’s creator, Alex Preston, says the game is a combination between TLOZ: A Link to the Past and Diablo. You can save and restore health at certain checkpoints in the game, which also serve as fast-travel points. These points can be found in the central city, and in the four areas surrounding the city. The player can upgrade certain aspects of the Drifter’s ability by finding batteries, which function like money/ability points. The developers also recently added a local co-op mode which is in BETA. Each boss has a very particular pattern, and have varying levels of difficulty, the last of which is the hardest. Even if this game takes after titles such as Dark Souls, it is not as hard, though gamers who enjoy a challenge will definitely enjoy this one. It’s simple but testing, can be casual at times, but unforgiving if you’re careless.


Visual:Two words: Pixel Art. This game has a very attractive aesthetic, all rendered in beautiful pixel art. The animations are wonderful and the environmental design is a delight to look at. Even though it is clearly a 2D game, some of the animations are executed so well that it almost seems like it might be 3D at times. From the visual effects to the simple animations of doors opening, swords swinging, and things exploding. It’s all fluid and satisfying to see. Although the cover art and concept art for the game is relatively minimalistic, in-game everything is fairly detailed, considering it’s all pixel art. The character feels alive and never feels odd to move or strike with. The atmosphere and ambience that the game’s visuals manifest is enough to immerse you into playing it for hours on end.


Sound:Sound in this game is what makes it all work. Combat sounds, environmental sounds, and character speech sounds, they’re all great, but the sound that makes it all come together is the music. It’s not very surprising that the soundtrack is so good, since the composer is Disasterpeace, the same guy who made the soundtrack for Fez. The 16-bit style music is a nostalgic trip to the SNES and is what completes the immersive experience of playing the game. The image-based narrative goes side by side with the soundtrack, making all extremely cohesive.


Final Thoughts:To be entirely honest, I didn’t expect much about this game except that it had Dark Souls-esque gameplay and a nostalgic aesthetic... until I started playing it. When I did, it quickly took me back to my childhood experiences of playing games like The Legend of Zelda, I must have put in close to four hours in my first session, I simply could not put the controller down. The story drew me in, the gameplay satisfied and challenged me, and I’ve enjoyed every minute. When I finished it I was surprised to see the credits go on for so long, Heart Machine aside, this was a fairly big production for an indie game. The special thanks section has some interesting names in it. I can’t help but have full respect for Heart Machine in reaching out to different people, funding their game with kickstarter, and delivering a truly special product. This game is very special.

reviewText:
Spoiler free review, with a short and long version:
TLDWTR (too long didn't want to read) VERSION:

Hyper Light Drifter (HLD) is a 2D action-adventure game, characterized by:
- a gorgeours pixel art style similar to Qora and Titan Souls' ones
- a cryptic wordless narration, similar to Teslagrad's one
- an unstable 30 Fps lock
- often irresponsive controls
- a deep combat system
- time required to speedrun" it: 4-5 hours
- time required to complete Normal Mode at 100%: 15 hours
- the presence of in-game secrets
recommended:
gear upgrades and a New Game + mode

Buy it if:
+ your eyes can withstand 30 fps
+ if your skill level with action games is slightly above the average
+ if you prefer to be enchanted by graphics rather then being amused by narration
+ if you love hard combats combined with a solid combat system
Don't buy it if:
- you believe that spending 20$ for a 4 hour game isn't acceptable
- if you're not gonna complete and collect the other collectibles
- if you hate games locked at 30 fps with bad controls
- if you hate frustrating challenges and/or playing with a controller (highly recommended)

LONGER VERSION:
I've been playing this game for over 30 hours and after completing it at 100% i'll quickly summarize the game's best and worst aspects getting a bit into their details.

GOOD ONES:
1- HLD's appearance is striking and beautiful as it takes inspiration from Atzec's art and from games such as Qora and Titan Souls by reproducing and improving their pixelated style

reviewText:
This game absolutely rules.

It sits comfortably upon the razor's edge of hard difficulty never steeping into the unfair ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t category that so many other git gud" games so often fall prey to. You die to a boss and you respawn immediately before the fight able to try again within moments. Bed of Chaos from Dark Souls 1 made you walk one minute across a pool of lava before you could re-fight him.

I had to take a pause in the game to soak in the beautifully crafted environments. This game didn't need to look so damn good but it decided to look ultra F-I-N-E anway.The colors pop vibrantly like the neon 80's. Music is a little bland and forgettable though.

The game doesn't do any handholding so here are some important tips that will save you some trouble.

1) The levels are all about the same difficulty. You can do them in any order.
2) Tackle the East first
date:
that boss is the easiest and your reward is a very high dps weapon
3) Purchase the triple dash before you head North. You'll want it for both the level and the boss.
4) The boss in the west is the hardest by far
5) The dash attack item is useless--the input is only one frame long so it never comes out."

reviewText:
Backed this game because the art style looked really compelling.

What I got far, far exceeded my expectations.

-Challenging combat that is difficult enough to keep you interested but fair enough to keep you trying.  It requires a level of mastery and reflex that isn't really like any other top-down adventure game I've played.  Makes successful combat very satisfying and makes you want more.

-Lumping this in with other pixel style games is unfair.  I personally hate pixel art games.  This game is dazzling.  Beautiful art design that is more stylized; it doesn't use pixel art as a compromise for poor art-design or limited resources.  It elevates the style to a new level, and I doubt many who use the style will be able to answer.

-The Legend of Zelda influence is there, and it's compelling.  The cinematic qualities aren't overbearing, but they definitely enhance the experience enough to add intrigue.

$20.00 might seem like a high price, but it's more than worth it for this.  It's an excellent, very well designed game.  I helped kickstart this years ago and had all but forgotten about it, but playing it now, I'm glad these guys took their time.  It's a very, very well done game.

9.5/10 - Near flawless.

Hyper Light Drifter is a lovely, brutal game that will test and reward your patience. I'm only about 5 hours into the game but I have another 5 hours from the beta.

Pros

- Easy controls
- Cool upgrade system (once you figure out how it works)
- Fun enemies (That all seem to have different behaviors)
- Lovely sounds and music
- Great graphics (If you enjoy pixel art)
- Interesting story.

Cons
- Well, maybe I'm just bad but the bosses are SOOOO hard. I've gotten to 3 of them but I haven't been able to beat them yet.

So far I love the game and it has been well worth the money.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a top-down hack n shoot a little zelda-like.


-Good-:

Gameplay:

Your options are fairly limited in combat. Slice, dash, shoot. You eventually get other weapons and a few new abilities, like 2 flavors of dash attacks, projectile reflection and a charge attack.   Enemies have patterns that you exploit to damage them and try not to get hurt in return. It's simple but overall fairly solid.  Bosses are extra challenging and pretty fun.  The length of the game didn't overstay its welcome, but near the end it was definitely becoming a little boring fighting normal enemies.


Graphics:

The game looks beautiful, both in motion and in stills. The opening is probably one of the coolest openings I can remember. Each 'main' section of the game world has it's own theme both above and below ground. There's a few cool setpieces in the game for you to appreciate [A battle frozen in crystal, remains of a titan, etc] , sometimes little details too.  I wish there were more of these honestly, just cool places to explore and appreciate, to try and put the story together, as oftentimes areas within the same zone kind of just blend together.

Music:

The game's music is very low key for the most part, ambient electronica. While on paper that sounds boring, in game it's used to great effect, with special musical cues during cinematic scenes or exploring an important area.

-Questionable-:

The story:
Aside from the monoliths, which are in their own language, there's no written text or dialogue in the game. That would be fine, but there's a real minimal amount of 'picture dialogue' in game. It's all very nice, I just wish there was more of it.  Most of the story is derived from conjecture. There's no real character growth, either from the player or the NPCs, even as the world changes.



-The bad-:

Mechanics:
I never got good at chain dashing. Maybe that's a personal thing, but it probably isn't helped by the 30fps max that a fast paced pixel art game shouldn't be running at.  You also get a shield dash, which seems to only work about 3/4's of the time.  That's probably also my fault, I think it has weird vulnerabilities on startup and end.  Weapons don't really feel balanced. The pistol is worthless compared to every other weapon (except against those 1 HP birdmen) and the homing shard launcher is also a little underwhelming. The lasergun is too situational.


Secrets:
They're terrible. They're a chore. They're poorly implemented.


They usually come in a few varieties. Invisible hallways, some of which have the BAREST of visual cues, a few that almost have zero, and about 3 that actually have reasonable hints. The worst part about these is that they're not consistent, having you end up just wallhugging the entire game. It really brings the entire experience down.

There's also hidden platforms. These are probably the worst. In some locations if you stand on an exact player sized area, your drone will make a little ping and you can activate it to reveal some platforms that you can dash on to. These kinds of secrets are absolutely terrible.  A few of them have the absolute slightest of hints (a hole in a fence of a walled platform), but even then finding these kinds of secrets is more of a chore when it should be exhileration.

There's also a few secrets where if you dash to one platform your normally locked camera will be moved to see a new area. I found most of these by myself, but they still were unintuative.

The worst hidden area I can remember is in the southern sector of the game, where you have to make a blind dash towards off screen to get on another platform.

Other:

There's also the map. It's very general, and for the most part, won't really be a help to anyone, aside from when you're looking at a guide to find where you missed secrets.  The game doesn't really have any puzzles.  I felt this to be a little wierd for a game that cited link to the past as a main influence. I wish the game had less obtuse hiding locations and more challenges for items.


Replayability:
The game stayed fun all the way through, but I didn't find any joy at going through it again, even with the alternate drifter or the 2 HP NG+ mode, which I realized in advance I probably wasn't good enough for, at least not without a lot of redoing.  The game just doesn't really offer enough ways to play differently, or an exciting story to experience again





-  Overall - :  Good for one playthrough for most players, only those looking for an abstract kind of suffering will replay on NG+  At it's price of 20bux, it's reasonable.

tl;dr

Hyper Light Drifter wants to be Link to the Past:Prepare to Die Edition with super metroid exploring, but ends up being Metroid II: Indie Edition.

reviewText:
Are you morbidly depressed because you can't run Dark Souls 3?

This is both a substitute, and a damn good replacement until you get a half-decent computer. I highly recommend using keyboard and mouse for fluid gameplay, though this is likely personal preference. A marvelous soundtrack, complete with rewarding pattern-recognition and gradually progressive gameplay. You can go wherever you want in the game, in any direction, and you'll be able to handle everything that comes at you, even without upgrades.

This game is the pride and joy of isometric dungeon crawlers for the last year or so.

reviewText:
If you like a beautiful atmosphere, and a game with a great degree of challenge, reward for unbridled exploration and minimalist storytelling, stop reading and buy the game.

It took me unlocking multi-dash, an extra health pack slot, an increased ammo clip and the ability to reflect projectiles with my sword, as well as the training accrued during the time it took exploring the world in order to gain these upgrades, to sufficiently prepare me with the skills to defeat the first boss I encountered.

That's how much of a challenge he was. Which is why it was so glorious when his health bar hit zero, and my drifter did his victory dance. Those who would complain of difficult boss fights in games, well, this game has them. You'll need to be patient.

Looking back, I could have probably killed him without the extra clip for my pistol, as well as the extra health pack. But I'm glad I gained these upgrades.

Hyper Light Drifter is some kind of mix between the older Zelda titles, with a spattering of Dark Souls, and all the atmosphere of a game like Bastion.

Once you get to the main hub, you can explore the world in four directions, with each direction ending in a boss fight. As you explore the world, you unlock upgrading chips which can be cashed in at shops in the main town. There are a number of upgrades affecting your sword, your guns, your movement, your health packs, and grenades. I'm about 23% through the game, based on what I've collected so far, and I can say at this point that it really doesn't matter what I picked up, except for maybe multi-dash/projectile reflection. Of the two boss fights I've done, they've seemed to be the most useful skills to have. I'd wager neither are necessary.

The game is devoid of text, and there's no voice acting. Everything you discover, you do so through images that present events, and visuals that explain your purpose, etc. Talking to people consists of seeing a few images that make up their story, and in many cases, a symbol is added to your map. You're on your own to divine what everything means. Exploration of the world helps in this regard, as the atmosphere provides you context for the world you're in.

Bonus points for that skeleton giant on the mountainside in the north. Seeing it in the background, and then actually encountering that area proper screamed Dark Souls.

Each enemy has a differing amount of life, and a different moveset. If you're impatient, you'll quickly find your Navi-like sprite shouting at you to heal. Once you've run the gamut against a few of the same type of enemies, you'll no longer find yourself in this situation, instead dispatching groups of shuriken-throwing ninjas with untenable grace. I suggest picking up the sword-projectile deflection as soon as possible, as your ability to deflect can transform a pain-staking ambush into a slaughterhouse ballet.

Bosses require a Dark Soulsesque amount of patience. Learning their moves, learning where you'll be safe, when you can attack using your different weapons, and again, maintaining safety, are your priorities. It can get frustrating, but I wouldn't call it twitch-style play. There's a certain amount of a grace period with regards to timing, at least as far as I've made it. You can set yourself up with quite a few potions with relative ease, allowing a greater grace for mistakes. Dying resets you to the closest checkpoint, which usually occur when you swap screens. Occasionally, you'll encouter ambush-style encounters where you can't escape until you clear the field, usually ending in a checkpoint. If you die in an area without hitting a checkpoint, all upgrades gained and enemies killed will respawn. Most enemies in an area do not respawn once dispatched.

Health packs respawn, so you can properly prepare for boss fights, as well as exploring new areas.

One of the few things I haven't yet mentioned is the ability to unlock magenta triangles" for each of the areas you go to. I've yet to realize their significance in the context of lore. They're used to unlock specific doors in each of the 4 areas. Specifically
date: each area has its' own pieces
recommended: which you'll collect as you explore
hoursPlayed: allowing access for further exploration.\n\nFinally

reviewText:
This game stirs my soul in evocative ways. It feels like an amalgam of my own past, escaping into 8-bit NES and titles like Blaster Master and Guardian Legend and Crystalis, although it's not a direct reference to any of those games... But it's like that, especially if you grew up playing 8- and 16-bit video games developed in Japan... Somehow mixed in all this is the DNA of visionary anime like Nausicaa and other fare.

It feels like a conversation held in the chiptune pixelated language of an entire era and aesthetic. Something somber about it all, too, a bit gothic perhaps.  The game invites profound awe and introspection just one layer below the action with every sprite, background, and audio track.

Hyper Light Drifter seems to come from the heart, and stands loudly proclaiming the artform of gaming lives on even as the world, wonder, and hope of our childhoods fade and are replaced with something more knowing, more appreciative of the fleeting good, and more weary of all in the world that erodes it.   It's especially poignant today; evocative of a cultural era that seems to be slipping through our fingers as the Japan of a generation or two ago that reached such stunning artistic heights in anime and digital media perhaps begins to fade.

I'm still relatively early in the game, but would enthusiasticly recommend it to anyone who enjoys deep, quiet, beautiful exploration, tremendous atmosphere, exceptional music, and a bit of legitimately challenging twitch gameplay. :)

reviewText: This game is incredible. It grips you from the first minute when you're introduced to the game through a slick, harrowingly beautiful and intriguing opening cinematic. The animation and art direction is top notch. The game play is a mix between link to the past dungeon crawling and challenging combat and exploration reminiscent of Dark Souls. The combat is tough but fair. Often times I'll die, and go back into the encounter with a new plan and win because I'm more familiar with the challenge at hand. This is the best kind of difficulty. It's not easy, but it encourages you to retry and conveys a sense of accomplishment when you win the fight. I would recommend this to anyone. One of the best games I've played in awhile.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a bright and colorful 2D action game presented to you in pixel-art styled graphics from an isometric angle. You control the drifter and set out to help a town out by ridding surrounding areas from all kinds of baddies. You're armed with your sword and your trusty side-arm, you traverse the lands by using your abilities. This is Hyper Light Drifter.

Let us begin. Although there's no direct dialogue in Hyper Light Drifter, there are pictures that pop up when you meet the friendly npc's you come across that give you an idea of what's happening. You pretty much have to piece the story together from these images. The same with goes for the upgrade shops, you must use pictures to know how much a new item costs and what it does.

The game features an open world which the player must explore thoroughly in order to complete the game. The world is full of life and death. It's cute and charming yet ominous. It's lively yet has some sense of emptiness and dispair to it. The levels have lower levels which is where you gain keys you will use to unlock other areas and eventually battle the boss of that area.

Combat is inspired by Dark Souls, it's simple but very effective. It's all aboutthe player being able to memorize the enemies paatterns and acting accordingly. Attack, dodge, and attack again. If you've ever played a Dark Souls game or another game inspired by Dark Souls (countless games out there now) then you should know the drill.

Pros  Very cool pixel art-style, great use of color makes the game pop
Mysterious and lonely feeling as you explore the world around you
Tranquil soundtrack
Full controller support
Cons  Locked at 30fps
No dialogue to clearly tell players what's going on
Can't set your own resolution, game uses automatically uses your desktop resolution
Final Thoughts:
The game started off very strong for me, howerver delving deeper into the game, the world managed to stay consistent in keeping my interest from start to finish. The game was worth the wait to fully experience what the game had to offer. A great alternative to games of the same vain if you need something different.

Rating (8.3 out of 10)

This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

reviewText:
Quite possibly my favorite game on steam. Everything about this game is great, from the music to the art style and overall gameplay. I love how it looks like a simple adventure indie game but at the same time I love how challenging and difficult it is behind all the prettiness that is this game. You cant necessarily improve your character based on just leveling up only, I like that while there are a few upgrades and perks from outfit combos, it's mostly you learning how to improve on your movements and utilizing what you've learned to defeat different enemies. At first it's confusing as you don't really know where to go. There isn't any dialogue at all besides a few figures shown to by certain characters. You choose where to start, either north south east or west and just follow the path and see where it takes you. At first I didn't like that there wasn't a guide as to where to start, but really that's what makes this game so special. It's an unknown world and you immerse yourself in it. Once you explore after a few hours you'll start to get the hang of it. The bosses are amazing, the enemies are unique too. And besides all that there are so many hidden secrets and items to collect from outfits to gear bits. You don't necessarily need to collect everything to progress in the game, but if you're like me you want to 100% it and collect everything. And if the game isn't hard enough for you as it is you can try it on NG+ mode and make your life a whole lot more complicated.

My only complaints about this game is on collecting items, it was a pain to collect all 186 gearbits and having no idea where to look for the ones I've missed. The game gives you hints as to there being secrets nearby I suggest you look for those once you start the game so you don't realize halfway like me and go through everything again and recheck every corner. (They look like small little squares on the ground)

Another thing is I highly recommend playing this with a controller. You need to be fast in this game and moving around fast and precisely is pretty hard with a keyboard and mouse. It's much more enjoyable with a controller.

Lastly if you liked super brothers sword and sorcery you'll LOVE this. I know I did c:

reviewText:
The trees rustle in the distance. A faint summer breeze blushes against your cheek, then dies. Holding tight to your blade, you make your way though a magenta forest. The metalic taste of blood in your moulth reminds you that you don't have much time left.

Hyper Light Drifter is a post apocalyptic tribute to classical Zelda games. You are a crimson traveler seeking a profaned crystal in hope of finding a cure for your illness. That is all I can tell about the story, not because I'm afraid of spoiling, but because it's fairly difficult to figure it out myself.

Most of the story is told though the enviorment. Between the combat rooms, you travel though graveyards and laboratories, unraveling why the world came to what it is now. Impressive pixel art combined with an immersive ambience create a very strong atmosphere. So, even if you won't understand what you have played, you may still have a jolly fun experience.

Now, the combat. The combat is generally quite simplistic and consists out of dashing, hacking away and occasionally using projectiles. Most of the challange comes from being forced to manage large groups of enemies. In a way, you can classify it as a bullet hell. The dash plays a key role in the game, as you are given a few moment of invincibility each time you use it. So, most of the time in the arena one will spend as a pink blur circuling around the room. The difficulty demands quick reaction times, up until you get the upgrades.

Two extra medkits, a shotgun and the abulity that allows you to deflect bullets back at the enemy have a tendency to make most encounters anticlimactic.

After completing the game, you will probably realize that you've missed about 60 percent of the content, since most of that content is quite well hidden. Everybody is expecting to find a spare upgrade part under the stair case, yet items that unlock new areas and game modes are so criptic to find, that there is no way the majority of players will uncover them without consulting a walkthough.

My first playthough lasted about 10-12 hours and held my interest quite well. If you are a fan of dungeon crawlers set in a surreal apocalypse, mind giving this one a look. If you are hesitant, try picking this one up during the next Steam sale.

reviewText:
Pros: This game offers interesting challenges, great art and a wide range of secrets waiting to be discovered. Some sections of the game are merciless both in setting and gameplay and will probably require a lot of tries to get through. For character progression, the game rewards exploration rather than grind.

The Linux port seems to be working pretty well on a Radeon HD 7770 using the Catalyst driver. If you're gaming on Linux, this is most definitely worth it.

Cons: Any completionist will inevitably have to spend a lot of time trying to push through walls and peeking from cliffs. Some of the hidden secrets seem to be unreasonably difficult to deal with, in particular the dash challenges. Why would you ever do anything like that?

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my short played time....  I bought this game on GoG as well.

Yes.  Thats right.  I bought it twice.

LegendOfMetroidSouls - Legend of zelda - meets metroid/vania - meets dark souls.... what else needs to be said?

Oh, thats right. Its absolutely GORGEOUS.

And the storytelling? No words... but its all there, beautifully rendered in imagery... artistic interpretation and a sense of imagination is needed to get the story.

But the game play is so awesome and 'simple' to pick up, that if you are the type to ignore the story, you can.

Don't think for one moment though that 'simple to pick up' means easy though...

Yes, the game is forgiving with save points pretty often, and you just restart at that save point when you die.  Not if.  When.  You will die... often.  Get used to it.       (disclaimer - sure, someone out there somewhere will post a no-death playthrough eventually....)

Its gorgeous, it scratched the zelda itch I had been nursing for some time... and a few other itches I didn't even know I had.... buy this damn game already!

reviewText:
----------------UPDATE-------------------
I'm going to go back to playing easier games, like Dark Souls
------------------------------------------------

My review will only be an initial one, as I haven't progressed much further through the game (so I won't comment on story quality yet).

Firstly, if you're thinking of buying this game...when they say this game is recommended with a controller, they absolutely mean it. The keyboard controls are good, but the mouse aiming just doesn't quite work with the drifting mechanic, as often the direction you're indicating with the cursor will be drifted over, and so the direction of the NEXT drift is the opposite. So basically, joysticks all the way.

The actual gameplay is excellent, and there's a clear emphasis on the pacing of attacks for a hack'n'slash title. You can't simply ghost an enemy and spam them with melee attacks, as the melee attacks aren't instantaneous in their duration and therefore leave a window for you to be damaged. The pistol/gun is also limited in its ammo, and you must refill it by killing enemies. It means you can't simply spam the gun, as it won't get you through a battle alone. Gameplay wise, the drift mechanic is pretty fun. Apart from traversing gaps in the terrain, it melds well into battling enemies as a dodge mechanic. It also assists in breaking up battles with the previous discussed melee and pistol/gun attacks, and the game seemingly encourages you to alternate between them, which is reinforced by the enemy's attack patterns. Level progression is also extremely Zelda-esque, a large open world with marked objectives and certain areas to continue story progression. So there's linear story progression but in an open-world, though I don't know if this will split into multiple story missions at this point (though it could). The possibility of some degree of non-linear story progression is only suggested to be possible as some story missions require you to travel to fetch various segments that combined will unlock the next story segment, so there's a degree of non-linearity in mission completion as is (the closest example I can think of like this is FEZ cube requirements when unlocking new sections). Additionally, the game also implements an auto-save system, so dying will result in respawning either at the beginning of the level (often occurs in dungeons), or nearby before a battle area. While autosave locations can often be annoying, or make a game overly easy, they have been well implemented in Hyper Light Drifter and strike a good balance, being useful without affecting difficulty. I say this because the game can be f*cking hard at times and no number of saves is going to help you.

Where the game stands out is its audio and visuals, Disasterpeace delivering on another stellar soundtrack that really drives home the atmosphere of the environment drawn by the phenomenal pixel art. The illustrations are beautiful, and quite frankly, I've never seen pixel art better than this in a game. There are points in the game where you can just stop and look from piece to piece of the environment, noticing the detail put into each. I especially liked the detail put into the non-combat environments such the robots(?) frozen in time, covered with moss. It very much has Studio Ghibli's Laputa: Castle in the Sky" appeal. It's hard to top this art direction
date: its been implemented perfectly.\n\nIt's also worth noting the 30 fps lock. While it certainly isn't desirable
recommended: I found it to be barely noticeable even when playing with a mouse + keyboard (as framerates have an immediately noticeable impact on the responsiveness of a mouse)

reviewText:
I'm not much for writing reviews, but felt the need to for this one. As of this writing I'm about 1/4 to 1/3 the way through.

Flat out this game has a fairly high difficulty, exactly where I like it. Battles take much strategy and fairly twitchy reflexes, as well as old-fasioned pattern-learning that made the old games so satisfying to defeat. Be careful what you spend your currency on. I made a poor first choice, then had to learn to use the chosen ability tactically in order to get by the difficult encounters which followed.

Much to explore, and a whole worlds worth of lore to uncover through scenery, subtle hints, and vague yet amazing picture-based story. The soundtrack is moody, atmospheric, and context based, with layers being added and removed to suit the scene. Way to go Disasterpiece.

So far this is the best [released] kickstarter game that I was involved in funding. Get it and play it, it's worth every penny.

reviewText:
There are a lot of games that I have played, some of them were good and some of them were at least... awful. But this game made a difference. In my opinion, Hyper Light Drifter is a game that you have to try out and make your own idea for the game, but here are the basic reasons of why I loved it so much.
First of all, the creator of the game had this great idea of using pixels in this specific way. This makes it extremely realistic, something that I didn't expect from it. Moreover, almost every soundtrack in the game is catchy and related with the boss or region the character is located. Last but not least, I personally found it interesting to find secrets in the game, once it is really rewarding and it doesn't make it boring.
But enough for the pros, let's have a look at the cons. Firstly, there are a couple of glitches that are in the game, but they still don't ruin it and I am sure they will fix it in a couple of days. Secondly, the price is a really big problem, because I don't think that it worths 20 euros. I can't say, it's a really nice game, but a lower price would make it even better. In other words, if there will be any offer of this game, don't hesitate to buy it, or at least try it out and see how it goes.
All in all, it's a really nice game but I recommend you to buy it when it will be on an offer and once it will take a while, I think that the glitches will be fixed, too.

reviewText:
Tl;Dr Buy this game, the graphics are beautiful, the gameplay is challenging, but fair, and the music is fantastic.

I had a fantastic time playing Hyper Light Drifter.  I could go on and on about the bespoke sprite graphics that adorn this game, I could talk about the very responsive controls that make you feel fast, light and dangerous, and I could endlessly spout effusive praise about the music choice (I really enjoyed the West Area's boss music / fight).

If you want a game that won't hold your hand as you progress through it, this game is for you.  If you want a game that can visually and mechanically explain itself to you without a tutorial, this game is for you.  If you want a game that truly speaks out to the hardcore gamers who grew up on titles like Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, or Terranigma, this game is for you.

I implore you to try this game, Heart Machine did a wonderful job.

reviewText:
Here's a list of everything awesome about this game.

1. the art
holy god, the amount of work put into the art of this game - the big camera-panning landscapes, the player animations (even the SITTING animation looks badass), the enemy movement, the themes - is phenomonal. i've never played a more beautiful game in my life. sometimes i just stop playing and look at the art in awe of its quality. seriously.

2. the combat
guys. this combat system, while hella difficult, is a perfect fit for what this game was going for (after the addition of I-frames to dashing). the upgrades to your equipment and movement add even more variety to your combat strategies as you go on in the game wrecking enemies, dying, and wrecking them again until the next area. beautifully done.

3. COLLECTING THINGS
you heard me right. a game that lets you go around collecting things for both a dopamine fix AND progress in the game is gaming done right. modules, gearbits, monoliths, health kits... finding things made me so happy. (COSTUMES THOUGH)

this game has had me in chills since day 1 of playing it and i'll bet you it has for everyone else who has. please play this game, and complain how hard it is, only to find yourself elated when you get through that room. this is an experience we all deserve to share and have.

thanks, heart machine. please make more games. we love you.

I have no idea what's going on and yet I'm very invested. There is no dialogue but damn does the game look good. Otherwise, everything is trial and error. Is that a secret passage? Maybe. Can I jump to that? Maybe. If you're right, you're rewarded. If you're wrong, you're punished. The game is unforgiving. Is that an enemy who can hurt me or is it an NPC, or a squirrel-deer? reviewText:
Been waiting with bated breath a couple of years for this game to drop. Every delay to the release has been greeted with a groan. Since yesterday's release I've only been able to play about 3 hours, but here's my experience of Hyper Light Drifter so far.

For starters, there is no hand holding. No tutorial. I can count on one hand the number of times text has appeared on the screen during the actual game. Everything is learned by the player through well-crafted level design, first forcing you to learn a mechanic in order to proceed, then gradually training you on the different situational uses of that mechanic until it becomes second nature. This creates a satisfying sense that you have learned something organically rather than simply being told how to do it. Mechanics are simple and easy to pick up, but challenging to use very effectively. Best of all, combat feels just as tidy and stylish as it looks.

The pixel art style is truly beautiful if you like that kind of thing. The levels are detailed and gorgeous with lots of little hidden pathways and small details. You're almost always rewarded for exploring and experimenting with combining your abilities with the level elements. The game leaves it entirely up to you where to go - there's no objective marker to follow. It starts you out at a crossroads and lets you dictate which direction you want to start exploring the world.

Animations are simple enough to fit the art style, but intricate enough that they immediately communicate what they're trying to communicate. The cut-scenes are remeniscent of the classic *Another World* / *Flashback* games from the 90s.

As much as the art is stylistically pretty, it is also extremely varied. There is very little in the way of copy-pasting when it comes to the level design. Every map feels individually crafted, every part of the world has a different feel. The ruins of the world you explore feel vast but deserted and creepy; caverns and other underground parts are suitably claustrophobic and atmospheric. It's amazing how such a simplistic art style is able to create such strong and varied atmospheres.

The combat is challenging to the point of punishing, but incredibly satisfying due to the incredibly tight controls. If you die, it's almost always your fault, and there's almost always something you can take from it. Enemy AI is varied but surprisingly smart - enemies will dodge and flank you, and you have to be precise with your movements. Mashing the sword button will certainly not automatically win engagements.

You will die a lot. If you don't like punishing games and would rather romp through a story without being challenged at all, this really is not a game for you. At all.

The checkpoint and fast travel systems are very well implemented. You barely notice they're there.

The music and overall sound design is incredible and one of my favourite features of the game so far. If you've been watching any of the trailers or know of Disasterpeace's work then you know what to expect - dark, atmospheric chiptune-esque beats that ebb and flow with the on-screen action. SFX are crisp and fit the game's style perfectly.

Overall, I'm very much enjoying my experience so far with Hyper Light Drifter, and can't wait for work to be over so I can dive back in to the world.

My only criticism so far is minor: the game seems to be capped at 30fps. Nowadays it feels less smooth and satisfying than the 60fps I'm used to in most games, but particularly for a game with this kind of old-school pixel art style. While it hasn't hampered my enjoyment of the game itself it still seemed a strange limitation.

reviewText:
So far, I'm one boss down and practising on my second. Yes, the bosses can be a bit tough and in a less fair way it seems than bosses in Dark Souls. But if you've got patience from playing FromSoft's games (and their ilk), you'll easily have the skills to beat this game.
The best bit about it is the atmosphere and exploration. The visuals are lush and gorgeous and really help to draw you into the world Heart Machine have created. The music by Disasterpeace is very similar to Fez's soundtrack, but still lush and entrancing. There aren't many instructions (something I really appreciate) and you're left to your own devices (which I appreciate as well). I'm probably 1/3 of the way through in about 6-7 hours of playtime, but I'm sure it'll take me much longer to find all of the secrets, etc.

TL;DR If you think a top-down quasi-Souls-like atmospheric action adventure and exploration game is your cup of tea - go for it! You won't be disappointed :)

reviewText:
This review was published as of my first hour of gameplay.

This game is legendary. I have never in my life, AAA games included ever been so absolutley stunned by the graphics of a game. This is one of if not the most atmospheric game I have ever played, the soundtrack, SFX and visuals come together to make one of the most perfectly beautiful things i have ever seen. Even if the gameplay was terrible i'd recommend this game just for the experience. However, i don't have to recommend it on the presentation alone because the gameplay is FANTASTIC. The three combat mechanics I've seen so far are all wonderful, and blend together perfectly. As of right now i have a gun, a sword, and a dash. The gun is filled via successful hits on enemies/breaking random containers in the world, which makes it fit well in combat as it gives you a powerful and satisfying ranged option whilst never invalidating the sword. The dash flows well in both explorative gameplay and combat, and is exactly the kind of ability that fits the weapons you're given in this game. This game is also difficult, with healing items seeming uncommon and enemies dealing large portions of your health in a single hit. This being said, the game never feels impossible or unfair. This will be, no doubt, my Indie GOTY 2016. I only have two issues with it so far, and both are very minor. The first issue is that you can easily click outside the fullscreen window, and because i have a second monitor i end up going too far right with my mouse sometimes, causing the game to tab out. However, after an hour of gameplay i've taught myself to just not do that and it's almost a nonissue at this point. [[THIS WAS PATCHED DAY 1]The second issue i have with this game is that the death/respawing animation seems to drag on, and (possibly because i'm trash) i die a lot in this game, and sitting there waiting really breaks this game's wonderful combat flow.] However, these two small issues overall don't detract from the gaming magnum opus that is: Hyper Light Drifter.

TL;DR version

Game is really pretty, the combat flows like a river, and issues are minimal.

9/10

If you like the pixel art, great music and a touch of souls inspiration I'd say get it!

reviewText:
I am enjoying the game a lot. My biggest problems are with the dashing mechanic. Although I can use it proficiently, I still have three issues. The first is that, even when only brushing up against an object, the player gets knocked onto the ground. Considering how much clutter there is in the game, this is too unforgiving and deters use of the dash. Dashing feels much better when fighting a boss, because there is enough space to use it without hitting objects. There are no invincibility frames when dashing, so I don't think allowing slight collisions to slide would make dashing too safe.

The second problem involves the small cooldown timer when a dash finishes. Every time either a chain dash or a single dash is ended, intentionally or otherwise, it is momentarily impossible to dash. When the next dash is allowed to begin, however, it is actually made impossible to chain. It takes an additional second before another chain can start instead of a single, solitary dash. I think it would be preferable if the developers had made the earliest dash chainable and increased the initial wait time after the first chain ends. It's unsatisfying and frustrating to try to start another chain without knowing that it is actually impossible to do so.

The third problem is that, if a player performs a chain dash of over three dashes, they will slide along the ground uncontrollably when it ends. What this means is that a player will be punished for being exceptionally competent at dashing in combat. Sliding can send the player into pits or directly into enemy fire. If the developers had given the player some element of control during the slide, or if the slide took less time, it might have worked a lot better.

The music is a lot weaker than I had expected. Almost all of it is ambient and totally forgettable, whereas the trailer music was a great pleasure to listen to. There is nothing inherently wrong with the individual tracks, but they do not aid in forming the hills and valleys of the game's arc. The music is especially underwhelming during fights with the reprehensible cast of bosses, who deserved fearsome and energetic music to match their characterization. The music is written as though it always wants to stay out of the player's way, and it unfortunately succeeded. I had expected the music to be one of my favorite parts of the game, but that wasn't the case.

Technically, the game is unimpressive. There are a number of small bugs, although the debilitating ones are quickly getting patched out. The camera does not follow the player closely enough for the speeds the game allows them to reach, occasionally opting to observe a completely empty room. The camera is also positioned in such a way that many damaging falls are simply impossible to see due to the foreground. I am unsure why these ledges were not made into boundaries. I did not expect a perfectly programmed game from such a small team. All of the technical problems are forgiveable with the exception of the keyboard controls. The keyboard controls turn the game into a fight against the mouse, and I want to emphasize that if this game launched without controller support, I probably wouldn't recommend playing it. In their current state, the developers had an obligation to let players know that the keyboard controls are far inferior to a gamepad's, but I don't think that was made clear. Don't play the game on a keyboard.

Those are my main gripes. I'm being critical, but this is one of my favorite games to come out of a small development team. The gameplay is slick and rewarding once players learn how to move fluidly, allowing them to smartly chip away at the enemy horde. At least half of the game's content is in the form of secret areas, meaning that players will discover the game rather than having it shown to them. This works in the game's favor, because it is a game you will want to explore. The pixel art is gorgeous and dreamy, and I've caught myself ceasing play a number of times to gaze at a background or watch the movements of one of the townsfolk. The unique design choice to remove almost all written language pushes the player to explore the foreign world even more. All of the ideas, stories, and item uses are easy to grasp thanks to clever imagery and are presented more effectively and emotionally than they might have been otherwise. The sound design also deserves a mention in this regard. The gutteral sounds made by the inhabitants of the world are always interesting, and the harsh electronic noises that the Drifter creates give a great sense of weight to all of his actions.

Although a lot of people have been choosing to focus on the difficulty of the game, it is actually set very reasonably. Any young person with healthy reflexes should be able to beat the game with a good effort. If you have a history with action games, you will be able to finish this one. I personally wish the bosses had put up a better fight, since some of them came close to dying the first time we met. If the dash mechanics were a bit tighter, I'm sure every enemy encounter could have been made more intimidating without added frustration. Despite some visible seams, Hyper Light Drifter is undoubtedly a great game and experience.

reviewText:
I'm glad, I blindly backed every Kickstarter project I thought looked cool a few years ago when I had some money left over and then totally forgot about it afterwards. Hyper Light Drifter is such a game and boy, was the surprise nice, when I suddenly received this Steam key out of the seeming blue.

Hyper Light Drifter is a wonderful experience that combines calm exploration with beautiful visuals and a soothing soundtrack with punishingly hard fights. It's never too hard, however; the game just lets you progress naturally, in a Dark Souls-esque way. (I've never played much of any Dark Souls title, sadly, but after this game, I strongly want to, again.)

The game rewards curiosity and persistence just as much as it punishes greed and rush, you want to carefully explore the world to not die and lose your progress since the last save. The game isn't perfect tho; while hard, sometimes the checkpoints are mostly set between map transitions, sometimes in such a way that you can easily exploit their placement. Especially when you don't want to repeat the arbitrary collecting action after eery respawn, you just collect after respawning, leave the area, enter again and then you don't have to do so again - that feels a bit counter intuitive to me.

Otherweise I can't think of many other negative aspects in HLD. A few things, that positively stuck out, in my opinion, were the almost total lack of text in the game. Except for the HUD and very brief control explanations, all written and spoken language is abandoned, so the game focuses on visual storytelling instead. Also, Disasterpiece did a great job at the music composition once again and its implementation is superb. The music and sound design do their part on the non verbal storytelling and it shows.

I don't have much more to say right now, except that this game deserves more attention. I am sure more people would (and hopefully will) enjoy this masterpiece but I kind of expect it to become an insider tip.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a fun 2D action combat game which focuses on exploration and intense combat. You play as a character with access to a sword, various guns, and a dash. Combat consists of fighting off swarms of enemies with different attack patterns that require learning. With only five points of health and limited full heal kits, surviving takes limiting the hits you let yourself take and the timing/usage of your scarce healing.

The actual game world is a huge overworld interspersed with dungeons, secret locations, and beautiful, screenshot worthy resting places free of the combat's franticness, that just deserve a moment to take in. The world can be easily navigated physically through dashing to cross the many chasms and visually through the understandable map that shows both the surface and underground layers. There is a central city where you can upgrade your gear with the game world's currency. Surrounding this are the four major zones, which for the most part can be tackled in any order. Each zone has a different theme and different enemies to master. Each zone also has a major boss fight. Some may take a few deaths to fully master the pattern, but they are all very fair despite the challenge.

The game is a blast to play. Combat becomes a rhythmic mixup of swordplay and gun sniping as you work down large groups of enemies. There are a variety of collectables hidden throughout the game in many of the secret locations (hidden walls, out of the way platforms, etc). I've read complaints that wall hugging is needed at many points to find collectables, but the game does a very good job of subtly showing the locations of hidden places, either by having well placed visual indicators or by showing a peek at the location when you stand in certain spots. You know an area that you can't immediately access is there, so you'll be compelled to find the route to it. The game takes about ten hours or less to complete the main story based on my first playthrough of it. Yet, there is still more to do as I've yet to collect everything or start the game's new game plus mode.

I definitely recommend this game. I've had a few bugs and a few crashes, but the developers have been working since launch with updates to smooth them out. The game has a great feel. Combat is fair, but it's still difficult and requires learning. Nothing beats the feeling of beating a particularly hard mob, and being rewarded with the silent protagonist mirroring your feeling of triumph by victoriously throwing his sword into the ground. It's great, it's fun, and it doesn't require a whole lot of time if you just want to beat it and move on. Go with this game if you like the genre and art of a 2D pixel game with challenging combat, and more importantly a lot of heart.

reviewText: Hyper Light Drifter is a cybernetic ninja roaming the ruins of a once great society. He has a bad case of the blood coughies and he frequently hallucinates/remembers a cyber genie killing him. A deified dog appears to be watching his every move and dead titan carcasses are everywhere. What's a poor drifter to do but uncover every secret and murder every hostile in his path?\n\nThe designer pretty clearly had a singular vision for this game that really coheres together all aspects into a superb video game. Between all the secret areas, combat scenarios, enemy types, upgrades, unique boss fights, interleaved level design, tight controls, there's also all the gorgeous pixel art and ambient sound design. Compares well to Cave Story, Dark Souls, and Fez.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter, in a lot of ways is simply a action-platformer.

Although many say it’s a indie Darksouls game, it more in-line with Devil May Cry or Bastion type game, as there is no punishment for dying. The game's combat and special moves resemble Devil May Cry with gun-sword combat, deflecting projectiles, perfect-timed swings and platforming, the game also borrows a lot from Bastion’s top down game mechanics.

The pacing and level design of the game resemble more closely to a Zelda type game, with freedom to go to three available directions; East, North and West. In my playthrough I started with the North. At the North I learn hints of the backstory and lore through its environments and pictograms-dialog from engaging with the NPC. Talking about environments, there are secrets, hidden switches and hidden rooms everywhere, I once also found a hidden switch that lead to a hidden room with more hidden rooms. Which leads mean to say “Way too much wall hugging” thankfully there are community guides if you so wish to use them.

In conclusion, Hyper Light Drifter is blend of multiple great games, but does not simply just copy, but make it their own unique design and style. A great recommendation for all!

reviewText: Hyper Light Drifter can be best described as a mixture between The Legend of Zelda and Dark Souls. The game is difficult, but fair and, like Dark Souls, the story is never handed to you and if you want to know whats going on youre going to have to explore a lot. The game also has a total of four dungeons, that can be beaten in any order, well except for the South dungeon. The combat animations are fluid and the mixture of Sword and gun combat is quite satisfying. It is also very dash heavy as it is the only way to avoid enemy attacks. All upgrades can be purchased in any order from the start of the game, but the currency is somewhat scarce and hard to find so pick your upgrades wisely. The games lenghth is around 8 to 10 on your first play through and there are new game plus options for those completionists out there. The only cons I could think of is that there are no words said or spoken by any characters in the game, thus leaving you confused as to what the heck is going on, but if you like that type of story then more power to you. There are also occasional bugs were the a cutscene might trigger too early. The game is also locked at 30 fps so if you cant stand that beware.I would highly recommend this game to all fans of Zelda's combat and Dark Soul's style of story telling, and despite it's minor flaws I believe the art style and combat system are well worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
This game. Wow. I went into this game completely blind, being drawn in by what looked to be great visuals backed by a fantastic soundtrack all supporting tight, satisfying fight mechanics, and it delivered.

Don't play it for the story, necessarily. Just know you're in an apocalyptic world battling warrior raccoons, fanatic bird zealots, cannabalistic frogs, and artificial life experiments gone wrong, all while being haunted by a mysterious shadow. If that doesn't draw you in already, I don't know what else to say.

The soundtrack and visuals are so well-done and fitting for every moment in the game. If you press the button (or key) for down, your character will actually sit down and chill. This game actually made me want to stop what I was doing and just sit once or twice, just to soak in a particularly fantastic sight, accompanied with great musical ambience.

What I really love about this game, though, is the fight mechanics. You will die a lot figuring them out, but once you get it, you will be dashing all over the various arenas of monsters, slaying them with impunity. Reflecting projectiles and unleashing powerful charge attacks are just a few of the abilities at your disposal once you unlock them with the currency you'll find hidden throughout the map.

Speaking of which, if I had a gripe about the game, its the map. I would prefer to be able to know where I've already been, and whether I've found all the items in that area or not so that I do not have to waste too much time backtracking.

All in all, this is one of my favorite games I've played this year so far. It's so vibrant, fun, and challenging.

Dat north bird boss fight tho... I died like 50 times. Tread carefully.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well worth its full price, I had good fun with this game. Currently halfway through NG+
Controller recommended.


+Great (difficult) bosses. Well varied and interesting fights throughout the game. Good enemy design in general.
+Extensive amount of detail put into the game. There's a surprising amount of lore that's discretely and very well integrated in the game.
+Interesting and great graphics. The cutscenes especially are really well done and everything's great to look at. The music also deserves a huge plus for being memorable and not tedious.
+Extensive amount of content, challenges, and collectibles. Secrets are (almost) always hidden in reasonable spots that you can find if you just pay enough attention.
+Moveset is advanced and difficult to master, but also rewarding to use.

-Wonky collision, accidentally clipped at points and ledges aren't always friendly.
-Crashes frequently on Yosemite (10.10.5). It never got in my way too much since it usually happens around screen transition (so you usually autosave before the crash). This might also have something to do with my controller, haven't tested or anything.
-Some sections were more frustrating than enjoyable because of bad placement (or no placement) of save spots.
-Some achievements are broken. I didn't get a lot of the achievements I was supposed to get during my first playthrough.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Hyper Light Drifter is pretty much what I expected. Top down, 2D Zelda-ish gameplay but with more emphasis on combat. I've been following the development of this game for a year or so now and I'm really happy with the finished product. Gameplay is really solid and the minimalistic nature of the art and storytelling within the game is nice too. I felt that the game was a little bit too short but it was still fun; the trailer made it seem like it was going to be bigger than just four areas/bosses. Replaying the game to find all the secrets and to get all the upgrades is pretty much the only reason I would play it again. It's a really solid game with challenging combat, but the only downside is that it's locked at 30 fps. It didn't bother me too much, but I know people who would not be happy with that. Definitely recommend playing with a controller. All in all, a really fun game for its combat, art, and interesting world building.

reviewText: I have been waiting for this game for about a year since I backed it on Kickstarter. reviewText:
Absolutely wonderful.

It's a fusion of a Zelda game and Dark Souls that really goes beyond what those buzzwords would imply. It branches out to forge its own identity somewhere between the two. The combat is intense and satisfying, and really rewards careful, analytical play. It's not all about reflexes, but they help.

The story is told brilliantly through images from NPCs and a few cutscenes. The overarching plot is a bit vague but gives you just enough to go on, Each area has its own subplot that is relatively straightforward, but beautifully delivered.

This game is not too hard, don't let anyone fool you. I am terrible at games and I beat it. It just takes practice and determination.

reviewText: It was everything I was looking for and more. The open world, minimal handholding, and brutally challenging combat have left me satisfied at every turn. Nothing has felt out of reach but everything has felt well earned. The art and music are fantastic and the controls are some of the most tight and responsive I have felt in awhile. Overall a great game and one that I actively recommend to most everyone I talk to that asks what I am playing or what I suggest.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An action adventure RPG with some absolutely great elements and some... not so great.

It's a similar sort of game to one of the 2D Zeldas or Bastion. A joypad is pretty much required.

On the good side, it has gorgeous, stylish visuals, superb atmosphere and great combat.

Great music and ambience from Disasterpeace is part of why the atmosphere is so good.

As for downsides, the map is very unhelpful, and if you're bad at games you may well not finish this one. It was a bit too easy for my liking, though.

Exploration and finding all the hidden objects squirreled away behind hidden walls or unlocked via invisible spots is more annoying than anything.

Despite the great atmosphere, the plot is just hinted at here and there and is mostly left to your own interpretation.

reviewText:
I was a backer but I didn't pay enough to get into the beta. I haven't played very long yet, but so far I have to say I am really excited and the quality on display here is a fantastic reward for my modest investment! It's not as hard as Teleglitch but it's a lot harder than Zelda. Harder than Bastion with no shrines, but not as hard as Bastion with all shrines. The gameplay is action-RPG with twin stick and strong elements of hack-n-slash(-n-dodge, because you really have to learn how to effectively use your dash to best effect in the combat).

The pixel art graphics are done extremely well, really shows off the format and what it can do when used in a sophisticated way by really talented artists.

I'll update this review later, after I've either finished the game or lost interest (don't think that will be the case, though, it's a really compelling play experience so far).
