reviewText:
You have a vision: A gleaming city resting in a fertile valley. A quartet of glyphs held by angular beings activate, one by one. Suddenly their lights give way to an apocalypse. The city seems struck as if by a hurricane, and all it's wonders and horrors, crumble and rot in a matter of seconds. The once blue waters of the valley become as scarlet as they fill with the bodies of millions of dead. A crawling shadowed mass pursues you, it's touch a mark of infection, and looming mortality. There is something that can save you, a luminous crystal. You reach for it, but the shadow snuffs it out and covers you. All goes dark. You awaken to a storm.

Welcome to Hyper Light Drifter.

This is a game that drips atmosphere from every single one of it's stylized pixels. Atmosphere, mystery, and death.

Professional reviews I've read tend to give it comparison to franchises like Zelda, or Dark Souls. Zelda, due to it's exploratory dungeon crawler set up. Dark Souls, for it's punishing difficulty. Even the game's lead director, Alex Preston makes mention of Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, as an inspirational source, along with another famous dungeon crawler, Diablo. But from my perspective, Hyper Light mostly pays clear homage to the console gaming golden age of the Eighties and Nineties. As I've played, I've felt the ancestral spirits of other titles like Ninja Gaiden, Mega Man, Robotron, Strider, Contra, and Metroid looking on and nodding a solemn ascent.

Hyper Light, like these, is a reflex game. A death game. And if your reflexes are not up to par, if you have a low threshold of patience, and you expect it's world to welcome you and give you a handguided tour to the end credits, Heaven help you. In the wilds and dungeons outside the tranquil town hub, enemies come at you in droves and there is not a single one you will meet that is a pushover. Each one has a pattern of attack that demands study and practice, and just when you think you have that enemy figured out, and take him down, three more just like him take his place, and seconds into THAT fight, eight completely different NEW enemies show up, just for good measure. You've never seen them before, they're faster. Now young Skywalker, you WILL die.

It takes time and patience to learn how to fight, how to kill, how to live. It takes time to learn what it is you're even supposed to be doing with your life, such as it is, in the game overall.

What are you trying to accomplish? Where do you go? The map you earn in the town hub, for example, gives you an idea of where things are, but only in symbols and vauge approximations of distance and location. You refer to the map rather than rely on it. And the assorted menagerie of beings who inhabit that tranquil town hub I mentioned? Most of them won't understand a word you say, and you won't understand them either. This is a genius move on the part of this dev team. You are in a world of visual communication. If there was literacy here, it's long gone, along with the ruined city. Those who you CAN understand, relay their stories entirely in images, and their information may or may not be in service of your vague quest. Even when you speak to the vendors in the hub, who offer new moves, weapons, and upgrades, they aren't giving you a clear picture of how to pay for those upgrades. You have to parse that out through exploring and figuring it out while delving and salvaging in the wilds.

Some professional reviewers seem to fault the developers for choosing to be so cryptic, but they seem to miss the point. The game uses the atmosphere of it's world to relay the story, rather than depend on long tiring dialogues. It uses the environment to remind you over and over again, that you can only truly rely on yourself and your instincts. You are a Drifter after all, cut off from this alien culture you don't understand, trying to solve a mystery. And the only way to solve that mystery is to embrace it, descend into it, and accept the risk of death that comes with exploring it.

Hyper Light is an immersive experience, a doorway to another reality, and it is superbly put together. Control of the Drifter in and out of combat is simple and tight, but subtle pros and cons are attached to each part of your arsenal. For example, you can teleport a short distance in any direction you like, at any time. But each blink" takes the briefest of instances to recover from. In a pitched battle
date: such an option of movement causes you to feel powerful and vulnerable all at once. Blink with skill and you feel like a god

voteText: yet beautiful places which beg you to seek out every hidden wall

reviewText:
I backed Hyper Light Drifter on Kickstarter for $40, which got me a copy of the game on launch, a giftable copy for a friend, and a copy of the digital soundtrack and digital art book.

Hyper Light Drifter is a blend of its peers that seemingly inspired it; Studio Ghibli, Akira, Diablo, Legend of Zelda, Dark Souls. This is evident from the beautiful opening animation that stylishly hints at a greater world, one that seems to have been fractured by some nebulous but terrible event, beautiful but broken and now tainted by a spreading darkness. Atmospheric music and sound and wonderful pixel-art work together to create a hand-crafted and gentle neon apocalypse tinged with grittiness.

After a short intro sequence that sets the scene and provides some minimal tutorial, you are off into the world. There are dungeons to go into, bosses to defeat, weapons to upgrade, secrets to find. It's part Diablo and Legend of Zelda in terms of moment-to-moment gameplay, by way of Dark Souls in terms of storytelling and difficulty. This is a difficult game. But don't let that put you off. When you die you respawn at the last checkpoint (they are numerous, at a minimum once per 'area transition', but often more frequent). The challenge comes in trying to learn the enemies, how they move, what they do, and then deal with them with a minimum loss of resources. The bosses, all of which I found fun, are actual credible challenges requiring multiple attempts. They require you to learn their moves and timings, to vary your tactics, to try again and again, learning a little more each time until you can get them. And you will get them, eventually. They each took me about 20 - 60 attempts, some taking a couple of hours to master. On one I had to go away, thinking that returning later with new items and unlocks would help, but ultimately it was all about learning, timing, and trying again.

I completed the game in about 20 hours, which included a lot of travelling off the beaten path looking for secrets. The game is divided into three 'regions', and a fourth that unlocks once the other three are complete. In these regions you have several 'dungeons', partly linear but with multiple entrances and routes through the regions, it always feels like there is a lot to explore. You'll get lost, you'll go in circles, you'll find dead-ends and eventually begin to figure out the layout and what the requirements are for advancing in each area, you'll discover secrets... I was immersed in this cycle of exploration, discovery, challenge and story. I've seen some people say they've completed the game in about 6 - 7 hours, I can only assume they are much, much better at the boss fights than me, and likely made a dash for the finish line and ignored most hidden areas and side content.

In terms of story, whilst it is by no means groundbreaking, it is well told and does a good job of immersing you in the world of Hyper Light Drifter. I loved it, it is understated and subtle and slow, hinted at rather than told outright. Ruins, bodies, glimpsed vistas, flashbacks and so-on will drip-feed you the context-delivered story. There is no dialogue, no text to read, you discover it all through images and discovering scenes and putting pieces together. Each region has its own story thread, that ties into the piece as a whole, and you discover some context through finding survivors and other wandering adventurers who offer a glimpse of context through some pixel-art still scenes of their experiences. At the end of it all, I'm not 100% certain I understood what transpired, but I have an idea, the essence of the story pulled me into it and immersed me, I was going with the broader strokes and the finer details seemed unimportant come the final showdown.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent video game by Heart Machine. A few of its influences are clear from the get-go, such as the top down Zelda games, and having played through it, even recent games such as Bloodborne came to mind. That said it is still its own thing, with its own strong identity. This is helped by the brilliant art direction and pixel art animation, which is hard to fault. Disasterpeace’s soundtrack is moody, atmospheric and just plain gorgeous. The goal of the game is to activate the four pillars located in the Northern, Western, Eastern, and Southern areas.

The game could best be described as action adventure, with a heavy emphasis on combat. You start the game with a sword and pistol, as well as the ability to dash. Using the combination of these three tools is key to progressing through the game.  The combat can be fast at times, although in some trickier areas a slow approach may be advisable. The enemies are well varied, with some being particularly aggressive. Most of these feel challenging and yet fair, although a certain plant enemy did aggravate me especially with its hard-hitting attacks. Often you may need to switch up the way you face the larger enemies, and it helps the combat from becoming too repetitive.

You will find various other weapons throughout the game, and also purchase new abilities or upgrades. In the main hub area you can find a selection of shops to do so, and deciding what to spend your currency on can be difficult in itself. Unlike many games such as the Zelda series, the currency is a rare resource, with 4 small ‘blocks’ being used to make a big one. The big ones are then used to purchase new gear. These blocks are found hidden among the environment, or after defeating certain enemies and bosses. If you find an area or boss too difficult, you may want to search these out as the upgrades can help tremendously in the long run.

Exploration is another big aspect of the game. From the outset, you have access to three of four main areas - each having a unique look and feel. These are linked to underground areas, which are filled with hidden paths and secrets. Finding the majority of these hidden paths isn’t required to complete the game, but there are still some you may need to find to progress. This brings me to the map, which I feel could have done with a little improvement, since it can be a little dubious at times. A marker system, similar to the one found in Axiom Verge, could have been a great addition especially when looking for a particular item or place. Of all the areas, I found the eastern area to be particularly confusing when going back to search for secrets.

The boss battles are by far the biggest challenge in the game. The bosses guard the pillars at the end of the areas, and, as in games such as Dark Souls, can be as frustrating to fight as they are rewarding to defeat. Each will test your skills, in both dodging and attacking. Again the variety here is great, with each presenting a different process to defeat them. And well done Heart Machine to making retrying so painless; if you die in an area you start the area again with exactly what you entered it with. This makes it easy to get straight back into the action, and I feel a lot of modern games could learn from this (although loading times can’t be helped in games sometimes, but that’s another discussion in itself.)

Music and sound design are excellent; from the more ambient sound to the more upbeat tracks everything suits the design of the game. The sounds are great, such as the satisfying noise from your sword swings or the little beeps your companion makes, nothing felt out of place. Overall both music and sound only enriched the game experience.

Having taken around 16 hours to complete Hyper Light Drifter I’m extremely satisfied with the game, and yet I also want to go and play more, to discover all the hidden secrets I’m yet to find. Far from an easy game, it may put a few people off, but bear with it and you’ve got an excellent adventure. I found the game as compelling as it was addictive. While there have been a few bumps in the release, Alex Preston and his team has delivered a quality video game, one that I hope many others will play and enjoy. Their hard work and dedication should be recognized with such a well-crafted game.

I can’t wait for whatever is next.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter: the world's first Zeldroidvania game!

This is my early pick for indie Game of the Year.

Excellent, precise controls. Classic NES gameplay action. Intellectually satisfying. Ambient, beautiful music which never gets tired and always adds to the dark atmosphere. Text-free storyline and sub-plots. Easily some of the best pixel art ever to grace a video game. Possibly my favorite animation since Jordan Mechner's original Prince of Persia.

Criticism of this game has been confined to difficulty. These gripes are legit if you're too young to have played 80s-90s classics like the first Castlevania games, games which were challenging on a level that makes Skyrim and Fallout look embarrassing by comparison. This game is not a walk in the park. You should not buy it for the pretty pictures alone. Expect to *play* this game. You'll need skills and brains.

As for critics saying, First boss is impossible
date: I quit --" this mentality is a lot like
recommended:
"Great Expectations was an excellent novel until it got too hard for me to read."

Zelda's overworld + Metroidvania game motifs + art for miles + thought-provoking puzzles + evocative storytelling = indie GotY.

Get a copy. Don't even wait for Steam sales or Humble Bundles (which may not happen). This game is *easily* worth 20 USD. If you liked the original Zelda for NES
hoursPlayed: Castlevania IV -- Symphony of the Night
voteText: and/or Super Metroid on SNES
helpfulPercent: then this should be one of the best games you've played in a long time. If you love all three
votesHelpful: Hyper Light Drifter just might make it into your Top 10 forever."

reviewText:
After waiting for this game for 2 years.  It finally arrived, but at the cost of the game promised kickstarter strech goals features, that is still on the way.  Thankfully the base game itself is very much a complete experience.  Don't expect a long game, it will take you about 5 or 6 hours to complete.  Which to me is fine and the replay value is pretty high.

Hyper Light Drifter is a top down action/adventure game that is set in a mysterious Cyberpunk/Fantasy world of the unknown.  You play as a Drifter who suffers from a nasty disease and must traverse into this strange unknown land to find a cure, while dealing with all sorts of pearls.  The story has no dialogue, its instead told by the visuals and photos of what has transpired here.  It offers good clues and histroy about this world before everything became a nightmare.  I only wish the game did expand upon it, if it did have more levels.  Hopefully it'll come in later weeks or months.

Gameplay is probably one of the most fun experience I had in 2016.  It mixes combat bits from Bloodborne, Legend of Zelda and Diablo into a single game.  The result is a brutal, challenging combat I have ever played.  Be warned that it's one tough game, but I honestly think it's one of the most fair games ever made.  There's not one moment that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me the hell off.  A lot of deaths will come by your actions, so you have to be very careful on how you deal with tough situations in either 4 levels that you can start with at anytime.  Boss Fights are fun and fair, the enemies are designed well enough (thou I wished they added more, but we'll see.), the controls and combat mechanics are solid.  I do recommend playing with the controller either the PS4 or 360 is up to you.  The Keyboard & Mouse controls are underwhelming, it's very customizable but the experience is better played with the controller.  Level design is solid with good amount of secrets to find and loads of hidden story bits to discover.  You'll be sucking the life outta this game for some time, if you want to see it all.

Visually, it's one fine looking game.  I do think most indie games that tried so hard to capture the old school visuals of the past, but Hyper Light Drifter to me looks more interesting than Undertale.  The detail is solid and the animations are slick and beautiful to look at.  The Soundtrack is also good and it fits well to the game's grim nature.

Overall: While Hyper Light Drifter doesn't provide the ultimate complete experience that we were promised but I do hope Hearts Machine will continue supporting this game for quite awhile.  There's a lot of love been put into this title.  It isn't perfect as the game short lengh and only 4 levels begs for more.  But I strongly recommend this game.  It's challenging, fun and highly replayable.  It might be the best indie game since Shovel Knight.

reviewText:
Been anticipating this game for a while and everything seemed to have lived up to expectations.  World is unique and very serene, especially with the lovely Disasterpiece music.

Going in gameplay can seem pretty challenging but once you learn the ropes you gain a lot of momentum (and because of this difficult curve can lower off midway through)

Exploring is fun and exciting but the backtracking not so much,  the map design is unique but difficult to understand.  Looking for that last collectible in an area turns into a big chore.

But all that aside I enjoyed it enough to beat it basically overnight,  combat is fast quick and satisfying and bosses even more so.  There are many complaints about framerate, checkpoints, and the minimal ui but none of this was a problem for me (I also played with Keyboard+Mouse and didnt have much trouble)

Get this game!

reviewText:
Full disclosure, I pre-ordered this game months ago. I saw it and knew it was going to be a game right in my wheelhouse, so I am a bit biased towards the game from that perspective. I have about 2 hours into Hyper Light Drifter and it is wonderful.

The game is gorgeous, the controls are satisfying, and the soundtrack is very atmospheric. If you like atmospheric games with a more skill-based lean than story-driven narrative, this game will be right up your alley. I honestly have very little understanding of what is happening in the story or why my character is driven to do the things he is doing but I'm really likining the game regardless.

The biggest problem with this game is the 30fps lock. I really wish this game was able to get up to 60fps. Occasionally the frames dip as well when there are a lot of enemies on the screen and my computer is pretty powerful so this may be a struggle for lower end PCs. On the other hand, my CPU is my bottleneck so that could be the issue.

Play this game, If you're anything like me you'll enjoy the hell out of it.

reviewText:
What an amazing game! It's everything I expected it to be, plus more!

- Great atmosphere and world immersion.
- Super tight controls, if you die, 9/10 times, it's your own fault! YOU f♥cked up.
- The artstyle is beautiful, a perfect mix between an 8 and 16-bit style.
- Amazing soundtrack, made by the ever so talented Disasterpeace (the guy behind Fez and It Follows OST, etc.)

I backed this on Kickstarter (I was immediately sold when I saw it back then), and it is one of the greatest things I have backed.
It has been a long wait, but well worth it!

If you take the adventure and combat elements from The Legend of Zelda (a sprinkle of Diablo as well), and mix it with the mysterious world from Ico/Shadow of the Colossus, using visuals instead of words to tell the story, this is what you'll get!

Heart Machine has really delivered! They have also already shown us that they are in 100% touch with the community, people wanted faster respawn time, and a day after launch, a patch including that is here!

For fans of the games I mentioned in this review, HLD is highly recommended!!!

reviewText: With its slash-dodge-and-heal gameplay loop, it invokes Bloodborne and the Souls games, while also incorporating their difficulty. I'm not an animator, but as someone who creates from animated source material, I appreciate the attention to detail on visuals, which match that of games developed on a scale larger than even its own. The omission of any text from NPC interactions, and even the skill tree, recalls the minuscule nature of Journey, resulting in an experience that transcends spoken languages. The soundtrack is good. You can listen to it for yourself.\n\nBuy, play, and appreciate Hyper Light Drifter if any of this resonates with you.

reviewText:
Okay, so I'm a little bit torn on this one. It's still a recommendation, but only barely.

The gameplay is solid. It's part Dark Souls, part 2D Zelda, part Metroidvania. You run around and slash up baddies, collect some guns and fight huge bosses. Basically what you expect from a 2D exploration game.

Everything else though...it's hard to pinpoint what exactly is wrong, but I'll give it a shot. The game is very minimalist and this was done so by choice. There is no real story, no interaction with NPCs other than watching a few pictures, and the map is god awful. You will get lost just because the map says you're somewhere you're not. At that point, just remove the map altogether please.

The fact that it's an open world" game does not make a lot of sense to me either. Here's why.
From the starting point

hoursPlayed: health and gun upgrades with your funds. These directions and upgrades are not at all similar in terms of difficulty and knowing which way to go and which upgrade to purchase is almost crucial to make the later parts of the game easier to handle. Yes

reviewText:
The first time I dashed through a group of enemies to deflect a bullet with the same slash that killed two samurai just as my thrown bomb pureed a pack of space wolves was pretty satisfying. HLD is one of the first games in a while that feels like I'm developing a unique skillset through playing it. So many games now rely on artificial progression systems in the form of rising statistics to add that feeling. There are unlocks in this game, but I'm the one getting better at playing it, not just my character. The different abilities complement each other well once you learn to use them.

HLD might be one of those games that could be great to come into knowing nothing about it. On the other hand, I've found that knowing about the lead developer's heart condition has changed how I see the game in interesting ways. You're free to see what you want in the imagery. But what I've seen so far is a story about a character with a terminal illness, wandering a dying world in search of something. And the quality of the art and sound really helps to sell the gravitas of that story.

Be warned that the game is not easy. Some of the bosses are very difficult, in my opinion. But the game is open enough that you can always come back to an area later if you get stuck. There is a lot to explore, and the game rewards you for doing so. There are many times when you may have more options than you think.

reviewText:
Alright. Played two hours of actual game so far with the other seven being the Preview Build.

So far, I have to say that the combat is great and requires you to think rather than just mash the button over and over to defeat enemies, there is a variety of things to purchase and unlock with the golden things you find through the world that make your character and weapons better, the soundtrack is great and probably my favorite from Disasterpeace, the intro cutscene was amazing from the looks to the music and forboding feel, there are many things to find and collect in the world along with many hidden areas that are sure to give the dedicated of explorers many smiles during their playtime, I like the game having no text to read from characters and such-all dialogue is done through pictures when you talk to a character, them basically showing you what they are trying to say which gives the player the feel of piecing the story together and wondering what has happened to these characters, the game plays wonderful on a controller-I dont understand at all people complaining about the dashing or the combat in the slightest because every feels very tight and crisp, the visuals are great with a varied color pallete that is distinct for each of the four main lands of the game, enemies are varied in my opinion and all look great and have somewhat different behaviors, and lastly the animation on everything in the world and distinctness between every character you see and meet is rather nice and makes you feel like these people are making do in a world with dangers all around this city.

I recommend this game to anyone that enjoys rpgs in the veign of Link to the Past and the challenge and patience of Dark Souls style combat.

Part 2 - 17.5 hours full release completion

Basically all the stuff I said in the first review along with some extras. All the bosses were interesting and having some level of strategy to them with the things that made each of them unique from one another. The use of upgrades for both your weapons and your dash ability is super satisfying, killing the final boss with six of his projectiles reflected back at him was awesome. I personally enjoyed the story being told only through images, cinematics, and the areas instead of text like most other games. Each area was unique in design and asthetic and had some sort of backstory you could learn from the npc you can talk to in each area. As you play the game you are likely to grow attached to the other drifter you meet in each area and feel terrible and it is your duty to avenge him when he eventually dies. The six different guns in the game are, well, different from one another and call all be used to take on a situation differently whether you want to snipe at a distance, shotgun up close, or use a pistol as a utility between sword attacks. Half of the people in the forums are great people and have come together to find many interesting secrets, help one another, and even translate the igname language. The other half cant stop complaining about 30fps which doesnt bother everyone in the world and some people mentioned in the Special Thanks part of the credits (btw, the ST part of the credits is nearly always pooled from all the devs in any production, meaning that the ideals and thanks of one can completely conflict with the ideals and thanks of the others. It's like we're all human or something). All the different equipment sets provide you many different passive abilities that provide some extra replayability and thought when going into a boss fight or an area for the first time. Personally, my current favorite build is BlueWhite for my companion, Pink sword, and White cloak. There's also alot of collectibles for anyone that likes to get everything out of a game.

Overall, this game was a great 17.5 hour adventure rpg (nearly 100%) with great combat, visuals, soundtrack, and an interesting story with a bitter-sweet ending. I recommend it to anyone in need of a fun game that requires you to think and recommends searching every nook and cranny.

reviewText:
(10 hours of my game time is in BETA build)

Finally finished Hyper Light Drifter... I will regard it as one of my dream games.

I can go on about the breathtaking pixel artstyle and excellent sound design... but I will choose not to as you already can get the hint from the trailers and other users.

What I will be describing here is my personal unbiased experience of the gameplay.

PROS:

1) Fluid and Responsive combat: that requires the right timing in order to overcome your enemies. Every enemy has a window of oppurtunity to strike them hard including the super challenging bosses. Resulting in a deadly dance of death as you drift around the battle field slashing your enemies before they can strke you and drifting away at just the right moment. Rarely have I played a combat so satisfying, easy to learn and hard to master.

2) Bosses: seldom have I faced challenge in recent past when a game threw me a boss. Reminded me of the goold old days when overcoming a boss felt like a real achievement to show off. Every boss fight is unique and memorable!

Those negative reviews that you have been reading about super hard bosses is only a complaint of people who didn't try enough. Personally it took me around 10 tries for each boss to beat (including the last one). I am not a super pro at games and consider myself average.

The key is knowing your enemy and timing your attacks and using your upgraded abilities by thinking on your feet. It is NOT unfair. Bosses are supposed to be super hard. Deal with it.

3) Exploration: The world of HLD is brimming with secrets galore... every nook and cranny can lead to a secret pathway containing rare gold artifact that you can use to buy upgrades for your arsenal.

4) Enemy Variety: Every region has seprate enemy units, behaviour and asthetics. Never did the game become boring slash and hack button smasher as every new enemy makes you think on your feet to deal with.


CONS:

1) Short: yes you might argue good things come in small packages but yes I believe they could have expanded each region further and add more sidequests than the overarching quest you already have. More dugeons would have helped feel the RPG and exploration aspect too. However they chose to focus and make this game purely action oriented. A lost oppurtunity if you ask me.

The intense actions sequences could have been more paced out with longer gameplay and the loot collection meta game could have breathed more space with more environments and dungeons.

2) Upgrades: Though each sword and dash upgrade is unique and useful in their own way, I felt guns could have  been added with more interesting modules and addons such that modifies the shot pattern or bullets. They could have hidden these modules in secret places to make things more interesting... instead of plain upgrades to magazine.

Bastion is a fine example of how to enhance gameplay by adding tactical addons to your existing arsenal. I felt HLD creators lost a lot of oppurtunity here in that regard.

3) Lack of Adventure: You already have all the map revealed to you in the very beginning of the game. I felt it kind of personally took away the wonder and adventure of the game which is based on exploration. Yes the map is abstract, yes you dont know the terrain or the enemy positions of the regions before you visit them, and yet I felt kind of put off by it.

4) No proper quest system: Except your main quest you never encounter any NPCs giving you sidequests of clearing dungeouns / discovering hidden artifacts in lost temples. This serously kind of bummed me as I expected it to be an Action-Adventure-RPG instead they focused it on Action-RPG.

This could have elivated the game to an altogether different level. Side quests could have been equally cryptic in nature I wouldn't have mind that.

The game therefore feels a LONG fetch quest for your main questline.


RECOMMENDED If you like intense action RPG with a challenging gameplay and breathtaking art and sound production. HLD is one of those rare gems that comes out once a while.

It has its shortcomings only because they could have made this into a even bigger and better masterpiece of a game than what it already is.

Rating (if that matters): 8.5/10

reviewText: Hyper light drifter is a 2d platformer that is a mix of action, adventure and dungeon crawling. It's a game about a person (Let's just call him/her Drifter) that's on a journey through an old land of corpses, mutants and lost technologies. The game has solid controls (Controller recommended). They are always tight and responsive, although sometimes I feels as if they may be off, but I probably just suck. The game is already great, and that's shown even more with the beautiful soundtrack and stunning 8 bit visuals. Just looking at it, not even playing it, you can tell that Heart Machine really poured their love for gaming into this masterful  piece.\n\nSince the game has very responsive controls, it has a high difficulty. At many times, it felt unbeatable. But that just makes the emotional reward and love so much better and Oh so sweet" when you pass a trial. The combat has quite a bit of strategy from what I can tell. Drifter can attack 3 times before he/she gets winded. This is critical in fights because you have to know when and when not to attack an enemy. Successfully hitting an enemy fills up your gun gauge. This of course allows you to shoot. reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter (HLD) is a seamless mix of beauty and frustration. The aesthetics are beautiful, but you'll become frustrated by the horribly designed map and UI. The combat is gorgeously fun, but you'll hit a few brick walls in the form of highly difficult enemy group compositions and bosses. The story is lovely in its simplicity, but baffling in its vagueness. It's a battle you'll face between eliciting ooo's at the beauty and AHHH's at the frustrations. What HLD manages to achieve, much how the Soulsborne games have, is balance the difficulty well and make the gameplay so fun that you're willing to throw yourself against the fray again and again just so you have an excuse to play more, and hopefully progress.

Story
The story is deceptively simple. What it tells you is just enough to convince you that your hero has motivation to progress in their quest, but withholds enough to leave something to be discovered. There's a detachment between you and the character. The character clearly knows more than you do, but has no means or reason to explain it all to you. Even the information you get from NPCs is not spelled out for you, literally. The denizens of this world all speak in grunts and clicks, but their words are displayed for you in the form of pictures. This kind of story telling is a brilliant way to convey information and one I've always admired.

The lack of a language (aside from the monoliths, whose unique language is there for something for devout players to decode to get extra information) is also a problem for the player as much as it is a refreshing take. Maps and inventory management is all wordless, and littered with overdesign. The map is virtually useless and will never tell you where you are exactly, just a very general location.

The story doesn't really unfold through your actions. Every major step toward the end goal is just another chance for the game to bombard you with the same few scenes that you saw at the start, all of which detail either the future or events that have shaped your hero's motivations. Instead, you're expected to infer the story through your environment and the few interactions you have with other characters. Soulsborne does this much in the same way, but it has the added benefit of item descriptions to lay down some more connecting fibers. In any case, you can either play through the game and form your own hypothesis about the story or read forums, subreddits, and watch summary videos.

Gameplay
I mentioned before that this game is beautiful and frustrating, and that the beautiful gameplay helps to push you to want to overcome the frustrating difficulty. The game is all about its fast and fluid combat, peppered with some exploration and secret finding. Both combat and exploration are equally rewarding and enticing, calling you to tackle both with the same measure of dedication over how simply they are founded by complex they are in their execution.

Your first task in HLD is to explore. You pick a path of one of three cardinal directions and set out on your journey to that quadrant's unique ecology. The first few zones, broken up by a fade-to-black transition, are peaceful, serene. The monsters do not live directly on the outskirts of the centralized city. This allows you to familiarize yourself with the environment, and also find a few secrets.

Secrets are found either by running along the walls and finding a hidden alcove or finding invisible platforms to dash onto and find a nearby island of goodies. Once you understand this is how all secrets are hidden, you'll be running along the outskirts of every zone you find. Yet, the secrets are so plentiful that this never feels tedious or unrewarding. They offer resources that are sparse and you are happy to receive them.

The other half of the gameplay is combat, which is split into thirds: dashing, slashing, and shooting. Movement in combat depends on your dashing between enemies, either to escape or to close the gap and strike. Dashing is fixed to three quick dashes and a short recovery before you can execute those three again. Slashing is much of the same, where you are allowed three quick hits with your sword before having a second to recharge. Shooting is to be used to take out far off enemies that are too dangerous to approach directly or if you want to destroy those last few pips of their health, safely.

Obviously, combat is designed very simply. Even the upgrades are few as to not over complicate the process. However, enemies are smart, and many have moves that can take out almost half your health in a single attack. Some will trap you in a pattern and kill you without you realizing what happened. Each enemy has their own tactics and its up to you to figure those out and exploit the weakness in them. Does an enemy dash at you to attack? Bait them into readying their dash, and then dash before they hit you, then close the gap and hit them while they're recharging.

Bosses operate on the same rules, just turned up to 11. In typical boss fashion, they are faster, stronger, and have far more health than their minions. Still, if you remember the principles of learning the pattern and exploiting the weakness, they can be taken down just like any other enemy. Again the Soulsborne comparison is made. Bosses are tough, but they rarely feel so difficult that you want to quit the game for being unfair (there's only one boss that I felt was overly difficult, the Western boss).

Audio/Visual
Visually this game is a treasure. It reminds us that pixel graphics is one of the most beautiful video game art styles to date. Other indie devs need to take note and remember that pixels should not just be a cheap and easy fallback for when graphics are too hard to do for their game. Everything in this game's environment is loaded with so much obvious passion and talent for the craft. On more than one occasion I had to stop and admire the vistas of overgrown ruins and the corpses of giants. Too often a game is judged on a screenshot, thereby stripping away so many of the elements that make it work as a whole and painting an unfair portrait of the game. However, with HLD, the visuals are so strong that a screenshot alone could convince someone to play the game without knowing another detail.

Musically...the game kind of falls flat. The opening track is a haunting, synth-laden, and mesmerizing piece that really got me excited to hear more of what the game would give me, audio-wise. However, all the music after that is very bland, repeating itself after only a few seconds, over and over. The music is dreary, uninteresting, and doesn't help to motivate me or paint a good picture of what the world is like. Thankfully the visual art is there to pick up the slack and then some.

Conclusion
HLD is a work of passion and vision, first and foremost. It's a game that takes simple elements and makes them seem gigantic with how they are utilized. A basic combat system feels engaging, overwhelming, and exciting to master. The rudimentary art style of pixilated graphics is expertly utilized to create stunning and shocking environments and monsters. Exploration, as a concept, is limited in its components but never feels hollow, and is instead an enjoyable experience. The story, while vague, gives you just enough to get you started and leaves the rest scattered about the game world for you to discover.

Still, it's not perfect, and in its quest of the beauty of simplicity
date: HLD forgets some necessary elements. The story isn't developed enough, and the music feels uninspired and redundant. More puzzles would have been nice, and exploration, while fun, could have done with more ways to be conducted. I fully expect people to say $20 is too much for a 5-7 hour game, but assigning a monetary value to hours of content rather than the quality of content itself can only do a disservice to those nay-sayers.

reviewText:
(There's few spoilers here and there)
At the time of writing this review I finished main story with ~25 modules and ~10 keys.

TL;DR
The game's good, but it's not nearly as good as I hoped it would be.
I recommend you play the preview build which is much better than the final product in my opinion.

Full review (In no particular order):
+ Atmosphere is really good; excellent ambience music, detailed surroundings and animations.
+ Game looks gorgeous, and it's aware if it showing you few vistas from time to time.
+ I found the story intriguing from the very beginning, partly thanks to that creepy intro. It's minimalistic, mysterious. Its lore is interesting to dig up.
+ Fighting's done very well; it's fast-paced and you can always be in control.
+ Level design of most areas is impressive, most secrets have some hint.
+ Overall boss fights are challenging and interesting.
+ Enemies are somewhat varied...

- ...although each has max 2 attacks and most have only one.
- There are only few interesting characters/stories in the world. And they are short and simple.
- In some fights game throws at you large numbers of same type of enemies - it's challenging, but it's not interesting (conversly some fights have waves set up really well).
- open-world' doesn't work for me in this game. The world feels too small and cramped. I feel like it would work better in Demon's Souls style world with warpins only from/to selected places and no direct connections between the hub and the zones.
- weapon upgrading is just redundant in its currect form.
- some secrets require wall-hugging/sixth sense to be found.
- map is useful only for collecting modules
- Big problem is the amount of content that's not present in final product

reviewText:
This game is fantastic. I stumbled upon it on the day it released because I happened to see it on the front page of steam and decided to give it a try, I had no idea it was pretty much exactly the game I've been looking for. By the time you read this you'll probably have already seen the beautiful pixel art, but the gameplay and story that compliment it are really what made this game great, if you ask me.

Gameplay: I'm a big fan of metroidvania style games, with the 3D ones I've played being my favorites (Metroid Prime and Dark Souls, mostly). This game incorporated elements of some of my favorites, the fair but challenging difficulty of Dark Souls, and the exploration and upgrades I enjoyed from the Metroid series. The gameplay is similar to games like the 2D Legend of Zeldas and the Diablo series, and boy is it satisfying. The controls are precise and the combat is fast paced, making every fight a struggle for your life. With the upgrades and different weapons you can find, you always have a number of options for how you approach each group of enemies, which are always varied and interesting.

Story: This game has no words, no text, no numbers. The story is told entirely wordlessly, but what a powerful story it is. It's best if you play the game yourself, but I'll say that the story was influenced/inspired by the health issues lead creator of this game, Alex Preson, has dealt with all his life. I love environmental storytelling, and this game did it very well. I got a sense of this deep and tragic world, its inhabitants struggling to survive in the wake of incomprehensible destruction. The details are unclear, but that's what I love about this style of storytelling, much is left up to interperetation and I'm certain there's more I could learn by playing the game again to explore areas I missed on my first time through.

Difficulty: If what I've said so far makes the game sound like it's one you'd like, be warned. This game is very difficult! With only 5 health points and some enemy attacks that do two damage, you can die very quickly. You have to be careful and make split second decisions in the thick of a fight, such as Do I try to dodge the next attack and heal
date: or go in for the kill?" Any indecision and you may not survive. The boss fights are excellent
recommended: but don't leave much room for error. I found myself starting over many times on each of them
hoursPlayed: and sometimes surviving with only one health and no health packs left. However
voteText: despite this difficulty
helpfulPercent: the game is fair. I always felt like it was my fault and I could learn something from how I died
votesHelpful: and when I finally triumphed
votesTotal: that made it even more rewarding.\n\nBasically
votesFunny: the only things I would warn you about are the potentially prohibitive difficulty and shorter length of the game (about 7.5 hours for me
commentsCount: that's without exploring for hidden areas much). Nevertheless
column16: if you enjoy fast paced gameplay akin to the 2D Legend of Zelda games
column17: don't mind--or think you would enjoy--the challenge the game offers
column18: and like environmental storytelling
column19: you should absoultely give this game a try!"

reviewText:
Besides the motion sickness person, every bad review of this game is about the difficulty. To those people: Get better at games and you might enjoy them more.

The good:
The sound
The graphics
The world building
The difficulty
The choice to make dodging a necessary and core mechanic from the beginning
The choice of silence and storyboards to keep the immersion

The bad:
There's some places where direct progress is too hidden. Like, after you complete the first boss, it should be more obvious how to continue forward. Same with the entrance to said boss.
I definitely won't complain about the crazy number of secrets and mandatory exploring, but main paths should never be hidden.
You guys need to watch strangers play your game, without telling them how to progress, and figure out where they're getting tripped up. Do this at least 50 times. Tweak your levels when there's something at least 5 people are getting hung up on understanding that is actually mandatory.
I didn't figure out the chain dash until I had it for 30+ minutes, went back to the dash test room, and noticed the counter. Even then, it took 5 minutes of futzing around to figure out how to use it.

reviewText:
After waiting for this game for 2 years.  It finally arrived, but at the cost of the game promised kickstarter strech goals features, that is still on the way.  Thankfully the base game itself is very much a complete experience.  Don't expect a long game, it will take you about 5 or 6 hours to complete.  Which to me is fine and the replay value is pretty high.

Hyper Light Drifter is a top down action/adventure game that is set in a mysterious Cyberpunk/Fantasy world of the unknown.  You play as a Drifter who suffers from a nasty disease and must traverse into this strange unknown land to find a cure, while dealing with all sorts of pearls.  The story has no dialogue, its instead told by the visuals and photos of what has transpired here.  It offers good clues and histroy about this world before everything became a nightmare.  I only wish the game did expand upon it, if it did have more levels.  Hopefully it'll come in later weeks or months.

Gameplay is probably one of the most fun experience I had in 2016.  It mixes combat bits from Bloodborne, Legend of Zelda and Diablo into a single game.  The result is a brutal, challenging combat I have ever played.  Be warned that it's one tough game, but I honestly think it's one of the most fair games ever made.  There's not one moment that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me the hell off.  A lot of deaths will come by your actions, so you have to be very careful on how you deal with tough situations in either 4 levels that you can start with at anytime.  Boss Fights are fun and fair, the enemies are designed well enough (thou I wished they added more, but we'll see.), the controls and combat mechanics are solid.  I do recommend playing with the controller either the PS4 or 360 is up to you.  The Keyboard & Mouse controls are underwhelming, it's very customizable but the experience is better played with the controller.  Level design is solid with good amount of secrets to find and loads of hidden story bits to discover.  You'll be sucking the life outta this game for some time, if you want to see it all.

Visually, it's one fine looking game.  I do think most indie games that tried so hard to capture the old school visuals of the past, but Hyper Light Drifter to me looks more interesting than Undertale.  The detail is solid and the animations are slick and beautiful to look at.  The Soundtrack is also good and it fits well to the game's grim nature.

Overall: While Hyper Light Drifter doesn't provide the ultimate complete experience that we were promised but I do hope Hearts Machine will continue supporting this game for quite awhile.  There's a lot of love been put into this title.  It isn't perfect as the game short lengh and only 4 levels begs for more.  But I strongly recommend this game.  It's challenging, fun and highly replayable.  It might be the best indie game since Shovel Knight.

reviewText:
Been anticipating this game for a while and everything seemed to have lived up to expectations.  World is unique and very serene, especially with the lovely Disasterpiece music.

Going in gameplay can seem pretty challenging but once you learn the ropes you gain a lot of momentum (and because of this difficult curve can lower off midway through)

Exploring is fun and exciting but the backtracking not so much,  the map design is unique but difficult to understand.  Looking for that last collectible in an area turns into a big chore.

But all that aside I enjoyed it enough to beat it basically overnight,  combat is fast quick and satisfying and bosses even more so.  There are many complaints about framerate, checkpoints, and the minimal ui but none of this was a problem for me (I also played with Keyboard+Mouse and didnt have much trouble)

Get this game!

reviewText:
Full disclosure, I pre-ordered this game months ago. I saw it and knew it was going to be a game right in my wheelhouse, so I am a bit biased towards the game from that perspective. I have about 2 hours into Hyper Light Drifter and it is wonderful.

The game is gorgeous, the controls are satisfying, and the soundtrack is very atmospheric. If you like atmospheric games with a more skill-based lean than story-driven narrative, this game will be right up your alley. I honestly have very little understanding of what is happening in the story or why my character is driven to do the things he is doing but I'm really likining the game regardless.

The biggest problem with this game is the 30fps lock. I really wish this game was able to get up to 60fps. Occasionally the frames dip as well when there are a lot of enemies on the screen and my computer is pretty powerful so this may be a struggle for lower end PCs. On the other hand, my CPU is my bottleneck so that could be the issue.

Play this game, If you're anything like me you'll enjoy the hell out of it.

reviewText:
What an amazing game! It's everything I expected it to be, plus more!

- Great atmosphere and world immersion.
- Super tight controls, if you die, 9/10 times, it's your own fault! YOU f♥cked up.
- The artstyle is beautiful, a perfect mix between an 8 and 16-bit style.
- Amazing soundtrack, made by the ever so talented Disasterpeace (the guy behind Fez and It Follows OST, etc.)

I backed this on Kickstarter (I was immediately sold when I saw it back then), and it is one of the greatest things I have backed.
It has been a long wait, but well worth it!

If you take the adventure and combat elements from The Legend of Zelda (a sprinkle of Diablo as well), and mix it with the mysterious world from Ico/Shadow of the Colossus, using visuals instead of words to tell the story, this is what you'll get!

Heart Machine has really delivered! They have also already shown us that they are in 100% touch with the community, people wanted faster respawn time, and a day after launch, a patch including that is here!

For fans of the games I mentioned in this review, HLD is highly recommended!!!

reviewText:
Alright. Played two hours of actual game so far with the other seven being the Preview Build.

So far, I have to say that the combat is great and requires you to think rather than just mash the button over and over to defeat enemies, there is a variety of things to purchase and unlock with the golden things you find through the world that make your character and weapons better, the soundtrack is great and probably my favorite from Disasterpeace, the intro cutscene was amazing from the looks to the music and forboding feel, there are many things to find and collect in the world along with many hidden areas that are sure to give the dedicated of explorers many smiles during their playtime, I like the game having no text to read from characters and such-all dialogue is done through pictures when you talk to a character, them basically showing you what they are trying to say which gives the player the feel of piecing the story together and wondering what has happened to these characters, the game plays wonderful on a controller-I dont understand at all people complaining about the dashing or the combat in the slightest because every feels very tight and crisp, the visuals are great with a varied color pallete that is distinct for each of the four main lands of the game, enemies are varied in my opinion and all look great and have somewhat different behaviors, and lastly the animation on everything in the world and distinctness between every character you see and meet is rather nice and makes you feel like these people are making do in a world with dangers all around this city.

I recommend this game to anyone that enjoys rpgs in the veign of Link to the Past and the challenge and patience of Dark Souls style combat.

Part 2 - 17.5 hours full release completion

Basically all the stuff I said in the first review along with some extras. All the bosses were interesting and having some level of strategy to them with the things that made each of them unique from one another. The use of upgrades for both your weapons and your dash ability is super satisfying, killing the final boss with six of his projectiles reflected back at him was awesome. I personally enjoyed the story being told only through images, cinematics, and the areas instead of text like most other games. Each area was unique in design and asthetic and had some sort of backstory you could learn from the npc you can talk to in each area. As you play the game you are likely to grow attached to the other drifter you meet in each area and feel terrible and it is your duty to avenge him when he eventually dies. The six different guns in the game are, well, different from one another and call all be used to take on a situation differently whether you want to snipe at a distance, shotgun up close, or use a pistol as a utility between sword attacks. Half of the people in the forums are great people and have come together to find many interesting secrets, help one another, and even translate the igname language. The other half cant stop complaining about 30fps which doesnt bother everyone in the world and some people mentioned in the Special Thanks part of the credits (btw, the ST part of the credits is nearly always pooled from all the devs in any production, meaning that the ideals and thanks of one can completely conflict with the ideals and thanks of the others. It's like we're all human or something). All the different equipment sets provide you many different passive abilities that provide some extra replayability and thought when going into a boss fight or an area for the first time. Personally, my current favorite build is BlueWhite for my companion, Pink sword, and White cloak. There's also alot of collectibles for anyone that likes to get everything out of a game.

Overall, this game was a great 17.5 hour adventure rpg (nearly 100%) with great combat, visuals, soundtrack, and an interesting story with a bitter-sweet ending. I recommend it to anyone in need of a fun game that requires you to think and recommends searching every nook and cranny.

reviewText:
(10 hours of my game time is in BETA build)

Finally finished Hyper Light Drifter... I will regard it as one of my dream games.

I can go on about the breathtaking pixel artstyle and excellent sound design... but I will choose not to as you already can get the hint from the trailers and other users.

What I will be describing here is my personal unbiased experience of the gameplay.

PROS:

1) Fluid and Responsive combat: that requires the right timing in order to overcome your enemies. Every enemy has a window of oppurtunity to strike them hard including the super challenging bosses. Resulting in a deadly dance of death as you drift around the battle field slashing your enemies before they can strke you and drifting away at just the right moment. Rarely have I played a combat so satisfying, easy to learn and hard to master.

2) Bosses: seldom have I faced challenge in recent past when a game threw me a boss. Reminded me of the goold old days when overcoming a boss felt like a real achievement to show off. Every boss fight is unique and memorable!

Those negative reviews that you have been reading about super hard bosses is only a complaint of people who didn't try enough. Personally it took me around 10 tries for each boss to beat (including the last one). I am not a super pro at games and consider myself average.

The key is knowing your enemy and timing your attacks and using your upgraded abilities by thinking on your feet. It is NOT unfair. Bosses are supposed to be super hard. Deal with it.

3) Exploration: The world of HLD is brimming with secrets galore... every nook and cranny can lead to a secret pathway containing rare gold artifact that you can use to buy upgrades for your arsenal.

4) Enemy Variety: Every region has seprate enemy units, behaviour and asthetics. Never did the game become boring slash and hack button smasher as every new enemy makes you think on your feet to deal with.


CONS:

1) Short: yes you might argue good things come in small packages but yes I believe they could have expanded each region further and add more sidequests than the overarching quest you already have. More dugeons would have helped feel the RPG and exploration aspect too. However they chose to focus and make this game purely action oriented. A lost oppurtunity if you ask me.

The intense actions sequences could have been more paced out with longer gameplay and the loot collection meta game could have breathed more space with more environments and dungeons.

2) Upgrades: Though each sword and dash upgrade is unique and useful in their own way, I felt guns could have  been added with more interesting modules and addons such that modifies the shot pattern or bullets. They could have hidden these modules in secret places to make things more interesting... instead of plain upgrades to magazine.

Bastion is a fine example of how to enhance gameplay by adding tactical addons to your existing arsenal. I felt HLD creators lost a lot of oppurtunity here in that regard.

3) Lack of Adventure: You already have all the map revealed to you in the very beginning of the game. I felt it kind of personally took away the wonder and adventure of the game which is based on exploration. Yes the map is abstract, yes you dont know the terrain or the enemy positions of the regions before you visit them, and yet I felt kind of put off by it.

4) No proper quest system: Except your main quest you never encounter any NPCs giving you sidequests of clearing dungeouns / discovering hidden artifacts in lost temples. This serously kind of bummed me as I expected it to be an Action-Adventure-RPG instead they focused it on Action-RPG.

This could have elivated the game to an altogether different level. Side quests could have been equally cryptic in nature I wouldn't have mind that.

The game therefore feels a LONG fetch quest for your main questline.


RECOMMENDED If you like intense action RPG with a challenging gameplay and breathtaking art and sound production. HLD is one of those rare gems that comes out once a while.

It has its shortcomings only because they could have made this into a even bigger and better masterpiece of a game than what it already is.

Rating (if that matters): 8.5/10

reviewText: I've put in just over an hour into the basic gameplay but I played the beta for hours on end. Don't know why Steam doesn't show all my hours. Overall it's about what you'd expect plus more. The game is so challenging I actually lost count how many times I got close to dying. It plays like a mix of a zelda esque type deal with difficulty mechanics not seen in any other game like it. You won't find enemies just standing still the whole time and just waiting for you, the game will send them all at once at you, with no mercy whatsoever. But with the how stylish and fluid the combat feels, it's super satisfying clearing out a whole room with a mixture of dashes, slashes, and shooting stuff up. The overall atmosphere is just amazing, no level feels the same as the last with every room and every new area practically having it's own story. The soundtrack is downright awesome with it's different ups and downs moments and it makes every cutscene and every level you play through feel practically like a movie. Been waiting for 2 years for this, Heart Machine, you guys really nailed it. Can't recommend any harder, wish I could.

reviewText: SUMMARY: Beautiful, moody, and difficult, Hyper Light Drifter is a (mostly) nonlinear action adventure in a post-apocalptyic world - Dark Souls Meets Zelda."  Must-buy for fans of action-adventures looking for a challenge
date: the the design work is amazing and artistic.\n\nHyper Light Drifter starts with an 8-bit voiceless introduction about a strange
recommended: ill wanderer in a ruined land.  It soon leads to a central hub where the Drifter in question begins his adventure - with nary a voiceover and spare text to instruct him.  From there
hoursPlayed:
it's up to you to find your destiny.

It's hard to not talk about the game's artistry - the 8-bit look includes amazingly crafted backgrounds and enemies.  The music is moody.  The story is told through visual clues and "conversations" that show still pictures or simple displays.  The entire experience feels incredibly crafted.

"Crafted" also applies to the gameplay.  As your nameless hero (heroine?) and their helpful robot/assistant venture into this strange ruined land
voteText: you'll need to think about how you play.  Enemies have specific movements and patterns
helpfulPercent: environments can be used to your advantage - and most things can kill you surprisingly quickly.  The game's layout and enemies are crafted - so must be your actions.\n\nThe game largely focuses on wandering around trying to unlock other areas.  Wandering into new places usually means a confrontation with enemies
votesHelpful: a hostile environment
votesTotal: or both.  Your response to these challenges requires thought and precision - button mashing isn't always the solution (though sometimes it actually is
votesFunny: but in a precise way).  Each location has a puzzle-like quality
commentsCount: and though you'll die (often) you usually blame yourself for your mistakes - and try again.\n\nThe environments are semi-linear
column16: loaded with secrets and challenges
column17: and with their own stories to tell.  When not adventuring
column18: there's a central hub town that lets you improve your abilities.  The relative lack of direction leaves you many options
column19: though smart layout design gives you a reasonable idea of what to do.\n\nIt's hard to find a flaw with Hyper Light Drifter except it is very challenging
column20: and unapolagetically so.  It's not a game to play to relax
column21: unless pushing yourself and puzzling out things is your idea of relaxing.  If it is - or if you're in a mood for that - you'll be happy.\n\nA must-buy for people who want a challenging top-down actioner - and the wonderful art and music turn it into an experience not to be missed."

reviewText:
Such a great game, not one bit of text just pictures, scenes and areas representing the world. ♥♥♥♥ing genius. The gameplay is fast and quick like Castlevania. The movement and overhead view is pure Zelda. And the linear/non linear gameplay is Super Metroid at it's core. And add a splash of Studio Ghibli and BAM!

With all that said, this game is it's own world and truly stands among some of the best Zelda'esc overhead gameplay. Like on par with Nintendo. I want to see this game on every system out. It's truly worthy of it and reminds me of Shovel Knight and it's success.

And the music, just win. Even got a bit of that Genesis twang, which suits the world so well.

GENESIS/SNES/Zelda/Metroid/Castlevania/StudioGhibli (Nausica VotW) all in one title. Take my money! 10/10 Good work to the Dev's on this!

reviewText:
Admittedly I hadn't followed this game too closely, but the art style was enough to have me interested. So much so that when I'd heard that it was an action RPG, a genre I don't typically enjoy very much, I was still determined to buy it.

I am pleased to say that this game exceeds any and all expectations.

The story is masterfully and uniquely told, but I'd rather not give details; it's best experienced first hand. As far as gameplay goes, there are comparisons to be made between both the original Zelda for it's lack of explanation of who you are and what you're supposed to be doing and Dark Souls for it's combat that rewards finese, skill, and efficiency.  You may find yourself lost at first since, as I said before, you're told nothing and are thown into a huge world. It's a bit disorienting, but you'll eventually find your bearings and the world is an absolute joy to explore. The atmosphere is spot on, the landscapes are beautiful, and it manages to capture the scale of this broken, dying world tremendously.

A particularly striking moment was when I went up a mountain and in the distance saw the broken down, snow-covered corpse of an enormous mech of sorts lain on the side of a cliff. After further investigation of said mountain, I found myself next to that very same corpse; dwarfed by it's hand alone as it's lifeless body menacingly stared up at me sporting a gaping mouth and blank, dead eyes.

This game did something to me that no game has done in quite some time. It turned me into a kid again. I was on a journey in a fascinating, mysterious, and hazardous new world, trumping my adversity with the skill and precision I'd gained along my grand adventure. I wasn't traversing dangerous cliffs and trap puzzles because I was told to. I wanted to know what was in store if I'd completed said challenges. I wasn't angry when I was killed by a boss because I'd learned something from it and I was sure if I'd just adjusted my tactic I could defeat the new relentlessly fierce opponent.

That said, this game isn't for everybody. Even basic enemies can make quick work of you if you're not careful with your approach and bosses are unforgiving to put it lightly. Interestingly, though, the bosses combine the abilities of all the mobs in their zone which, in my opinion, was a fantastic design choice that forces the player to strategize, time their attacks and dodges, and really  make sure they know how to control the avatar. So they're challenging, yes, but far from impossible and certainly can be beaten in a rather reasonable amount of attempts.

My gripes with the game are minimal; a birdman NPC blinks in and out of existence for some reason, there's a strange bug where gear bits appear in one place but can be picked up in another, and I did have some slight issues with lag. That could just be my computer, though. It was really strange as well to make it so the player has to aim their gun with the left stick instead of the right; you get used to it, yeah, but I don't see why it couldn't have been the right stick seeing as it has no function anyway. Also I feel like it would have been better to not have a tutorial to add to the figure it out" aspect of the game
date: but that's highly subjective and I wouldn't dock any quality points from the game because of it.\n\nOverall
recommended: if you want a game that gives you beautiful scenery
hoursPlayed: fantastically satisfying combat
voteText: and a uniquely presented and gripping story
helpfulPercent: this is for you. This may not be the game for more casual gamers
votesHelpful: though
votesTotal: as those bosses can definitely give  you a run for your money.\n\nI'm not completely through with the game just yet
votesFunny: but as of right now it's an 8/10 for me. If the ending is good enough I can easily bump it up to a 9/10."

reviewText:
I had a long review written up, but then I accidentally switched windows and lost all that I wrote (R.I.P. me), so I'll keep this succinct:

- Story is told visually only, no dialogue. It's vague, a lot of it left up to interpretation, but told very well regardless. Expect a lot of debate over the game's lore and its meaning.

- Presentation is amazing, if you like retro stuff. Art is pixel art, all hand-made from scratch, and music is beautiful, most of it in the form of ambiance. Visuals and audio put together, it's a spectacle to witness. I advise lowering game volume, though, certain cutscenes in the game spike the volume extremely high.

- Game is hard. Very hard, in regards to both lesser enemies and bosses alike. Especially bosses. Not sadistically difficult, though, difficult in a forgiving, You messed up but can try again" kind of way. Doesn't hold your hand at all
date: but gives you many options to keep going. Death checkpoints are decent; some very forgiving
recommended: others not so much.\n\n- Combat is very satisfying. Sword strikes and gun shots alike have a big impact to them. Very reflex-based
hoursPlayed:
"stay aware and keep on the move" kind of combat.

- Exploration is abundant. Good amount of ground to cover and tons of secrets to find and scavenge for.

- Progression is RPG-like; have to find gold pieces that combine into full gold to buy skills/equipment from town hub shops. Encourages exploration to further upgrades.

- Kind of short game if you take away difficulty. I beat it in around 7 hours

reviewText:
This game has really good controls and great gameplay feel (on a controller), just moving the character around feels good, which works wonders since the game is heavy on exploration. The combat might be tricky to some, and even though the game isn't overly difficult it can be challenging at times. Once you get the hang of it though it becomes greatly satisfying.

The world is not only amazingly beautiful, it's also well thought out and seasoned with lore. The levels are really well designed and filled with secret items and paths. It all comes together with an outstanding atmospheric soundtrack by Disasperpeace.

All in all it's a solid and memorable experience and a GOTY contender on my list.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is an extremely compelling game that focuses on combat and adventure.

+PROS+
++ Art/Music are amazing and fit the atmosphere perfectly
+++ Combat is fast fluid and difficult
+++ There are a wide variety of enemies and abilities, making combat different and progression feel amazing
+ You are rewarded for taking your time and exploring every nook and cranny in the world to find secret rooms and pathways
+++ Bosses are threatening and very difficult requring multiple tries and adoption of new strategies.
++ The world is dense and the levels are designed with extreme detail to keep things challenging (in combat) and interesting.

*Note: If any of these things listed as PROS (Too hard, fast combat, etc.) do not appeal to you this game is probably not FOR you. {[I'm looking at you Rock Paper Shotgun]}

-CONS-
---My game crashed 3 times throughout the course of 8 hours.
---As of the time of this review, I had a glitch that when I died in an area only accessible by hitting a switch to activate platforms, I could not get back to the rest of the map. Thus forcing me to warp home and completely redo the entire area. Wasting 30 minutes.
-The options menu is pretty lacking, there are proper volume sliders, but I should at least be able to choose my resolution. This isn't a big gripe but it's always annoying to see games with simple graphics neglect such a basic feature.

+Design Choice-
+-Although I see the lack of dialogue as a good thing for this game, it does make most characters in the game very forgetable. But at the same time maybe they use that to reinforce the fact that your character is all alone, and faces this challenge by himself. So it is up for you to decide if you like that or not.

+SUMMARY-
Overall the game was a joy to play. The only text in the entire game is used to teach you basic controls. Other than that the game lets you figure things out for yourself. The set pieces are beautiful and the music really imerses you into the game. The boss fights are very difficult (reminiscent of dark souls), and the mystery of the story keeps you going throughout the entirety of the game.

*TL/DR*
Hyper Light Drifter is worth the $20 admission if you enjoy games that will challenge you and tell you a compelling story.

reviewText: This game is clearly one of the most visually stunning indie games on the market. However, it is very, VERY flawed. The game is riddled with glitches, most of which you'll find without even trying. Once, an enemy jumped off a cliff, and spawned an item in the ground that was innaccessible. The AI is hilariously stupid, and will often walk into a wall repeatedly or kill itself by jumping off cliffs. The collision is enough to make a grown man cry. Sometimes I'll jump to a ledge only to land on the very edge of it and fall off. What's even worse is that falling puts you back on the ledge and you're stuck in a loop until you die. Passing a checkpoint with one health and no health restores is a nightmare, as you have to pass the next few rooms without getting hit at all since dying doesn't restore your health.\n\nOverall, unless you can get this game for 10$ or less, don't buy it. A 20$ price tag isn't worth the struggle of playing it.

reviewText:
This is a fairly long review, so here's a summary of my issues: You will wonder around aimlessly without a guide in this game. It will waste hours of your time, and take away your enjoyment of the rest of the experience. Not only that, but using a controller makes it impossible to aim while moving, when the keyboard and mouse is able to do so that. Oh, and the map is by far the most useless map I have seen in a video game. This game desperately needs a mini-map, but lacks one. Plus there's just so many different little issues I see that it drives me mad anytime I play this game.

Just as a heads up, I'm writing this review out of frustration created by this game, so I will likely exaggerate a lot here. Even though that may be true, these are still some very serious issues I have had with the game, and I genuinely want to warn those interested in this game about. With that in mind, read away!

First off, I want to discuss the modules. Just to let you know, I spend most of my time in Hyper Light Drifter looking for the modules, which are these diamonds you need to collect around the map in order to fight the boss of an area. There are four areas in total, with four modules in each. But you wouldn't know that because the game doesn't even tell you what a module is, more or less what they do. Want to know how I discovered the name of modules? An achievement description. Yes, you heard me right, an achievement description. To make things worse, I only learned the name of the protagonist, and what their goal is through a Steam trading card. What is this, Destiny!?

Anyways, getting back on topic, the issue with thse modules, is that they are required to progress. You need to find three out of four to reach the boss, and then you get the fourth after beating the boss of the area. At least that's the pattern I see after enduring one area of this game. Now yes, it may not seem that bad, but these modules are hidden in the most obscure corners of the areas. I just spent an hour trying to find one, and came back empty handed, ready to write this review. Even after you get to a halfway point in an area, and an NPC puts the location of the modules on your map, it's still too hard to find them. In fact, that leads me onto another thing I hate about Hyper Light Difter: The map.

It is beyond frustrating to figure out how the map works. You may be at one point in the map, travel north in-game, and then you decide to check your map. But wait... what's this? You moved to the west on the map! Please explain to me how that makes any sense. That's why module locations on the map are mostly useless. They just tell you it's in that area" when "that area" is gigantic! It's like if you were trying to visit your dying mother in a hospital
date: but had no idea which room she's in. Obviously
recommended: you would ask the person at the front desk. But when you tell them your mother's name
hoursPlayed: they just point in the general direction of the room and tell you to go find her yourself.\n\nOh

reviewText:
Let me just start this review off by saying, I don't completely dislike the game.  It does a few things fairly well.  The combat is fun and fluid, the art is great, and the soundtrack is nice.

However, I feel like the game does a lot of things wrong.  For starters, my biggest complaint with the game is the world in it.  You have a decently sized world, but it feels completely lifeless.  None of the characters in the game actually have any dialogue, and all speak through pictures, the story is very loosely explained (And even then, it's EXTREMELY vague on what's actually going on), and while this has sort of become a trend in certain games, it just leaves me feeling disconnected from the game's world, and I don't feel invested" enough into it.
