reviewText:
Just beat the first boss, here's my impression so far.

Why I am already a fanboi.
Hyper Light Drifter plays like the old Zelda games. The world is designed similiarly to how I remember the Megaman Legends games. The way the story and world is presented however reminds me of Dark Souls.

To put simply, the game is very strange and mysterious, not really explaining to you what the protagonist's goal or purpose is. You are simply given a weapon and a healing item, and there you go, have at it. Very much like Dark Souls. The lore and the world itself reminds me much more of Megaman Legends however, aka ruins full with sci-fi artifacts.

The gameplay is pretty much the later 2D Zelda games (think Minish Cap and similiar) but on Steroids, aka the fights get very fast and overwhelming very quickly. This however makes every victory ever so satisfying. The only real difference I noticed in terms of combat is that it feels more weighty than Zelda and can be compared more to Dark Souls, aka if you find yourself stuck in an attack animation and the enemy is about to hit you, you are most likely gonna have to eat that hit.

The music is a matter of taste, personally I feel like it does a great job of emphasizing the atmosphere of exploring the unknown, without really knowing why. It can get a little bit too intense in certain scenes though, where the volume just goes crazy (I am pretty sure this is intentional, lol).

And now the bad
There are no rebindable controls for controllers in this game. While I didn't really have an issue with the default layout, people who wish to customize their controls to their own tastes are out of luck, unless you are planning to play with keyboard and mouse, which are rebindable as far as I could see (I didn't try the KB+M controls).

The biggest issue however, and this was discussed alot on the community hub before the game released as well, is the framerate. Without a doubt, the decision to lock a game this fast to 30 FPS was not benificial to the gameplay at all. Half of the time I die, I literally blame it on the fact that I could have reacted faster to the crazy amount of bullets and enemies flying at me if the game rendered more frames.
Is it playable at 30 FPS? Yes, without a doubt you can enjoy the game at 30 FPS, but at the same time it would have been better for it to be at 60. Overall, it's more of an annoyance than a gamebreaking issue, so whether or not you feel comfortable with it, is up to you.

Conclusion
Do I recommend this game? Oh hell yes, I do. The gameplay is stellar, the world feels compeling to explore and there are a lot of secrets hidden around. Though I would most likely have enjoyed it even more with a higher framerate, the 30 FPS lock is not stopping me from enjoying the game, at least so far.

So if you'll excuse me, I got more bullets to dodge and more pits to fall into.

reviewText:
This review is written with 2h gameplay of the beta build and 2h gameplay of the final version of the game. No spoilers ahead

Atmosphere: The game is just beautiful. Gorgeous. The feeling and atmosphere of the game can be predicted by the 3 trailers, but what you couldn't know is the love to details. The Birds still fly away if you walk near them, so this is a thing. But where I really was suprised is when there was a mirror which had a) a reflection of the player and b) I hit the mirror and it broke! That is just such a need detail. 11/10
The music fits the game great. After hearing that the music of the first trailer (which i love to death) was not composed by the composer of this game I was disappointed. When the second trailer was released I was worried, because, well I didn't really liked the music. Suprisingly the music just melts wonderful into the game while playing and just underlines the overall theme of the game.
The game has a feeling of solitude and mystery to it. There is not one english letter in the game so far. Just some mysterious symbols. The story is told by pictures. If you talk to story relevant NPCs they will tell their story by several pictures which you have to interprete as you see fitting. This was again rather suprising but in a good way, because this as well fits the overall theme great in my opinion.

The controls are pretty responding and feel very good, which is the foundation of such a game. It is hard. The combat is fast paced and punishing. If you don't time your attacks or movement well you will die. If you get hit by certain attacks you will get punished by falling to the ground, so if you rush headless into some enemys and one hits you once, it is almost certain that the others will hit you afterwards without giving you a chance to avoid it, because of the first mistake you made.
You have environmental obstacles which can kill you and will force you to think how you aproach a certain situation. So you will die a lot. Speaking of dying. You can't save the game whenever you want, it has like a checkpoint system. If you reach the checkpoint the game will save. So far these are in fair distances to one another and if you wan't to quit the game there's a message telling you how long ago the last save was.

The game offers a lot of secrets, path's you can't see on the first glance. Like in the beta there are invisible platforms, but it looks like that you can make them visible for a short time if you a) stand on them (makes the whole path visible) or if you are at the starting point you can use your companion (which gives you a signal that something is there) to make them visible.

So far I haven't understand how the level system (if this even is one) works (or rather what improves if you level up) or how the currency works in this game. Maybe those two are connected. The game will give you a really short tutorial, but it looks like you have to figure out most of the mechanics, which i really like. Hate those tutorials and taking all exploration out of a game by forcing everything down your throat.


Just one thing. When I close the game it will crash. That is probably not a big thing, because I wanted to exit it anyway, but it just shouldn't happen after such a long development time. A beta for a game was originally a thing to test if a game is running properly and if I will stumple about bugs or if the game won't start (error message) for other people (which i've read on KS) and other systems. If something the game crashes, bugs or similar, that is a no go. You (developer) deceided to exlude most of us from a real beta test and you did this intern for story and suprise purposes (which i can kinda understand), we got just" a preview build. So I hope you made sure that the game will work properly!

Anyway great Game."

reviewText:
Beautiful and vibrant pixel art, tight controls and combat timing, and very interesting story presentation.

Hyper Light Drifter is both unique and also barrows (perhaps unintentionally) from games like Transistor and Bastion but gives it a Dark Souls feel. It's a difficult game, but with repetition comes a mastering of the tools at your disposal. The combat is simple and balanced but open enough to allow a few different play styles.
Also worth mentioning is using a controller will enhance the feel ten-fold. The mix of great sound effects and synced controller vibrations is very immersive, and helps even more to bring you into this foriegn world.
There is one word of caution however, be alert and stay vigilant. Many traps and secret passages lay around the levels.

It's worth every penny. If anything I said interests you I guarantee you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
Is Hyper Light Drifter a good game? Yes - Here is why I believe so:

Hyper Light Drifter is a call back to the games of old - before the internet and online guides were prevelant. During this time frame (more so the nes/snes era) games had an air of mystique, most things were never told, and the world was experienced and not explained. This is the world of Hyper Light drifter.

Also do you remember the music of your favorite games of old? You probably do. Why do you remember this? Because the music helped to build the moment, and it was integral to the world building of the game that you played. Disasterpiece (who scored Fez) did a brillant job with the score. You really feel like a wander in a strange, but not outlandish, land. The highs and lows of the music correspond with the setpieces known as the backdrops.

Besides the atmosphere being a call back to older games, this game also calls back to a time before there were difficulty levels. This game is difficult, but not impossible. When you die, you don't feel like you were cheated - you just feel like you messed up. I feel like this is the mark of a well developed game - and Heart Machine should be applauded for their first time effort.

The gameplay of this game is like a mixture of zelda (the grand adventure), and the combat of modern ninja gaiden (fast and furious, with multiple weapons). The movement system that they implemented - a chainable dash - was a great idea as it makes traversing the huge map quite easy (you also have the ablity to teleport to certain locations at any given time - even in dungeons).

The last time that I felt so good about a neo-classic game was when I played Fez. The difference between this game and fez however (besides the genre/gameplay/etc) is that when playing this game, you will know if you missed something. You will not need ultra complicated maps, decoder rings, etc to be able to get the most of the game. Take your time, enjoy the ride. You will find all sorts of secrets that will make you feel proud of yourself.

So is Hyper Light Drifter a good game - in my opinon - yes
Its a throw back to the difficult and yet imaginative days of old - yet its formula helps it to be able to stand on its own without nostalgia.

reviewText:
So Hyper Light Drifter.

First, I'd like to say the game is a complete 10/10 in my book. I'd recommend anyone play it if they enjoy difficult games. I've also not beat the game in New Game + yet, I'll get to that in a few days.

Alright, onto the review.

Let's start with the combat system. It's great, easy to pick up. It's satisfying, challenging, fun, and balanced all at once. Enemies can attack through your attacks most of the time, meaning there's no stunlocking any enemies. You have to strategically plan your hits to make sure you hit the enemies enough times and then dash out of the range of their attacks. Multiple enemies can be hard to deal with, but that's why the game includes ranged weapons. Not meant to be used as primary means of damage, but the ranged combat is an easy way to lessen the numbers of enemy groups into more manageable sizes. Bosses, on the other hand, are really, really tough. You've got a lot of health to get rid of, and you only take a few hits

Next up is the visuals and sound. Both are fantastic, truly masterpieces. The visual style is simple in color, but the lighting and quality of animations and detail makes up for any and all mistakes made. Those mistakes are very few and far between, and very hard to see when you're just playing the game. The music is amazing, each area's music slowly changes depending on where you are and what's going on around you. If you're underground, if there are enemies around, if the room you're in is more of a puzzle room, the little touches make it all that much better. What else did we expect? Disasterpiece did the music for the game.

Alright, now we'll look at general gameplay. Most of it's self-explanatory. The movement system is great, just the perfect blend of slippery but perfectly controllable. The dashing system is a nice way to get around fast, and with some practice, Chain Dash can get you around even faster. There's been a few times when I've fallen off of ledges due to minor things, but it doesn't punish you much for falling out of the world. Health packs are thankfully abundant, if you explore enough. The upgrade system is straightforward, but I wish there was a liiiitle more variety in the way of things you can collect for upgrades.

There's nothing really to write on the story of the game, it's really vague. Play yourself or watch someone else play, then figure out what you want to think of it.

reviewText: I would just like to say, the level design in this game is one of the best I've seen in a while. Every secret, every hidden area, has a way to be spotted. You do not need to randomly rub your face against a wall to find a secret. May it be seeing it from another area, or an enemy walking through, or a tiny path.The games difficulty is great, you can get ability upgrades and more ammo for your guns, but from what ive seen, most enemy types have the same health, take the same damage, and deal the same damage. Many would say that that sounds easy and not hard, the difficulty of this game doesnt come from bullet sponge enemies" or stacking enough health to survive. It comes from using your abilities  to avoid damage and deal damage. The game is great and I highley reccomend it to anyone who enjoys a difficult

reviewText: As a consistent keyboard + mouse player I was immediately drawn to play by WASD for this game, as I've gotten used to in most other games. Unfortunately Hyper Light Drifter seems to be very poorly optimized for anyone arguing against using a controller, which I don't have the ability to play the game with in the first place. As much as I'm willing to sacrafice a joystick's versatile direction scheme for the simple and stupid eight directions WASD allows, I can't tolerate the fact that certain functions of the game seem to be broken by K+M use in the game.\n\nMy problem is only this for the time being: it doesn't seem to be possible to change chain dashing direction with just WASD. I can't complete several portions of secrets to the levels in the game without being able to do this. Until an update is released that better accomodates the use of a keyboard, I'm afraid I'll have to shelf HLD. I hope the developers find time to address issues like these in the near future.

reviewText:
Review: I have very mix feelings with this game, after playing for 24 hours I feel confident where I stand with this, so I will start with the good and lastly bad. HLD has done an incredible job delivering a beautiful, well-crafted game into a pixel art form with an excellent aesthetic and kind of unique per say, emerging simplistic but nice sound design helps to add beauty to this game. The game mechanics are very simple but it has enough depth to create very complexed and challenging both puzzles and fights, although sometimes it can be overwhelming making the overall experience enjoyable.
With a large amount of puzzles - secrets and collectables to obtain is more than likely you will spend 20+ hours to discover them all. The sense of exploration is but the lack of map only readable by the creators is comes down to your memory, is really frustrated to see how bad the map in this game is, it reminds me of FEZ a map that only the creators themselves understand it.

Now HLD presents a weird story, tackling a similar approach of games like Dark Souls where much is left to the player to discuss it, and create their own theories. The problem with this HLD doesn’t deliver enough content and ideas to even create a sense story. It was very disappointed for me see the ending, not only didn’t explained what or where I was there but the ending boss was super easy with 2 tries only I figure him out, in fact it was more challenging the waves of monsters in the town, or the 800+ dashes challenges than the final Boss, so all the hype that caught me to this point was left to bad.
The game itself personally think lacks of content, the only incentive to collect all the keys are sort of skins but not really, they are color palette swapping of your original character making you wonder wasn’t enough funding for this game to at least have some extra skins or features. Lastly CO-OP feels cheap, the enemies have same life so the difficult doesn’t increase and makes it easier, the second player can’t interact with the world is just feel doesn’t have the same impact in the game.

So Hyper Light Drifter as it stands now is beautiful well-crafted game that lacks of content and narrative design and feels more like a lazy design rather than simple. If you want some interesting story this isn’t the game for you, if you prefer some action game with quick fast phased the game does deliver.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really, really wanted to like this game. I spent 3 years following it after backing it on Kickstarter and was sorely disappointed with a game that could be beaten (although not 100% completed) in less than eight hours. Not only that, but I paid $20 for it.

Those who claim this game is difficult probably just aren't very adept at playing many games. The fighting is repetitive, predictable, and forgetful. There are only a handful of enemies in each section of the map and the bosses prove to be the most difficult, though not overpowering. The story, if you can call it that, is vague at best and the best part is that when I beat the game, it froze and whatever ending there was supposed to be, I missed. I'm not really curious enough to play through again to see what happened.

I don't see the intrigue to the New Game+ because the regular game was so underwhelming. The graphics are beautiful, the soundtrack is ambient and relaxing, and the movements are pretty fluid. However, the amount of abilities is pretty limited so there's not much variety to your attacks.

Again, I really wanted to like this game, but for this price, I just can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Take a pinch of Zelda, add a pinch of Dark Souls, and then smother the whole thing in a stunning audio-visual presentation--now you have Hyper Light Drifter!

The mechanics are decidedly old school: you run around a mysterious world upgrading your character and learning new mechanics as you fight monsters.  Every new mechanic lets you unlock new areas of the map and/or reach previously inaccessible locations in order to further upgrade your character.

The difficulty is best described as arcade difficulty
date:
really -- some may compare it to Dark Souls (ahem...opening sentence), but the truth is that the game plays very much like a retro RPG.  Meaning that there are stretches of quiet and beautiful scenery and music followed by frantic monster-filled fights where you slowly learn which threats the most pressing and which you can deal with after dispatching that  freakin' caster.

In line with the above, the game says it is best played with a controller, though I found that using a mouse works fine, too.  The only thing I would mention, though, is that your character's field of view moves as you move the mouse around to target/aim at things.  Before getting the hang of it, that mechanic produced a little motion sickness, so be careful not to let your mouse fly around (remember that almost everyting is accomplished with the keyboard.

In case you all are interested, my friend has started a playthrough of the game here (caution, spoilers):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6rU8Lyqm1Lo

reviewText: Let me start by saying, this game is hard. It is not something you can just hammer the LMB/X/A - buttons and succeed at. It's got complex combat and gameplay.  There is no dialogue.  The game doesn't hold your hand at all.  It's totally open world, and you are free to go wherever and do whatever you need to do to advance.  Boss fights are brutal, and a try and die and try again until you don 't die" situation....there were times I wanted to punch a hole in my wall or strangle a baby kitten over some of the mechanics in this game......\n\n.....and it is hands down
recommended:
one of the top 3 video games I have <EVER> played in my 40 years of life.  This game is Legend of Zelda meets Tron meets Tides of Numenera.  It is Dune + Star Wars + Mad Max combined. It is perfect in almost every way.

10/10.

PROS:

-outstanding game world in a post-apocalyptic future/medieval theme
-awesome array of weaponry and upgrades
-creative and unique boss and enemy designs
-music and sound are spectacularly done (I would buy the soundtrack!)

-complex combat yet with a simple design
-artistic
hoursPlayed:
amazing style
-animation is top notch and fluid
-so many secrets and unlockable places/rooms

reviewText:
I backed this game on Kickstarter a while back: September 2013. The presentation of this game was what really caught my eye and the beta that came midway during its development helped remind everyone what this game was all about.

Quite frankly, I've never been so mesmarized by an atmosphere since FTL and Dark Souls. Hyper light drifter did just that and more without any dialogue whatsoever. The game is mysterious and unfolds at a pleasant pace. The soundtrack is very grandiose and dynamically changes depending on the scenery.

The combat is very fast paced and it'll have you looking around like a bullet hell game ; paying attention to enemy movement and closing in at an opportune time. Even the creator of this game shared his thoughts on his game's combat mechanic, saying that he prefers smarter enemies over larger ones, and boy did he drive that point home! Even the easiest of enemies can dodge, lure, ambush, and flank the player during encounters!

Yes, I am in love with the amount of hard work that has been poured into the game and I truly hope there will be a sequel very much like this. Truly worth the investment.

reviewText:
Rarely a game comes along that gets me excited enough to buy it the minute it comes out. Hyper Light drifter is one of those rare games, and it doesn't dissapoint.

At the time of this review I'm only two hours in, but I'm already hooked. Hyper Light Drifter is a hack and slash that hits every note with perfect precision, and manages to add it's own beautiful twist that makes it unique. Let me explain.

The Atmosphere: You are probably already aware that the art style is absolutly fantastic, but the trailers don't give away the full story. Each set piece feels like it is well thought out, and each screen is beautifully composed. Even more so, the music adds to the atmosphere and mood without being distracting or obtrusive. The sound of this game strikes a fantastic balance between emotive expression and being a delicate background foundation to the game. Even the sound effects feel masterfully created. I can not rave about the way this game presents itself more. It is top shelf.

The Story: So far I'm only right at the very start of the game, but the story has already drawn me in, and it has managed to do so with absoltly no text. This game takes the idea of show
recommended: and it absolutly delivers. It didn't take very long at all for me to become invested in the characters
hoursPlayed: and the world feels very real and lived-in. It is hard for me to find fault. Granted
voteText: this early on it is entirely possible for the story to fall appart later on
helpfulPercent: but given how expertly the beginning of the game is constructed
votesHelpful: I highly doubt the rest of the story will be anything but fantastic. I'm excited to discover more about this world and the people who inhabit it.\n\nThe Combat: No game is perfect
votesTotal: and Hyper Light Drifter is no exception. The combat feels tight and responsive
votesFunny: but beyond that it doesn't really introduce anything too exciting. Combat is neither brutally hard nor boringly easy
commentsCount: but it can be a little frustrating. Enemy's attacks will follow you accross the screen after you dash out of the way
column16: which can lead to the annoying experience of dodging an enemy's attack only to have the enemy fly accross the screen and kill you anyway. Combat is a little punishing
column17: with enemy's two-hitting you from very early on
column18: meaning you have to play perfectly to progress
column19: and might need to retry a fight ten or more times before you can move on. The ranged weapon feels pretty underpowered
column20: with very limited ammo and an awkward aiming system. Using the gun often feels like a waste of time and effort. Your sword is much more effective
column21: and doesn't cost ammo. On top of that your abilities are the same powers we've seen a hundred times over. One melee attack
column23: and a dash. Don't get me wrong
column25: but it is only fine where the rest of the game is great.\n\nAll up this game does not dissapoint
column26: and I'm excited to see where the game takes me and what the company produce in the future. Solid performance.\n\nTLDR; Game is good. Spend $$$."

reviewText: Hyper Light Drifter has a magnificent aesthetic, beautiful soundtrack, and intriguing world. Unfortunately, this is where the appeal ends. reviewText:
Fantastic game. I've beaten 3 bosses now in a little under 4 hours (i left the game open when I went to eat). The game is punishing, yet rewarding. Graphically it's astounding. Play wise it's the exact opposite  of child's play. Let's cut to the meat here.

Pros-
1. Reminescent of Zelda, while having difficulty and mechanics you wouldn't find in a LoZ game.
2. Astounding soundtrack, with music that helps set the tone for every area you're in.
3. Stunning visuals. I've never had a game that I walk in to a water area and just stopped to look at how beautiful it is.
4. It makes you think. Exploration gives you upgrades, and upgrades keep you alive, though admittedly they are not completely necessary.
5. The story telling is done in a way that I haven't seen done this well in a long time. There's no words. When you meet an important NPC they show you what they need to in pictures. There's no hey go here". There's only a picture of the boss killing people followed by two more somewhat similar pictures.

Cons-
1. This isn't a con for me

reviewText:
Excellent, amazing, fantastic, perfect game.

Visually, it's one of the most beautiful and rich games I've ever played. They really put so much love into every pixel. The music and sound effects are awesome, no surprise coming partly from Disasterpeace. The combat can be super hard, but you can feel yourself learn and adapt to enemies as you play, and when you finally do beat a tough section it's so fulfilling. The HUD and menu interfaces are super minimal and straightforward and fit perfectly into the environment.

There is symbolism and beauty everywhere in the game, and it really makes the universe come to life. It's thought provoking and extremely fun.

reviewText:
Great game, very original and refreshing; it's hard to compare to anything but for me, it has a Legend of Zelda vibe to it, especially A Link to the Past.

It's not possible to fully advance into the game without exploring A LOT. You'll hug walls, cliffs, edges, trees, everything. If this is something that does not interest you, you might find the game tedious in the long run without a walkthrough. I'm trying to find everything I need to get (I think) the best ending and without any guide, it's becoming quite a chore because there are little to no indications.

Combat is visceral, fast-paced and when you use all of your arsenal, you get pretty powerful. It's not perfect, but it's unique and satisfying. You can unlock a couple new moves and ranged weapons that helps a lot.  Some people have been mentioning the difficulty, but I haven't run into any difficulty wall, most bosses were one-shot except a few that killed me once or twice. Even if it did go well for me, it is probably the hardest game I've played of this genre if you compare it to Legend of Zelda, Secret of Mana, Soul Blazer, Terranigma, etc.

The story is not told with words. When you talk with NPCs, they respond with sounds (the non-important NPCs) or images (those ones explain what happened/is happening in the world). Though I have not experienced the ending yet, I'm hooked. The emphazise on exploration really makes you observe the world with all of its details and that's how the story/universe of Hyper Light Drifter unraveled for me. Your character also goes through a lot of mini-cutscenes as you progress which kept me captivated. The whole setting is kind of mysterious.

I'm 9 hours into the game and I've killed the last boss. I'm exploring the maps to find everything I'm missing to see if the ending change. I haven't tried new game + yet. Expect 8-10 hours of story on your first playthrough. There's a hidden gauntlet/monster arena to complete and a lot of collectables that I have no idea what they unlock yet, it's exciting. If you're in for achievement/trophies, there's one that requires you to not die at all during a playthrough. That's plenty of hours, I'm sure.

TL/DR fast-paced and moderately difficult action/adventure/RPG with minimal rpg elements (unlock a few abilities and such through the collection of tokens), heavy exploration, lot of collecting to do, great pacing and memorable world/ambiance. Just get the damn game.

WORST GAM EVR DO NOT BUY UNTIL DEVS SORT THIS TRAVERSTY -666/10

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

April fools, this game is absolutely incredible.

The visuals have so much obvious love and care poured into them.  Although the game does have some occasional issues with visual clarity and clutter, it's more than made up for by the sheer amount of excellent visual storytelling, alongside animation that is both attractive and integral to the game's Dark Souls-seque combat system.  Gorgeous use of shape and colour, too.

The audio is an absolute treat.  The game's hazy, SNES-influenced soundscape mixes perfectly with Rich Vreeland's predictably wonderful musical score, that sounds not unlike what would happen if Tangerine Dream and Boards Of Canada did the sweetest damn collab ever.  Moreover, both the sound and music tie in to other aspects of the game on a  deep level.  Sound is often used to highlight enemy attacks and pinpoint hidden secrets, and the music swells and modulates in such a way as to offer punctuation and drama to the visual storytelling on offer.  It really is a treat.

The gameplay is tight and responsive but challenging, and punishes sloppy play.  Easy to pick up, tough to beat, satisfying to master.  This game wears its Legend Of Zelda and Dark Souls influences on its sleeve, and is all the better for it.  Bosses can occasionally feel cheap, but this is less down to overall unfairness as it is to complex attack patterns and strategies.  You will try, try and try again, slowly learning how best to chink away at its armour, and when you eventually defeat it, the sense of accomplishment is wonderful.

This game is not for everybody.  I imagine some people will bounce off its offputting initial difficulty curve and that the bosses will cause many a smashed joypad and ragequit.  However, for those willing to be truly challenged in exchange for some of the best audiovisual storytelling and exploration in videogames, then you can't get much better than this.  I've waited since the Kickstarter back in 2013 and I am in no way disappointed.

It's an absolute masterpiece.

reviewText:
One of the most beautiful and detailed games I've played. The story is mysterious and doesn't reveal itself right away, rather through the enviroment. If you pay attention to the opening cutscene and think about it some it starts to make sense and it is certainly not as limited as others say.

The combat is fair but challanging. The bosses will take some repitition and learning their patterns is the best way to go about it. This is not a hack n slash and combat is more like precise dueling than some sort of slamathon WWE poundtown. Strike when an oppertunity is available, then retreat and if possible throw a few shots from range. Just play patiently and you will be rewarded. When I died to bosses I found myself encouraged to go again rather than getting frustrated and quitting (which is my normal experience with difficult games ie dark souls).

The art is tremendous and really sinks you into the world. Make sure you take time to appritiate the details and enjoy the vistas, they are part of the experience! Don't rush through to complete this quickly as you won't understand the game or enjoy it as much. And while you are enjoying it, look for secret walls or cliff edges, they hold worthwhile rewards.

In all, I highly recommend this game. The difficulty is there but does not alienate those not typically fond of that (me). The art kept me motivated when I struggled and gave me time to breathe. The story kept me enthralled and thinking, but thinking is definitely necessary if you want to understand it. The $20 price tag may seem steep on entry, but the time I've put in this game (6 hours right now and I'm about half way through) does not reflect my enjoyment of this game. I'm usually the cheap kind of gamer but I picked this up first day 10% off and wouldn't regret paying full price.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter: A Modern Masterpiece

Hyper Light Drifter has easily taken the place of my all-time favorite game. The game is a masterpiece in all aspects, combining challenging combat reminiscent of Dark Souls with a unique style all it's own. The art style of this game escapes what can be described in words alone, a stylistic blend of otherworldly sci-fy and post-apocalyptic adventure, the game takes pixel art to an entirely new realm of graphic excellence. The beautifully crafted scenery and enemies are a delight to the eye, with the pixel graphics providing just enough fine detail to provide rich, engaging visuals while still allowing the player to apply their own imagination to the scene. The same can be said for the awe-inspiring story, told through vague images and leaving much to speculation. The story is exciting and engaging, but at the same time seemingly absent. The only clues to what you must do are the occasional vague hints told through images, leaving the player to their own devices. This seemingly utter lack of direction allows the player to make their own story, rather than having it spoon fed to them as so many modern games do. The beauty of this game is how it forces you to make your own choices and theories, not knowing if they are even remotely correct. This amount of freedom is liberating- nothing is given easily to the player, they must earn it through skill and perserverence. That level of satisfaction gained from overcoming an obstacle that this game provides in ample supply is essential to connecting and engaging with the player, and is missing from far too many games. The combat is tough but fair, constantly keeping the player on their toes. Combat is fast paced, yet crisp and responsive, with varied and challenging enemies. The soundtrack is a wonder of audio engineering, with scores ranging from light, enchanting melodies to dark, gritty anthems that set the player on edge. The music completes a rich, ambient overall style with the artwork, a beautiful blend that engrosses and envelops the player.

TL:DR
This is a masterpiece of modern game design and it would be a disservice to both yourself and society as a whole to not buy it.
Overall rating: 10/10; Pinnacle of modern game design.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent game. 9/10. Would recommend. Read below for further details.

PROS
- Atmosphere: From the very beginning you are sucked into this world. The music and art design blend together wonderfully creating a drive to explore your surroundings.

- Combat: Battles require precision over mashing. The controls felt tight and once you understand what enemies are capable of battles become a dance. You'll battle melee and ranged foes, sometimes at once. Dispaching a room of enemies without taking damage is very satisfying.

- Level design: There are four distinct areas to explore in HLD. There is a minimap but I rarely had to use it. The levels have enough branching paths but not too many that you get lost often. There are NUMEROUS hidden nooks and crannies to find. There are some environmental tells but the visuals are so cohesive that the player really has to look and explore to find extra goodies. This is where the dash movement mechanic really shines as you'll constantly find yourself dsahing across gaps to small ledges in search of secrets. The developers really did setup the environment to syngergize with the core movement mechanic of dashing.

- Boss Battles: While many people feel the battles are too hard, I though the difficulty was well tuned. All of the bosses have a unique visual design and require different strategies to beat. There was never a boss I had to replay more than seven times (including the final boss). You revive right outside the boss room and a recent patch sped up the player death animation so restarting was not frustratingand after every death. The battles are tense and require constant focus but that makes victory that much more satisfying. I was able to beat the entire game without buying any healing upgrades so with healing fully upgraded I feel many players can complete the game if they learn the patterns and stay determined.

CONS
- Upgrade System: Melee attacks, movement abilities, and the secondary gun can be upgraded along with a few other things. In keeping with zero dialogue or explanatory text the upgrades merely show a quick clip of what they are. This does leave some ambiguity in what new abilities do. Also, as all upgrades can be purchased from the beginning, choosing an upgrade is simply guesswork. All of the abilities are useful (to an extent) but the currency to purchase them has to be found through exploration so new upgrades can only be purchased so quickly. Buy one you won't need for some time and you're out currency and the gameplay doesnt change. I did a decent amount of additional exploration and did not find enough currency to upgrade everything. Not a problem to me personally but then I was happy with what I chose to upgrade.

- Autosave System: I understand why the game has auto-save. It allows the devs to provide difficult sections of the game. The game saves so often I don't think I was never bothered but life does happen so be aware you can't stop playing whenever you want (unless you don't mind replaying a section).

- Length: I was only lost once that I can recall and I didn't waste much time dashing around (for a certain achievement) and I beat the game in six hours. I was hoping for an 8-10 hour experience. There is a new game plus and I didn't get all the collectables but for what I'm calling the main game, it was a tad short.

Overall Impression
- Hyper Light Drifter was worth the 18 USD (sale price). Some of the best boss fights I've played. Great combat. The story presentation being purely visual challenged me to think about the world and what the Drifter's purpose was. Is the game difficult? At times, but you are given all the tools to overcome. Like many of the best indie games, Hyper Light Drifter provides a unique and focused experience you will not get anywhere else.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a game I'd been excited for for the past couple years now and I'm happy to say it does not disappoint. The visuals are some of the most beautiful I've seen in the pixel art genre, and there are various astonishing sights to see, some of which I would stop to study for a couple minutes. The soundtrack is great too, Disasterpeace does some of the most unique chiptune music I've ever heard.

Before playing I was a little worried since a lot of people have been saying the game is too hard and frustrating to be fun, but after playing it through I wholeheartedly disagree. The bosses are very hard, that I wont deny anyone, but I found all of them really engaging and never frustrating, even though I died repeatedly on a few of them. Combat in this game is more about being aware of your surroundings and timing your actions than simply mashing buttons. I'm not against the idea of an easier difficulty setting for people who don't play this type of game often, but the experience of finally getting it down and sticking it to a boss is really satisfying. Some of the game's appeal would be lost without it.

I finished the game in about 8 or 9 hours of play time, though I feel like there were a lot of secrets I missed, and there is a new game + mode as well so replay value seems good. Definitely will be playing this more in the future.

reviewText:
9 / 10

A truly deserved rating, this game is the destination in storytelling that so many other indie games have tried and failed to reach. With a fantastic and creative world to explore, difficult to master mechanics and an immersive soundscape, Hyper Light Drifter left me wanting more, but more than satisfied with what I got. Its cryptic hints at a background story and its beautiful art whet my appetite in a way no game has since The Legend of Zelda. A series based on this game could have the potential to become a major hit in the indie gaming world, and far beyond.

We can only hope for a sequel.

reviewText:
One of the most beautiful and detailed games I've played. The story is mysterious and doesn't reveal itself right away, rather through the enviroment. If you pay attention to the opening cutscene and think about it some it starts to make sense and it is certainly not as limited as others say.

The combat is fair but challanging. The bosses will take some repitition and learning their patterns is the best way to go about it. This is not a hack n slash and combat is more like precise dueling than some sort of slamathon WWE poundtown. Strike when an oppertunity is available, then retreat and if possible throw a few shots from range. Just play patiently and you will be rewarded. When I died to bosses I found myself encouraged to go again rather than getting frustrated and quitting (which is my normal experience with difficult games ie dark souls).

The art is tremendous and really sinks you into the world. Make sure you take time to appritiate the details and enjoy the vistas, they are part of the experience! Don't rush through to complete this quickly as you won't understand the game or enjoy it as much. And while you are enjoying it, look for secret walls or cliff edges, they hold worthwhile rewards.

In all, I highly recommend this game. The difficulty is there but does not alienate those not typically fond of that (me). The art kept me motivated when I struggled and gave me time to breathe. The story kept me enthralled and thinking, but thinking is definitely necessary if you want to understand it. The $20 price tag may seem steep on entry, but the time I've put in this game (6 hours right now and I'm about half way through) does not reflect my enjoyment of this game. I'm usually the cheap kind of gamer but I picked this up first day 10% off and wouldn't regret paying full price.

reviewText:
With top down gameplay inspired by zelda with a dash of unforgiving fast paced combat, HLD was worth the price of admission. The music atmosphere and animations make enemies and the main character a pleasure to watch as they attempt to dismantle eachother. The game is also dense with secrets, with unfortunately some boiling down to running against walls and leaps of faith.

I would wadger that a casual play through might clock in at 7-8 hours, depending on how many upgrades your willing to search high and low to finance. Almost all important additions to your abilities are bought from trainers, with the exception of guns that mostly lie behind the games major boss fights. Some are more useful then others: the chain dash is extremely important but upgrading your pistol clip or learning the slash into dash can wait.

There are issues: frame rate can make executing some of your moves difficult. Your character will sometimes drop dashes when chaining them and there's not much to do, and it gets annoying trying to execute a 7+ chain dash required to clear some of the more difficult puzzels and your imput dropping or your character skidding to his certain death. The secrets in some areas are well marked, but those same markers in the same broad area might just be junk on the floor. It is compounded partially by the style of graphics: the charming pixels with tons of doo-dads on the walls and floor mean that it looks like everything might have a switch or passage behind it.

You can't track where you've found things aside from the games diamond shards (which act as keys for progression) so you might wander an area for hours trying to find elusive secret collectables only to learn apon consulting a map that you've already cleaned it out long ago. Most of the rewards as you move to full collections tend to be minor: there are outfits that have different effects on them of varying use (some are quite subtle) but the most powerful effects they have are generally obtained past when they mattered anyway.

That being said there's a lot of fun to be had exploring and buying upgrades and fighting some very intense ambushes and bosses in the grim but very colorful ruins of hyper light drifter.

reviewText:
That feeling when beating some kid in a football minigame is more difficult than destroying the eldritch nightmares that haunt every second of your waking existence...
Bloody hell the football minigame and the hyper-dash-challenge-thing are massive difficulty spikes. Whose idea was it to make you dash 800 times in a row? Sadistic. I got to six-hundred and something and buckled under the pressure and wrist strain. Why is the football kid such a prick? I'm supposed to be a hero or something, why do they want to hip-check me the second I get within a couple feet? Brutal.
All right, that's all the salt out of me. This game may well be the first of any that I've seen on Steam, looked into a little, and then immediately bought without discussing it with friends. Haven't regretted that decision in the slightest (bar good-natured football kid hate). The game recommends you use a controller, but I recently switched over to using keyboard and mouse instead and I think I actually prefer it - if you want to use k&m, don't feel discouraged. Both options are definitely viable.
Gameplay is fantastic; it has what I gather are Legend of Zelda and Souls Series vibes to it, with a few platformer elements thrown in. Exploration, combat and difficulty definitely seems reminiscent of the impression I got of Bloodborne, with the caveat that checkpoints for the most part seem a bit more frequent/forgiving.
It can be a bit challenging to figure out what some things are supposed to do and what your objectives actually are, but considering the almost complete lack of text in the game it's probably pretty fantastic that a blind playthrough is even possible, which it very much is, even if the secrets are pretty easily missable. Luckily, most problems can be solved with the tried-and-tested go wherever you haven't been yet and interact with whatever looks important" method.
It's good. Well worth the £15. Would recommend."

reviewText:
Not for the impatient, but utterly beautiful nonetheless
I am, due to current financial constraints, not accustomed to buying games outright, especially not at full price. But I had anticipated Hyper Light Drifter for a few months simply going off the trailer, and incredibly, it actually fully held up to my internal hype. The world is absolutely gorgeous, from the central hub to the various worlds to the north, east, etc. Each area has something unique to offer visually and strategically, and while it can be fairly linear in it's pathing to objectives, it also rewards the player that decides to explore, and solve the various puzzles hidden throughout the levels. As for the combat, I'd liken it to that of Bloodborne, oddly enough. You will come to areas where there are several enemies, all of which are stronger than you, and your only advantage over them is their specific attack pattern that you need to learn and counter. You will die. A lot. But as you progress, you will unlock new abilities and hone your reflexes, to the point where things that seemed impossible will be laughable. And holy ♥♥♥♥, is it ever satisfying when you finally clear an area you've been working on for the better part of an hour.

In conclusion, if you like beautiful, meticulously designed worlds with a diverse array of enemies and plenty of hidden passages to explore, you'll love Hyper Light Drifter. Personally, it was worth every penny.

reviewText:
I don't really write reviews often.. blah blah, you all know the rest.

I'm going to be quick and honest with this, the game is nowhere near being for everyone. If you're into actually having to think before each fight and adapt during them, then just go and buy the damn game already, you'll most likely enjoy it. Also, don't expect to buy the game and immerse yourself into some extraordinarily deep story, since you'll probably understand almost nothing on your first playthrough.

reviewText:
Excellent, amazing, fantastic, perfect game.

Visually, it's one of the most beautiful and rich games I've ever played. They really put so much love into every pixel. The music and sound effects are awesome, no surprise coming partly from Disasterpeace. The combat can be super hard, but you can feel yourself learn and adapt to enemies as you play, and when you finally do beat a tough section it's so fulfilling. The HUD and menu interfaces are super minimal and straightforward and fit perfectly into the environment.

There is symbolism and beauty everywhere in the game, and it really makes the universe come to life. It's thought provoking and extremely fun.

reviewText:
I really like the game : the atmosphere is quite unique,
a lot of design are lovable and I found myself wanting to spare enemies until they ask for it,
and there's a lot of love behind this game overall.

My two main concern with it is that you cannot use the d-pad to play and you're forced to use the analog stick : I mind because the dash require precise direction and stupidly falling off cliffs could have been avoided (this among other things).

And two the framerate is inconstant : again, the dash require precise tempo to be chained and it kind of ruin the experience when you're in the middle of tight battles (don't blame my pc, it runs modern-ish games on high, I don't think I'm at fault here)

You play as an ex Interstellar 5555 member who wanted to join Attack on Titan only to realise Titans are already dead. Being the pinnacle of anime character, you have the ability  that every nekketsu protagonist dream to have : you cough blood.

For one reason or another, you're going from place to place, doing genocide and regicide all while having acid trip and heart attacks.

That's pretty much my understanding at least. HLD doesn't talk much to you, or just doesn't at all. Upgrades are immensely useful if you want to have a better experience, so think thrice about what upgrade you chose first : I heavily recommend that you get the attack that send back projectile, it help me a lot (but I'm not your mother you do what you want)

All in all it's hard, but in a cheap way. Life bar could be restored at each death, it's not like it add challenge, it's just tedious.

but it's really enjoyable despite that. If you're getting crush by bosses : take a breath, observe them. deal with minions first and chain pistol + sword attack as much as possible. Also you can go in whichever direction you want, so if you're stuck with one boss, try another one, you might get useful weapons along to way to facilitate other encounters too.

The game is fairly lenghty, expect 5 to 7 hours before finishing it. Aiming for 100% or doing the new game+ will take a lot more time as there's a lot to explore, even though sometime I just don't know how.

I highly recomment this game, do not give up on it because the beginning is tedious : it's not that hard.

reviewText:
I just defeated the second boss (went East first, North second) and I must say I am very impressed with this game!  I've been playing with a steam controller and it has been a wonderful experience. I've not played a top-down game this challenging for a very long time!

I'm loving this game so much! I simply cannot believe how much  great it is to dash into a group of enemies and blast them with a gun then use the sword to sweep up the rest. I haven't felt this kind of acomplishment with a game since Dark Souls.

If you don't enjoy dying in games, or exploring without really knowing where to go, you will probably get frustrated at some point. There is a map with points showing you where you need to go, but it is not as exact as a metroid game.
This game relies on you to learn from your mistakes and get the timing down. I've probably died well over 100 times already but I don't mind at all! Its been fun trying to master this game!

Also, I feel I should mention it only runs at 30 fps. But it is worth a try atleast! I don't mind the 30 fps and the Dev has mentioned why it is locked at 30, but I know a couple people have been complaining about headaches. I've never gotten headaches from any game except when I play Stereoscopic 3d for too long.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter: A Modern Masterpiece

Hyper Light Drifter has easily taken the place of my all-time favorite game. The game is a masterpiece in all aspects, combining challenging combat reminiscent of Dark Souls with a unique style all it's own. The art style of this game escapes what can be described in words alone, a stylistic blend of otherworldly sci-fy and post-apocalyptic adventure, the game takes pixel art to an entirely new realm of graphic excellence. The beautifully crafted scenery and enemies are a delight to the eye, with the pixel graphics providing just enough fine detail to provide rich, engaging visuals while still allowing the player to apply their own imagination to the scene. The same can be said for the awe-inspiring story, told through vague images and leaving much to speculation. The story is exciting and engaging, but at the same time seemingly absent. The only clues to what you must do are the occasional vague hints told through images, leaving the player to their own devices. This seemingly utter lack of direction allows the player to make their own story, rather than having it spoon fed to them as so many modern games do. The beauty of this game is how it forces you to make your own choices and theories, not knowing if they are even remotely correct. This amount of freedom is liberating- nothing is given easily to the player, they must earn it through skill and perserverence. That level of satisfaction gained from overcoming an obstacle that this game provides in ample supply is essential to connecting and engaging with the player, and is missing from far too many games. The combat is tough but fair, constantly keeping the player on their toes. Combat is fast paced, yet crisp and responsive, with varied and challenging enemies. The soundtrack is a wonder of audio engineering, with scores ranging from light, enchanting melodies to dark, gritty anthems that set the player on edge. The music completes a rich, ambient overall style with the artwork, a beautiful blend that engrosses and envelops the player.

TL:DR
This is a masterpiece of modern game design and it would be a disservice to both yourself and society as a whole to not buy it.
Overall rating: 10/10; Pinnacle of modern game design.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent game. 9/10. Would recommend. Read below for further details.

PROS
- Atmosphere: From the very beginning you are sucked into this world. The music and art design blend together wonderfully creating a drive to explore your surroundings.

- Combat: Battles require precision over mashing. The controls felt tight and once you understand what enemies are capable of battles become a dance. You'll battle melee and ranged foes, sometimes at once. Dispaching a room of enemies without taking damage is very satisfying.

- Level design: There are four distinct areas to explore in HLD. There is a minimap but I rarely had to use it. The levels have enough branching paths but not too many that you get lost often. There are NUMEROUS hidden nooks and crannies to find. There are some environmental tells but the visuals are so cohesive that the player really has to look and explore to find extra goodies. This is where the dash movement mechanic really shines as you'll constantly find yourself dsahing across gaps to small ledges in search of secrets. The developers really did setup the environment to syngergize with the core movement mechanic of dashing.

- Boss Battles: While many people feel the battles are too hard, I though the difficulty was well tuned. All of the bosses have a unique visual design and require different strategies to beat. There was never a boss I had to replay more than seven times (including the final boss). You revive right outside the boss room and a recent patch sped up the player death animation so restarting was not frustratingand after every death. The battles are tense and require constant focus but that makes victory that much more satisfying. I was able to beat the entire game without buying any healing upgrades so with healing fully upgraded I feel many players can complete the game if they learn the patterns and stay determined.

CONS
- Upgrade System: Melee attacks, movement abilities, and the secondary gun can be upgraded along with a few other things. In keeping with zero dialogue or explanatory text the upgrades merely show a quick clip of what they are. This does leave some ambiguity in what new abilities do. Also, as all upgrades can be purchased from the beginning, choosing an upgrade is simply guesswork. All of the abilities are useful (to an extent) but the currency to purchase them has to be found through exploration so new upgrades can only be purchased so quickly. Buy one you won't need for some time and you're out currency and the gameplay doesnt change. I did a decent amount of additional exploration and did not find enough currency to upgrade everything. Not a problem to me personally but then I was happy with what I chose to upgrade.

- Autosave System: I understand why the game has auto-save. It allows the devs to provide difficult sections of the game. The game saves so often I don't think I was never bothered but life does happen so be aware you can't stop playing whenever you want (unless you don't mind replaying a section).

- Length: I was only lost once that I can recall and I didn't waste much time dashing around (for a certain achievement) and I beat the game in six hours. I was hoping for an 8-10 hour experience. There is a new game plus and I didn't get all the collectables but for what I'm calling the main game, it was a tad short.

Overall Impression
- Hyper Light Drifter was worth the 18 USD (sale price). Some of the best boss fights I've played. Great combat. The story presentation being purely visual challenged me to think about the world and what the Drifter's purpose was. Is the game difficult? At times, but you are given all the tools to overcome. Like many of the best indie games, Hyper Light Drifter provides a unique and focused experience you will not get anywhere else.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a game I'd been excited for for the past couple years now and I'm happy to say it does not disappoint. The visuals are some of the most beautiful I've seen in the pixel art genre, and there are various astonishing sights to see, some of which I would stop to study for a couple minutes. The soundtrack is great too, Disasterpeace does some of the most unique chiptune music I've ever heard.

Before playing I was a little worried since a lot of people have been saying the game is too hard and frustrating to be fun, but after playing it through I wholeheartedly disagree. The bosses are very hard, that I wont deny anyone, but I found all of them really engaging and never frustrating, even though I died repeatedly on a few of them. Combat in this game is more about being aware of your surroundings and timing your actions than simply mashing buttons. I'm not against the idea of an easier difficulty setting for people who don't play this type of game often, but the experience of finally getting it down and sticking it to a boss is really satisfying. Some of the game's appeal would be lost without it.

I finished the game in about 8 or 9 hours of play time, though I feel like there were a lot of secrets I missed, and there is a new game + mode as well so replay value seems good. Definitely will be playing this more in the future.

reviewText:
THIS GAME DOESNT RUN AT 144FPS, ITS NOT VR COMPATABLE; CANT RUN RESHADE/ENB, ITS TOO HRAD AND THE MUSIC DOESNT EVEN HAVE ANY DROPS OR BANGERS

WORST GAM EVR DO NOT BUY UNTIL DEVS SORT THIS TRAVERSTY -666/10

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

April fools, this game is absolutely incredible.

The visuals have so much obvious love and care poured into them.  Although the game does have some occasional issues with visual clarity and clutter, it's more than made up for by the sheer amount of excellent visual storytelling, alongside animation that is both attractive and integral to the game's Dark Souls-seque combat system.  Gorgeous use of shape and colour, too.

The audio is an absolute treat.  The game's hazy, SNES-influenced soundscape mixes perfectly with Rich Vreeland's predictably wonderful musical score, that sounds not unlike what would happen if Tangerine Dream and Boards Of Canada did the sweetest damn collab ever.  Moreover, both the sound and music tie in to other aspects of the game on a  deep level.  Sound is often used to highlight enemy attacks and pinpoint hidden secrets, and the music swells and modulates in such a way as to offer punctuation and drama to the visual storytelling on offer.  It really is a treat.

The gameplay is tight and responsive but challenging, and punishes sloppy play.  Easy to pick up, tough to beat, satisfying to master.  This game wears its Legend Of Zelda and Dark Souls influences on its sleeve, and is all the better for it.  Bosses can occasionally feel cheap, but this is less down to overall unfairness as it is to complex attack patterns and strategies.  You will try, try and try again, slowly learning how best to chink away at its armour, and when you eventually defeat it, the sense of accomplishment is wonderful.

This game is not for everybody.  I imagine some people will bounce off its offputting initial difficulty curve and that the bosses will cause many a smashed joypad and ragequit.  However, for those willing to be truly challenged in exchange for some of the best audiovisual storytelling and exploration in videogames, then you can't get much better than this.  I've waited since the Kickstarter back in 2013 and I am in no way disappointed.

It's an absolute masterpiece.

reviewText:
Have been looking forward to this quite some time, unfortunately it didn't blow my mind like I hoped it would. Gorgeous and fun little game though.

Hoped this to be much larger and more complex. Like those early Nintendo action adventures with lots of different weapons and spells and whatnot. Devs seem to have aimed for some focused retro clone (which they definitely delivered on).

If you are frustrated by the game's difficulty, you might try some upgrading first. After that the difficulty is just about right.

+World. Swords, blasters, neon lit ruins. Sweet science/fantasy juice with some nice 70s flavour.
+Pacing. Moments of calm bliss sliced by lightspeed conflict, everything spiced with some satisfying hunt for secrets.
-Protagonist. Most NPCs look way cooler than me.
-Size. Like fine cuisine there just isn't enough to fill an honest stomach.

reviewText:
Consider this an early impression rather than a full review of the game but I just wanted to share my opinions thus far.
First off, HLD is absolutely gorgeous! It might be one of the best looking (2D) games I've seen in a very long time. The audio and music are also on point and fit the game very well.
The combat is fast, fluid, fun and pretty hard but more on that later. I'd say the combat is a bit like Devil May Cry but in 2D.
HLD isn't holding your hand either. It drops you straight into the action with basically no explaination whatsoever. This wouldn't be too bad if it weren't for the fact that they refuse to explain anything! I for example went to the Northern area first and there were some collectibles there, if I collect one of them a screen would appear with a square and one corner of the square would light up without any context. Maybe I haven't played far enough for it to make sense but as of now it's all a bit too criptic for my taste.
Another problem I encountered are the PC controls. The game recommends a controller and I can see why! The mouse and keyboard controls aren't bad per se but in combat the cursor can become your worst enemy making combat way harder than it actually is. The problem is that both attacking and (more importantly) dodging go in the direction the cursor is facing. So say you're moving to the left but and you need to dodge an incoming attack but your cursor is on the right side of the screen you will dodge to the right even though you were moving to the left. It's infuriating and I hope there will be an update that prioritizes the direction you're going to the cursor.

Yet even with these complaints I recommend Hyper Light Drifter just make sure you get yourself a controller and that you can handle the vagueness from time to time (although that might disappear later in the game). The combat still is a lot of fun and the atmosphere is just superb!

reviewText:
I'll try to say things which haven't been said (that this is a very difficult Souls-like; well, you die a lot more but death isn't nearly as punishing.  There are checkpoints everywhere.  But there's the same emphasis on deadly fights and big, connected maps.) and which aren't apparent from the trailer (both the art and sound design are gorgeous).

1: Holy ♥♥♥♥, the map design.  There are a bajillion nooks and crannies and hidden paths.  Exploration is _very_ much rewarded.  And it's not like some games where it's a matter of pressing the A button or the E key on every single wall.  There are a lot of nice patterns as for figuring out where the hidden panels are, and the game does a nice job of training you to see them.

2: The balance is _perfect_.  You don't have any stats which increase over the course of the game (closest thing to getting more health is getting more capacity for healing potions).  Yet you definitely feel like you're getting stronger as you progress through an area.  The upgrades are great, but they can pretty much only be used to exploit a weakness once you've figured out an enemy's pattern.  This means that even though the game branches out very early on, you don't have to worry about being too OP and tearing through the area you choose last, or getting crushed in the area you choose first.  In any case, enemies are introduced gradually, so you get trained in how to fight them before you see too many of them.  Exception being those charging plant monsters.  ♥♥♥♥ them D:

3: Try to buy the dash chaining upgrade as soon as possible.  It's so hard to get good at but it's soooo much fun.

reviewText:
Short review: If I hadn't kickstarted this game, I would have refunded it.

Long review:
Don't get me wrong, there's a lot to love when you at first start playing this game, gorgeous graphics, beautiful music, an intriguing world, interesting enemy design,...

The experience is however ruined by a game that has only one difficulty setting, and that one setting is onerously unfair. This game's idea of difficulty is throwing wave after wave of enemies at you at once, making it essentially more of bullet hell game than anything else. Upgrades exist, but will barely improve your survival chances.
The main character is slow, unresponsive (30 fps ahoy) and has a far to large hitbox, making enemies with projectiles a hassle to deal with.

The game leaves you completely free to choose the order in which you tackle the different area's and their respective bosses, but these regions are definitely not balanced, and 1 of the bosses is a lot harder than all of the others.

To top it off, the chain dashing mechanic required by the game to obtain currency for upgrades and key for completing the game, essentially locks these items behind a deeply frustrating rythm mechanic for which there's barely any proper cue which is the proper rythm unless you crank the sfx volume way up, what's even worse is that the animations don't sync with this rythm.

The developers and fans of the game cite a Dark Souls inspiration or even a Zelda one, and try to justify the difficulty of this game in doing so. It seems to me they've clearly never played those games. While Dark Souls may be hard, it's definitely not unfair, this game is. Although the difficulty in Zelda ramps up throughout the game, it never really becomes overly hard, and genereously awards players with more and more equipment and health to take on tougher enemies, don't expect such generosity here however...

All in all, this could have been a great game, but it has been ruined by the developer's choice that only those with the perseverance and the time to suffer through their random mechanics get to enjoy the game. After dying countless times on yet another impossible path, I simply gave up.

reviewText:
I have just finished the game for the first time. I have not collected all the secrets or even started NG+.

I will edit this review if I find more to gain from this game.

As of right now I cannot say that this game is worth the $18 asking price. With the game of just playthrough, no bactracking for secrets, you'll see about a 3-4 hour game time. This doesn't involved the time out of game where you'll try to puzzle what the story actually meant or why your character was meant to do anything at all as the end of the game makes the journey feel almost pointless.

Confusing characters, and limited gameplay options make for an obtuse experience with a great art and music direction. I was so sad to feel let down by this game. After following this game's development I can honestly say that it does not offer what I thought it would.

In the long run I think there will be more to gain after beating NG+ and collecting all the secrets but for now I cannot recommend this game to someone who is not secret gatherer or someone who doesn't enjoy getting their ♥♥♥ handed to them for multiple rounds with a difficult boss.

Edit:
I want to add onto this that the game back when I first looked at the kickstarter was a lot more grand in scope and scale. It feels like the game was watered down from that, and it took the part of Zelda games I like the least in regards to secret finding. This is to say, hopefully you notice that this part of the map is slightly different from the rest!"

Edit 2:
I promised I'd come back and talk about the game more after I got the secrets. After getting all the monoliths and figuring out the language of the world and putting together the story of what is going on I can tell you now that this game assuredly is not worth your time if you want a story that is interesting and complex while stil being accessible.

The devs should be ashamed of putitng such a complex story behind strange writing and hard to access areas. They should have taken a leaf out of dark souls' book and realized how to hide a story while still having it be accessible to those who look. Having to translate a bunch of hidden monoliths from a language that was luckily guessed was a nightmare
date:
I can now promise you that this game is not worth your time for the reasons previously stated and also because of a lack luster story hidden behind a wildly trivial language barrier.

TL:DR

Fun gameplay
hoursPlayed: and not worth $18. If you're gaming on a budget skip this one."

reviewText:
It's a game with a pointlessly obtuse story that quickly becomes frustrating due to a floaty, imprecise control scheme (at least on mouse and keyboard) and an awful camera system. I wanted to like it, but it quickly just turned into a slog. Can't recommend, though maybe it's better with a controller.

To go into more depth:

There's something to be said for games that don't spell it all out for you. Dark Souls, for example, gives you a lot of lore and interesting story, if you care to dig it out. Hyper Light Drifter, on the other hand, feels a lot like someone saw that and decided to ape it in a clumsy attempt at being mysterious and deep, which unfortunately just makes it vague and annoying. All I've gotten out of the story so far is that it's so obtuse that I don't really care about it. I have no desire to puzzle out what the game is trying to tell me, and that's a shame because it's an otherwise interesting world.

My other complaint is fairly large, though it's mostly on me. I'm using a mouse and keyboard even though the game hints heavily that you should use a controller, mostly because I don't have one I can use. A game like this needs tight controls and it just doesn't have it if you use a mouse and keyboard. Everything is extremely imprecise and floaty. Gun shots veer off from where you aim to the point that you can't be sure how to aim at things, despite how basic it seems. Dashes hurl you off in slightly wrong directions, making mobility during combat a clumsy, frustrating affair. I never once felt like I was getting better, or learning the system. Most fights just felt like a crapshoot instead of an opportunity to get better at the mechanics.

Another complaint is the camera. It doesn't always follow you. Usually it's in something of a fixed position to display a single screen" (if you remember Metroid
recommended: and only shifts when you reach the edge and go into another "screen". There are numerous times where this is just awful
hoursPlayed: especially in areas where combat occurs. If the controls weren't bad enough
voteText: imagine having to blindly dash off-screen because enemies back-flipped out of the screen you're currently in and are now shooting you from somewhere you can't see.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: it wouldn't be a terrible purchase on sale. Just don't expect a lot of depth to the story or the gameplay."
