reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a game built on the shoulders of giants. It wears its inspirations (Legend of Zelda; Dark Souls) on its sleeve and that's not always a bad thing. I'm going to analyse the core design of the game and provide my own opinion on how to fix them bit by bit.

The obvious and most noticeable benefit the game has is its beautiful pixel art so I'm just going to get that out of the way and say what everybody else has already said: It looks beautiful. No denying that. The most obvious and noticeable drawback is the crippling framerate, which was, as far as I can tell, a conscious decision -- not a limitation of Game Maker: Studio.

PROBLEM: The level design is just not very good. The problem is the clutter and the poor conveyance in regards to fake walls and passageways. It was extremely easy for me to get lost. Having to backtrack over the same area time and again is not an acceptable waste of my time. I rapidly got sick of sniffing walls for secret doors and the genius decision to hide progression-crucial paths behind such gimmicks is incomprehensible. A camera pan that only occurs if the player nonsensically stares into an abyss which does not, in any way, prompt the player to investigate the area; a hidden glitch-like clipping through a few pixel trees; some weird soulless floating object which you have to shoot which is completely out of range of sight until the player approaches the edge of a map, and stands still for a few seconds so the camera interpolation can catch up; these are not secrets and it does not contribute to subtle exploration and world-building. This is wall-sniffing. I was initially unsure on whether the designer intended to do this but it occurs so frequently that I must accept that it was a thing they were going for. Well, as far as I'm concerned, it failed.

SOLUTION: As a designer, you must understand that your level must always subtly funnel the player toward their goal. Remove the weird transitions hidden behind blocks of trees entirely or remove trees that obstruct vision. Reduce the distance between platforms to ensure players can realistically view hidden areas, or create assets which visually guide the player to approach said gaps more often. As it stands, it takes a gigantic leap of logic to even approach the gaps at the start before you even know you should, and after that, the player will be doing that systematically, which removes the joy of exploring and turns it into a meticulous chore.

Combat is very fast paced while also retaining an acceptable degree of strategy and timing. Utilizing a hidden limiter mechanic, the creator made it so that after the regular three-hit combo, there is a punishing delay until the player may attack again.

PROBLEM: Unfortunately, the player can never really upgrade this at any point, as far as I can tell. The addition of a swift dash helps to string combos together and the later addition of an ability that damages enemies while dashing is very useful to this end as well. This may sound good on paper, but the problem arises when attacking enemies with the sword is so suboptimal that you might as well not have the ability to attack at all.

SOLUTION: I realize the amount of work it would be to properly balance new types of weapons and to draw and animate sprites. I feel it would have been the best choice to implement a few other melee weapons which have contrasting benefits and drawbacks as opposed to so many different guns. I'd also like to point out that allowing the player to improve the number of attacks per combo would have gone a long way into making melee combat slightly more bearable and less frustrating.

PROBLEM: You have access to many types of guns which sounds interesting at first. The problem is two-pronged: First, guns are not properly balanced; each pellet from the Shotgun is strong enough that, given proximity, it completely and absolutely deletes any need to use any other gun, ever. Secondly, the only way to regain ammunition is to attack enemies or objects. If you come across a puzzle or a situation where you need bullets and don't have a ready source of regaining, you're going to be forced to backtrack, which is not acceptable.

SOLUTION: Firstly, I don't feel the game really gained anything from having so many gun types and I feel the creator just mostly had trouble to think of rewards to give the player after each boss fight. It's far easier to draw, animate and implement different gun sprites than to implement more meaningful melee weapons, so I guess I can understand. In what concerns the ammunition, adding an ammo regaining mechanic based on time on top of the existing one, whereby it will replenish with time and only outside of combat, could go a long way.

PROBLEM: Healing isn't properly thought out. Being stuck in the same string of challenges with 1 peg of health and no healing kits is ridiculously punishing. This happened to me on more than one occasion. Healing kits can be found throughout the levels but I found myself either starved for kits at the time I needed them most, or being full and having to leave kits behind. It was a smart decision to automatically use a healing kit should the belt be full, but the point is less of an organic resource just like Estus Flasks from Dark Souls, but instead an external benefit that the player has no real agency over -- either use them at 1 health or don't use them at all; it is devoid of real strategy.

SOLUTION: Replenishing the player's health after dying and granting them a single healing item should they have none is a solution that would not contradict the game's design and would help to facilitate the tackling of challenges repeatedly without feeling like an unfair meat-grinder. I get the feeling the designer did not want to replenish the kits at a checkpoint because they didn't want the mechanic to be seen as a straight rip-off from the Souls series and I would bet it was that way sometime during development -- I get this feeling because warp points heal the player anyway, as well as replenish their ammo, but never kits. If it got changed sometime later, the change was unjustifiable partially because the challenges were not balanced around the idea that a player may be completely out of healing at any given point. If it was never that way from the get go, then it's just a bad decision altogether. The Estus Flasks are a very elegant system; if a formula works, there is absolutely no reason to change it, especially if it becomes such a marked step below what it was initially. There is no shame in reappropriating a good idea.

PROBLEM: There is no story. By that, I don't mean that there is absolutely no plot, but the ambiguity and esoteric meaning of everything that occurs both at the start as well as the end was a very poor choice. Humans use words to communicate because it's incredibly difficult to convey complex emotions and ideas without verbal communication. It's easy to sign and emote simple notions, such as simple geometric shapes and basic instinctive desires like hunger or cold. However, once it begins involving themes that imply mysticism, relating to symbols becomes harder and harder.

SOLUTION: For this reason, to retain the wordless theme, going for a simpler, more earthly and relatable plot would do wonders to make the player feel engaged and motivated to partake. I don't care about anything that's happening because I don't understand what's happening at all, and the absense of any compelling side character doesn't help, either. The big themes may remain, but I feel presenting them as secrets and hidden lore would have been the better choice instead of frontloading them.

Unfortunately, I still have many gripes which I would love to address but I'm sure I'm reaching the character limit. For now, I'm going to say: Wait for these problems to be addressed.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a game that has been stymied by numerous delays in its development process stemming from issues within the studio creating it and the team head's heart problems. The title was slated to include much, much more than actually managed to make it into the game, and it appears as though there will be no attempt to integrate these missing, promised, funded features.

I feel very fortunate as to only have paid $15 for this title, as I'd recommend it for purchase only below the ten dollar mark. While the game initially invoked memories and feelings I'd only be able to draw from older adventure games such as The Legend of Zelda: Oracle of Ages that I had played long ago, these feelings of nostalgia quickly wore thin as I progressed past the first boss for me in the eastern section. The game is highly opaque in its setting and story, which I would appreciate if there existed much of a real setting beneath its extremely polished artsytle, environments, and laudable musical score.

Gameplay suffers from the occasional bug of any variety, few of which had much if any impact on what I've played. The combat system enables players to really put themselves into engaging and entertaining situations that may occasionally seriously challenge them. It's unfortunate that the limited number of upgrades, purchasable only with often hidden currency fragments stashed around in both enemies and recessed corners, are rather difficult to fully explore and access. It may well take people multiple playthroughs of the title to try everything out.

While environments are novel, I feel as though the game often falls flat as it draws the player into its world, beckoning one in with all of the often inaccessable platforms off to the side and number of fragments in each quadrant. So many of these hidden areas are dependent upon finding nearly pixel-sized gaps in walls or barriers, requiring incessant terrain-hugging to find any of these spaces without resorting to third party information.

I do not plan on finishing this title, as I have yet to recieve the game I backed. Too much promised is completely absent to look upon the title favorably. I will unfortunately remember Hyper Light Drifter as an ultimately lackluster, half-baked Kickstarter game, reasons behind delays and missing content notwithstanding.

reviewText:
Alright. Well, let's get this thing started.

Hyper Light Drifter is something everyone should experience in their lives.
You start the game with little direction and a beautiful world. Each path you choose comes with it's own trials and rewards, and at the start you probably won't know where to go. So trust your gut. I went east, because it was the closet place to the house that I assume you stay at. In the beginning you meet a man in red and pink. He's the closest thing to a guide you have in this world. Finding him, he'll mark important locations on your map, if you haven't been to them already.

It's not an easy road but it's a rewarding one. The challanges the game gives you are fair, it's just up to you how you handle them. I never found a room I couldn't handle, even if it took more than one try. Pick your abilities carefully and be positive about what guns you are using. Buy the bomb early, it helps.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TLDR

Good -
Art Style - Visuals are excellent
Unique Setting - Alien World
Combat - Could be Improved but Satisfiying

Ac/Dc -
Dialouge - There isn't any...so no Planescape Torment here you can take it or leave it
Sound - Effective Enough
Difficulty - Somewhat Tough - Pattern Learning Required to Beat Bosses
Instructions - Minimual

Bad -
Exploration is really just a Pixel Hunt for the same two treasures screen after screen
Repetitive and overlong at certain points
Lack of a concise story

My Verdict?

Very.....Okay. Reminds me of Axiom Verge and Zelda.

Which is good in certain aspects such as excellent retro style art (not just pixel graphics) and it's adherence to theme throughout the expierence. The visuals are really a shining point for this game.

However like Axiom Verge this title suffers from some retro game problems that have no place in modern games.

I found the exploration portion of the game (it's a substantial part...like most of it) grew tedious as you pixel hunt each area trying to find extra loot hidden all over the level. The loot itself seems to be either health refills or coinage...and that's it. I mean if I'm searching for something and I stumble upon a seceret it would be nice to have some mystery as to what I was going to find there but some of you may enjoy getting the same christmas presents year after year.

The combat style is sort of a mish-mash of button mashing and screen dashing that comes off okay. It could defintely be smoother but if you are technically precise and know what you are doing you will be successful. That's easier said than done as mob rushes are common and can be overwhelming.  The fact that you just start over at the begining of the screen is an old and tired mechnic that winds up having the effect of not caring one bit if I roll off a cliff or get KO'ed right before I kill the last bad man on screen.

If your looking to scratch your Zelda itch and enjoy the aesthics of video games this a pretty solid title. I would say it needs some serious revamping to elevate itself up to Titan Souls or Shovel Knight territory.

6/10 --- Solid Fun mixed with some tedious searching sets this as a slightly above average title in my book. While the price might be a bit too high for the gameplay itself the unique setting and visuals makes up for a bit.

reviewText:
i honeslty don't know what to say about Hyper Light Drifter anymore, i have changed my review about five times to far. this game is a masterpeice of art style of atmoshpere, hands down Hyper Light Drifter has the best atmosphere of any 2D game i've ever played. the story is really instresting too, it is hard to get what is going on at first but the story is still really intriguing. you play as this drifter guy who is trying to find a cure for a illness or something on this old torn down planet. the story is really told more through the atmosphere, people encased in crystal tells a far better story then a 1 hour cut scene.

the combat is really cool too, a hack and slash dance. dodging with your dash move and then attacking, it is like a waltz of brawling. yet some of the games flaws get in the way of this beautiful waltz. the dash and attack dance doesn't really play out well when you are being spammed by 10 plus enemies at once. this is where another part of the game comes in, Hyper Light Drifter is a hard game. don't exspect to walk through a area maybe kicking the bucket once or twice, you will see your drifter guy die 20, 30 times. the worst thing about is that this diffucultly comes from poor design chocies rather then skillful placement. things like no manual saves, the game saves like Bioshock Infinite, at the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ times. plus the really faded cursor on PC doesn't help you play any better. it is hard to find even outside of combat, and once you are in combat it becomes a guessing game of where you might attack. the the AI is also needs a lot of work, enemies walking into walls and even bosses tweek'n out. yet once you play the game you will see the flaws in design far more clearly, they are small but still there.

the game's art style is just hands down the best in any game you will ever see, it is something you cannot describe in words. Hyper Light Drifter is how a pixel game should look like, it is a peice of art that should be in museums. the music is fantasic too, the syth work is reminiscent of a  sci fi 80-esc world. then the paino comes in with grand Debussy runs that shimmer like fine crystal, it is like the art style, just perfect.

Pros
- PERFECT art style
- Amazing music
- Cool story
- Instresting cobat

Cons
- Janky AI
- No manual saves
- Very Hard (this might be a con for you, depends)
- PC cursor is almost invisable

if Hyper Light Drifter is tweeked just a bit, it will win game of the year like 20 times.

reviewText:
Decent Zelda-lite.

Pros:
- nice level design, although a bit too samey for the amount of backtracking required
- exploration not exposition
- bosses are hard but (mostly) fair
- overall combat is good

Cons:
- 30 fps refresh looks stylish but makes for annoyingly sticky" controls; minimal cancelling
- no attack interrupt on enemies means constantly getting sucker-punched mid-combo
- Music runs the emotional gamut from bland to insipid
- It's ugly as all get-out
- Putting a cyan/magenta player character on a magenta/cyan background and then shaking it about all over the place is  an offence in most forward-thinking jurisdictions."

reviewText:
This game, is nice.
This game, is a bit hard.
There are too many bugs for a simple game like this one.
The gameplay stays quite the same, everywhere.

The pixel-art-graphic is very beautiful.

The game does not get harder over time, the first boss I fought was the hardest one. (north)
The story is ... simple.
The items are hard to find, most of them.  Bossfights are easier than finding all Items by yourself.
This game is not really worth 20€.
The framerate is locked at 30, AT 30 !!! WTF, WHY? (You can´t change that btw. )

This game is probably a 5/10.

reviewText:
For more reviews click here[thegoodbadgaming.com]

TL;DR: Unless on sale I can't honestly recommend Hyper Light Drifter which makes me very sad

I was extremely excited about Hyper Light Drifter. Ever since watching the awe inspiring Kickstarter trailer back in 2013 madly throwing money at the screen, pre-ordering the game plus its soundtrack. Now having finished the game in a little over 6 hours I have very mixed feelings about the game.

The game is at its best when it focuses on gameplay. Combat and level designs are extremely tight and well-crafted with enough nooks and crannies that feature hidden collectibles such as gear bits or modules that are necessary for progress and unlocking the final boss fight. Outside of that there are also collectible outfits and new ranged weapons ranging the starting pistol to a rail gun. Traversing the world and fighting enemies is a lot of fun.

Levels look a bit like those in Super Giant’s Bastion, broken up land of floating islands that you dash between if the distance is not too great. There are cleverly hidden invisible platforms that your little hovering robot companion can make you aware of by having a question mark appear above it. The way Hyper Light Drifter structures its progress is similar to that of Dark Souls (specifically) since you travel towards four different lands to get to a collection of four modules (instead of the lord souls, since collecting four in each area unlocks the final boss fight) then you beat an area boss that unlocks a way to the monolith which lets you progress further in other areas or unlock secrets within the same area letting you collect more upgrade points or gear.

Combat has an enticing rhythm to it, despite the dismal framerate. Each enemy has its own attack pattern with obviously telegraphed attacks that you learn very quickly and counter with you own set of skills. The most important skill is the very basic dashing ability, which lets you chain three dashes together making the player able to evade any attack thrown their way. To inflict damage upon the enemies there is the basic sword for close combat and pistol for ranged combat. While the sword stays pretty much the same throughout the game, the slots for ranged weapons receive several variations over the course of the playthrough. Hyper Light Drifter does a great job having all weapons staying relevant throughout, it all depends on the player and how they want to approach each encounter. For me it was switching between rail gun and shotgun depending on the current enemy line-up or boss’ pattern.

When the game tries to tell its story it sharply conflicts with the polish and meticulous design of the gameplay. The story it tries to tell is intriguing at first but the problem is it starts falling apart due to its mishandled vagueness. Hyper Light Drifter again tries to mimic the Souls games, but it doesn’t know how to. It tries to tell a story of a world that while some bits are implied strongly enough that I can put together a basic line what possibly happened, but we do not know our own place within this world, if the journey actually happened, what or who our “Vergil” really is. There are moments where the game attempts to convey information through a short slide-show, which usually tells you short narrative about characters you’ve met or who the area boss is, but there is very little told in relation to your place or role within the world so little that by the end of the game what drove me to finish it was the gameplay and music rather than story.

Hyper Light Drifter’s aesthetic is striking and very well realized but it is being held back by its unreasonably low frame-rate. The developer Heart Machine made the strange choice and locked the game at 30FPS, which feels sluggish and slow for what is fast paced, close combat focused action adventure. On the other hand the pixel art is crisp and unique with matching colour scheme that is heavy on purple and shades of blue\green. The enemies’ visual designs are great with animations very distinct that you can clearly predict the enemy’s attack and determine a course of action. Overall outside of the obviously poor technical choice the game is a sight to behold with some of the game vistas being truly breath taking.

The sound design is a mixed bag, some of the sounds got on my nerves during larger encounters while the ambience and the music are absolutely stunning. Disasterpeace’s soundtrack is amazing giving the game personality that the story sadly couldn’t. Helping to set the mood and telling story of the area. The soundtrack is mostly relying on synths and other electronica specific devices to create very sci-fi sounding tracks, that wouldn’t be lost in the worlds of Shadowrun or Blade Runner. If I have to be brutally honest, soundtrack is easily the part of the game I have enjoyed the most.

While the gameplay is great when it comes down to it as a whole the package is very underwhelming and leaves a lot to be desired from narrative and technical standpoints.

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter is a phenomenally pretty action game.  The gorgeous artwork combines with the moody soundtrack to evoke senses ranging from awe-inspiring wonder to suffocating menace.  Hyper Light Drifter displays a masterful sense of atmosphere that few games match, which in addition to the quick and brutal combat, hightens the excitement of fighting your way through desecrated homelands and ancient battlegrounds.  Your repetoire of tools for dealing with the waves of varied enemies in a given encounter is relatively simple; you have your basic three-hit combo of sword atttacks which charge ammunition for your ranged firearms , a purchaseable grenade, and your dash.  Waves of melee enemies will attempt to flush you from cover to give ranged attackers a shot at you, forcing you to dodge back into another group of deadly foes.  You need to quickly identify who, what, and when to attack.  If you make a mistake, you'll likely be punished, and punished severely.  As you die and retry, you'll go from reacting to impending threats to conducting the cadence of battle.  Combat is less about flashy button combinations and manual dexterity than quick wits, careful positioning, target prioritization, and stricking swiftly when you identify the opportunity.  The combat in Hyper Light Drifter is a dangerous and exciting joy.
However, murdering your way through the beautiful environments alternates between being the only enjoyable way to interact with the world and being the ONLY way to interact with the world.  Exploration involves fighting the game's nigh-useless map in order to reach the next combat encounter until you come face to face with an area's boss on the surface.  Delve any deeper, and finding the hidden secrets in the game involves obsessively hugging walls and edges to the point of tedium in the hopes of locating a hidden path or invisible walkway.  These secrets can lead to extra health or currency, indecipherable glyphs, a new color scheme for your character, and, if you're lucky, an exciting new encounter to test your combat skills in.  Never do you find any narrative payoff.
Which is both astoundingly dumbfounding and disappointing.  For all the care gone into crafting the world, the game has, literally, NO plot.  The events of the opening cinematic, the events you play through in game, and the events revealed once you vanquish the final combat challenge are never connected or given reference in-game.  Whatever transpires between starting the game and viewing its credits is entirely dependant on your interpretation of how to connect the vague dots on display.  In practice it could mean anything.  In effect, it's meaningless.
And so Hyper Light Drifter is a phenomenally pretty action game.  If you want anything else out of it, be prepared for disappointment.

reviewText:
Nobody I know was more excited about this game than ME.

I've set aside 2 different days this week to play this game. Both have ended in the game repeatedly crashing.

At first I couldn't get the game to launch at all (this would be where the intro video plays after starting a new game and naming your save file.) This was happening on my Steam Link connected to my TV. I decided I'd try sitting at my computer with no Steam Link and just using the monitors.

Now I was able to play the game through the intro video and the first intro level (under ground.) When you come out of the first house (building?) and find the first teleport pad, all the game wants to do is crash. If I walk back into the house i get a crash. If i press start I get a crash. Everything just wants to make this game crash.

In the meantime I'm maxing out newer games like The Division, GTA 5, Fallout 4, Wolfenstein the new order, and Tomb Raider with zero issues.

Really severely disapointed. I asked for a refund becuase money is tight this week after paying all my bills, AND 'Enter the Gungeon' is coming out in TWO days. Hopefully that game will actually run, unlike Hyper Light Drifter.

I'm upset that the dev's wasted my time and money. I hope the refund goes through. What an absolute waste of my Sunday.

reviewText:
Within the first hour: While I was looking for triangle parts and gold blocks, I got lost in a bird people cult tomb and giant swamp golems mercilessly pounded me in to the dirt. 10/10 game of the year.

For real, though, this is a labor of love. The soundtrack is phenomenal, the game looks fantastic, the combat is responsive and absolutely demands that you pay attention. No to mention the amount this game encourages exploring every little nook an cranny. The amount of attention to detail is crazy. Having backed this game via Kickstarter a couple of years back, the wait has been /well/ worth it.

Shout out goes to the guitar playing skeleton in town. I was tabbed over while poking this and that and enjoying the soundtrack when my ears picked up on the soft twang of some guitar strings. It was only then that I realized who I was standing next to.

reviewText: To start off, I had really high expectations for his game so perhaps that has only made my disappointments with it that much more frustrating. The combat is not fluid. For example, using the gun is basically pointless because of the speed of the combat and the way you are being attacked when combat situations arise. I get that the game is not meant to be easy but to make half of your defensive/offensive options essentially useless is something I just do not understand. Aside from the poor gameplay mechanics my other serious gripe is that there is essentialy no story. No one talks, you only somewhat get an idea of what the game may be about by approaching a prompt from standstill characters within the various areas of the game. By approaching, I mean you come up to them and press a button that shows you some pictures of something bad happening to them. Without an explanation of what has happened, immersing yourself within the world that this game is comprised of is impossible. Better luck next time, Heart Machine.

reviewText: I love top-down shooters in the same general gameplay style as this one, and the initial gameplay footage did not look anywhere near as hectic as the final product turned out to be. I'll happily admit that I suck at twitch shooters, and have no desire for punishingly difficult games. A game difficulty option wouldn't go amiss, but it is sadly lacking. This game appears to be built for hardcore speed runs, and this was not advertised at the outset of the kickstarter.\n\nHaving supported the kickstarter from the very beginning, back in 2014, I can say I'm disappointed by the final product. While it's only $10 down the drain for me financially, it's a whole two years following the development of HLD and being hyped for the release. I've been cheated and mislead, and I don't appreciate that at all.

reviewText:
MISERABLE SLOG

I backed on Kickstarter because I was interested in a pixel-art RPG about exploration, and instead I got something else entirely.

The Good: The art, the style, the worldbuilding, GREAT soundtrack by Disasterpeace (even if it does sound too much like FEZ from time to time)

The Bad: The Difficulty Curve is terrible. Most games introduce a technique, allow you to become comfortable with it and then combine it with a different technique. HLD just throws some stuff in your face and expects you to keep up. First time you've seen a rolling plant-monster, you'll have four of them trying to kill you. Where is the RPG part of this game!? No dialogue trees, no NPCs, no levelling up - only some very obtuse upgrades. The 30fps design choice seems a bit eye-swimming at times.

The Ugly: Boss Fights are on the far end of the difficulty curve, and require patterns to be learned and mastered. Apparently I no longer have the twitch-gaming skills of an Adderall-popping teenager because THE BOSS FIGHTS SUCK.

I have all four triangles in the East, West, and North areas, have found a few extras" and after numerous deaths have only completed one boss fight (East). At some point it stopped being fun and became a miserable slog."

reviewText: Aside from the pretty asthetics, there's really nothing here that hasn't been done better in other games. It takes a lot of inspiration from Journey with the storytelling, yet there's a lack of story progression after the prologue that makes you lose interest. I really wanted to see what was next through every step in Journey. I was suprised at how quickly I stopped caring about what was ahead of me in this game. It think it might have had something to do with the immediate use of the collect so and so thingamagigs to proceed". Guess I just didn't feel like dealing with that trope when so much of this game is riding on it's story and atmosphere.\n\nCombat is serviceable

reviewText:
There are games that do little to hand hold or tell much about themselves to you. Keep you in the dark to some degree. But then there are games that just flat out don't tell you much of anything at all. Hyperlight Drifter is that. It's a solid combat game lacking in depth due to making its surface story impenetrable. Having finished the game, the fights also are incredibly unbalanced. Bosses vary between laughly easy to fairly interesting, with one boss being solidly just a frustration train.

This game is what I'd call a Gamer's Game. To someone who's never played a video game before, the fact that progression based tokens are hidden behind scenery that you have to guess to go around, invisible platform that take guesses, and lots, and lots of things that involve mastering skills quickly, it plays to those that have played similar games well and does not lend itself well to first time players.

This game is rage inducingly frustrating. It doesn't help that the final fight provides all the satisification of a wet noodle to the face. I figured New Game+ Might help resolve that, but making the main character have 2 health pips instead of 5 turns something okay, doable, into I got steam rolled to death instantly
date: about 15 times" because truckloads of enemies hit for 2 pips. 3 would have been doable
recommended: but 2 is just loading up the frustration train and packing it full of coal and water.  Might as well have made it one pip for all it mattered. As for finding the secrets
hoursPlayed: one discovers after trawling the scenery for secret doorways

reviewText: Honestly, I really, really wanted to like this game. I followed it for months on kickstarter. Aesthetically, the game is wonderful. The art style is fantastic and the animations are very well done. The music, while different, is good. To me, some of the areas didn't really fit the music that was playing, but that's more personal preference than anything. What killed this game for me was the framerate. While I understand the technical limitations of the engine used to build the game, it was just unacceptable. I can deal with a cap of 30fps, as long as it's consistent, and in this game it is anything but. With the level of precision recquired by the fast-paced combat, a drop of 3-5 fps absolutely threw off my timing. I was met with frequent and intense stuttering. All-told it just made what would have been an incredible game a very unenjoyable experience, and I sadly refunded it.

reviewText:
No. Just no.
There's a difference between a difficult game that doesn't hold your hand and a game that's obtuse for the sake of being pretty. Hyper Light Drifter is the latter.
The game tells you NOTHING. Absolutely nothing about anything. The upgrade system is unreadable, the story is nonexistent, and whoever designed the map needs their head examined. It's ridiculous. It doesn't even tell you where YOU are, much less what you're supposed to be doing.
I tried to enjoy this, I really did. It's just too difficult and too pointless feeling. It's gorgeous, but empty.
Save yourself the time and trouble, and watch someone else play this instead of doing it yourself.

reviewText: This game is almost exclusively style over substance. It is beautiful, and has an amazing tone and sense of aesthetic, both aurally, thanks to Distasterpeace (of FEZ fame), and visually. However, the gameplay and level design is horrifically designed. The game clearly takes inspiration from Dark Souls, but the designers clearly did not understand the nuance behind the game design that makes Dark Souls difficult but fair. Boss arenas are cluttered, visually, making it incredibly easy to fall off the area, or to be be blindsided by attacks off-screen. Dodging doesn't grant invincibility frames, healing takes far too long, dodging feels unresponsive and every button input has noticeable lag behind it. Bosses themselves often have plenty of additional enemys, artifically increasing difficulty by forcing combat with multiple opponents.\nIn short, horrifically designed. Moreover, death and respawn animations are obnoxiously long, making death even more frustrating than in Dark Souls.
voteText: 14 of 32 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is a really solid and well put together game with 3 complaints. The utter lack of exposition while neat from a design perspective makes it really hard to figure out if you're going the right way or doing the right thing. Then there's the lack of some kind of outline or something on certain elements of an area, meaning you think it's on your level so you can dash to it. But in reality it's high up in the air and you just fell to your death. I'll get to the last issue in a second but I first want to talk about how great everything else in the game is before I do. The enemies are fun and challenging the music is top notch. The level and area design with hidden little paths and secrets are wonderful. It's a really great game.\nThat is also almost unplayable due to it's FPS cap. The imput lag will cause you to scream your lungs out in anger and want to pull your hair out at every given opportunity. From dodging the bird bosses ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t following attack, that seems to follow where you're trying to hammer to get away to; but can't because of imput lag. reviewText: First time experiencing motion sickness from a video game. What I saw when the camera was still enough to let me appreciate it, was a challenging, stunning looking experience. I was very excited to explore and learn. Sadly, I've got a headache. 30 FPS can work. Not everything needs it. This game, from my experience, is hurt, and definitely hurts, from not having a 60 FPS framerate. The camera has this odd choppy effect that I found strained my eyes to the point of a headache, and has made me nausious. I requested a refund, but would gladly rebuy if the devs take the time to patch in a higher framerate. From what I've read, this probably can't happen. But, I hope it does get patched, I really want to be able to play this.\n\nTL;DR: FPS caused motion sickness bad enough to give me a headache. Cannot recommend until there's a solution to that.

reviewText: Kickstarter backer - I'm sorely disappointed in this game. It looks beautiful, but plays sluggish and incredibly boring. I like that it tried to start out with a 'silent movie' vibe to it, but for the most part, it just doesn't work. The world is too empty to have any impact on a new player. Additionally, when things do get moving in combat, the controls are just BLEH! The dash and all of the enemy attacks give the impression that combat will be fast, fluid, and rewarding. However, the enemies all behave like that and the player just has these awkward pauses that inhibit fluidity in combat.\n\nAll in all, I'd say avoid this game or prepare to refund it through Steam; maybe buy it on sale. Unfortunately the art and sprite work seem to have taken priority over the actual gameplay in this case. I guess I'm 1:1 on good Kickstarter projects after Shovel Knight; won't be doing any more at this point.

reviewText:
This game's aesthetics are gorgeous, its wordless storytelling is excellent, its combat is extremely well tuned. I've been looking forward to this game since I first saw it on kickstarter; it was the first kickstarter game I ever got excited for...

and I'm getting a refund.

The core health system of this game is, for lack of a nicer term, inexcusable. Its a zelda style game with something even worse than a megaman health system. I would consider a megaman health system unideal, but workable, for an exploration based game, but this has created something even more abysmal. To explain: In this game, you have a healthbar, and energy tanks you can find randomly on the map, enemies drop no health, and the only way to refill your health is to backtrack to a warp pad, which exists at a rate of maybe one per area. A large, sprawling area in which you need to backtrack to a warp pad any time you get seriously wounded...because you do not recieve full health after death.

Upon death, you are restored with one health, and a constant vibrating heartbeat to remind you you're near dead. There is no way to undo this without backtracking to the starting point to refill your health, or hope you happen across an energy tank, which are few and far between. This is an exploration based game that punishes the player for failure and encourages backtracking every single time you get wounded, because there is no reliable way to recover your health.
Megaman gave you full energy upon death, Zelda gave you health drops from enemies, these games which definitely seem to inspire Hyper Light Drifter gave you these concessions because they realized the game slowed to a crawl and lost its sense of enjoyment without this enabling of the player to keep trying.

Hyper Light Drifter actively punishes and discourages its players from continuing to play it.

Thankfully, Alex Preston has stated that he's willing to rethink some of these mechanics if he recieves reasonable arguments indicating why he should change it. Consider this my argument. I would encourage other players to please also submit similar arguments of your own. Until this is changed, I will be refunding my purchase, and I am very willing to rebuy if Mr. Preston is a reasonable enough man to see why this is a core mechanic that needs reworking.

reviewText:
Game keeps crashing. And I cannot get back to the desktop from that crash. Happened twice in my 20 minute run. The game runs at 30 FPS which is really subpar for a quick reaction game like this. With fullscreen panning it seemed like the game was stuttering a lot, which made me feel nausea, might be because I have a 144Hz display and am used to it.

The art style is quite interesting and the minimalist music and sound effects were fine. The gameplay did not grip me at all. Dodge jumping over holes is glitchy, and I fell multiple times because it seemed like the character got stuck in an invisible edge. The movement and combat seemed a bit laggy or too elastic when compared to enemy speed, and the dodge has no i-frames to help you out. It seems like the game design doesn't know if it wants to be a Platinum game or a Souls game. Ending up a far cry from either one of those.

If you can get over the gameplay and a stuttering 30FPS with crashes is fine for you, you might want to try it out for the style. Otherwise skip it and play better games in the same genre.

Update: Just to be clear, 30FPS itself might not be a problem, but the game judders/stutters especially when scrolling, which makes it a lot worse. Happens on a i5-4690K 970 GTX.

reviewText:
As a Kickstarter backer I was vibrating for my chance to get my hands on the game. I was hooked from the very get-go with the pixelated style, the team behind it, the music that played in the background of the teaser. Needless to say my expectations were high.

Right from the off, the art style and music lived up to all expectations. I jumped right in an got acquainted with the controls and thought aiming with the mouse was unorthodox, but okay I'm sure I'll get used to it. Then came the enemies.

If you're making the Link comparison, based solely on the top-down camera, please stop. Using the mouse to aim AND guide your teleport is cumbersome to be generous. I lost count of how many times I trained my mouse on my next target, moved into position to get the perfect attack, and teleported directly into their projectile. Add to that the enemies ability to chain attacks without any delay, even if you're chewing on their ♥♥♥, and timing gets tossed out the window. Low on health? Well, I wouldn't recommend healing cause with the delayed animation you're bound to be hit from multiple angles. Taking your one health point to full then back down to half (or less) wasting the healing potions that are few and far between. Best to just die and try again (without being reminded of 'Edge of Tomorrow' where you die and respawn a million times before you get the fight just right).

I'm coming off a 30+ death streak (spread over only a small area) and it's frustrating to say the least. I want to move forward in order to see all that the story can offer (and hear the score that accompanies it) but it's hidden behind a brick wall so thick and decked out with spikes that I just can't be bothered. I want to pull out my old controller in the hope that that might improve the gameplay (over that damn mouse aiming) but I'm at the point I just can't be bothered.

I'm sorry to say this about a game I backed and drooled over since the beginning of the campaign, but after punishment this severe, bleeding from the eyes and ears doesn't do the visuals or music any favours.

I'm hoping (and praying) for the controls to be tightened up and/or an easy mode, apparently for life-time gaming noobs like me, in the future. Here's hoping I can turn my frown around.

reviewText:
This game has so many problems, not sure where to even start.  Both technical and design.

A glaring technical problem:  the frame rate is locked at 30 fps.   This is absolutely unacceptable in 20-freaking-16 on PC.   The screen follows your character as you walk around, constantly scrolling to keep you near the center.  Why does this have to scroll at 30 FPS?  The animations are fine to be 10 fps or whatever, because they are hand drawn and look cool.  But why does the screen have to clunk around at 30 fps?  After 10 seconds it's downright nauseating and it never gets better.  It's annoying every single minute.

The physics are really bad.  Enemies getting stuck out in empty areas beyond your reach, your character getting stuck on crystals randomly. Trees" where sometimes you can walk through them and other ones you can't
date: with no visible difference between them.   There are these crystal spike traps that damage you when you walk on them.  About 20% of the time my character would get stuck in the middle of them while trying to "warp" past them and get damaged or killed instead.   I couldn't figure out if it was something I was doing
recommended: so I spent about 5 minutes and 20 lives trying to figure it out. Never could detect a pattern or cause. But I did find that if you walk halfway into them
hoursPlayed: and then warp
voteText: you don't get stuck as much
helpfulPercent:
maybe only 5% of the time.

There is no consistency to the auto-save. Sometimes it saves each time you enter a screen.  Sometimes it doesn't.  One time I died and I had all the items I had before dying.  One time I died and it went back 20+ minutes and hadn't saved anything.

The game play is excrutiatingly boring for two reasons:

1)  You start with a sword and quickly get a gun.  There is a grand total of 2 moves:  swing your sword and shoot your gun.   That means after you swing your sword a couple times
votesHelpful: then you get to shoot the gun a couple of times.  Oh and then swing your sword some more.\n\n2)  99% of enemies drop nothing
votesTotal: and you gain absolutely nothing by killing. They serve no other purpose than to put a barrier between you and the things you want to do
votesFunny: like explore the game you just bought or fight a cool boss.   The same enemies are in the same place and respawn every time you die. That means you get to enjoy repeating the same fight against the same enemies in the same places over and over again!  Yay!\n\nIf this game was trying to be a 2D Dark Souls

reviewText: Honestly?  This game looks great and it sounds great.  But what it demands of players is unrelenting perfection on every single challenge the game throws at them. reviewText:
locked at 30fps gimping its otherwise mostly fair but challenging combat; unresponsiveness kills reflex based combat
the dashing; while it's recommended to play with a controller, I don't think you should have to just because one mechanic is poorly implemented
you dash where you point your cursor at
that might not be bad per se
but if you can barely see the cursor because it almost doesn't contrast with the background or is transparent and it becomes a game of guessing where you might end up dashing; particularly in snowy environments
you either need an option to increase the visibilty of the cursor or use the established way of dashing the way you're facing
punishing combat
beatiful aesthetics with great animations, artstyle and dynamic music
somewhat confusing map at first
not too far into the story; intriguing atmosphere, i'd like to play more
it feels bad not to recommend this game but i think the bad outweighs the good
this game lives and dies with its combat and with the game locked to 30fps i get in situations where i feel unfairly treated, where i don't feel like an equal to my opponent
this game feels a little like Bastion, altough the storytelling is quite the opposite and without any narration at all
to be frank i didn't play enough of the game to judge the story but i wouldn't get back to the game because of it.

to me this is a solid 3/6
it is good and got its own strenghts but also weakpoints
just a little more on the technicalside and i feel like i could recommend this without hesitation
but for now i can not.

reviewText:
I have waited for this game for 2 years. I wanted it. I'm happy to have it.

I love the way he looks. I love the colors, i love the level / character design, i love the way things are said with pictures, how you can do the levels in the order that you chose, i love the map, i love the hidden things, i love the money system... If i had to only watch the game, i'd be fully satisfied.

But the gameplay have some flaws, witch make some fights really hard, especially boss fights.

-----------------------------------------------------

Three problems to me :

1) No invulnerabily frames : if you're touched, especially by a boss, you're stun, or put down, but you still take damages, and the attacks keep going. So if you're touched one single time, you're probably dead.

2) You're no invulnerable during a dash. You never are. Would make a great fight system, but the dash is just a way to move faster, not a dodging stuff like the rolls we have in Dark Souls. Too bad :(

3) The healing time is reaaaaally too slow. Takes 2 seconds to trigger, and 2 others before your health bar is full and you can move (you will be touched during this time). This is way too long in these super speed boss fights.

-----------------------------------------------------

Few little bugs I forgive (also, the save system looks good to me, everybody hates it...).
Plus these bugs can help you beat the game sometimes, but never blocks or bother you.

I can't reccomend the game as is, because he makes me RAGE so much, i do not wish that rage to anyone. This is too hard. You can think i'm a noob. I think some deaths i had in the game were unfair.

This is too bad, because the game have so many things to offer...
If you love unfair challenge, and if you're not afraid to rage, try it.

reviewText:
I find the game way too difficult to control and the amount of enemies spawning is way too much for me. On top of this I have had frequent game crashes and spent an hour trying to get the game to start then having to look at a steam community bug fix (Which was very useful) 4 hours after purchase to actually get the game running. When I actually got the game running it would slow down randomly (which was not due to hardware as my CPU and GPU were only at 50% load) and this caused the game to be impossible to play. The enemies have no pattern and seem to have completly random spacings between attacks as well as some enemies being invulnerable when attacking, making attacking completely luck based. As for dodging, the dash is useful but the amounts of enemies cause it to have no real effect as you cannot dash frequently even though you need to. The part that annoyed me the most was getting hit as if you are hit by a charging enemy you are knocked down and have to stand back up before moving and that makes sense. However, you can still be attacked when you stand up even though it will not actually let you move or dash.

This overall creates a frustrating game that I enjoy exploring, but hate combat wise.
World design - 9.5/10 (Extremly fun to explore and look for secrets)
Story - 8/10 (Though not for everyone)
Combat ideas - 9/10 (Very interesting and seem cool)
Combat implementation - 3/10 (For previously stated reasons)

reviewText:
This game is not only overpriced hipster trash, it's overpriced console-tier hipster trash.

It obviously looks pretty, which is its strongest attribute. The music is lovely as well, although the synth score by Disasterpiece is too-frequently undermined by a piano piece which makes the film-school tier symbolism at work in the scenes it plays over all the more cringe-inducing. Superficially it has similarities to Another World, both in terms of the pixellated look of the graphics and the minimalism and starkness of the world it takes place in. The primary difference being that Another World was the work of one man, and managed to much more elegantly and affectingly tell the story of the friendship between two characters and how they overcome the odds against them. It also did 'textless' story-telling much better. On the other hand, this game opts for metatextual ♥♥♥♥♥♥y and 'find your own meaning in your struggle' dreck that I would expect of hipsters. And the pixellated graphics in Another World were limitations of the time, rather than the convenient excuse for not doing more complicated things that they're beginning to feel like in modern games.

I understand this is a kickstarter game developed by a small team, but for the asking price and given the simplistic nature of the design, I was expecting a much more substantial and challenging adventure. A few of the bosses held my attention for more than a few minutes, but despite aspirations to From Software games the best strategy to beating the vast majority of them seems to simply be to attack them fast and hard before they can lay down too much damage. By and large, the gameplay was far too repetitive and the 'shop' mechanic would probably have been better if replaced by item pickups that actually altered the core mechanics in any way, as they should in a vaguely Metroidvania game such as this.

All these problems aside, I could still give the game some sort of qualified recommendation. So let's talk about the really glaring flaw; the multi-platform nature of this release. If you're a PC gamer, you'll quickly pick up those 'multi-platform' cues we all know and loathe. The checkpoint save system is an issue which, now that I've completed the game, I think is keeping me from seeing a few optional parts of it. I don't intend to go through the whole game again just for that. Uncustomizable controls are also a multi-platform standard.

And of course, the most compelling reason you shouldn't spend your money on this; the 30fps lock. It's basically inconceivable to lock any game, especially a PC release, at anything less than 60fps, especially one this primitive which can run on any potato you throw at it. Of course, console users are used to it, and I've got a kind of wide open Christian sympathy for that. But it's unacceptable on the PC. For a game 'in the vein of the best 16 bit classics' it certainly is amusing that the developers don't seem to understand that those virtually all ran in a stable 60fps. I'm guessing most of them are actually players of fairly more recent consoles. I'm also not sure what they can be referring to apart from the Mana games or their (in my opinion superior) cousin Secret of Evermore, or possibly the Fushigi no Dungeon games, none of which were really much like HLD.

Hyper Light Drifter is basically another 'retro' indie title that defends its shoddiness with 'stylistic choice' deflections. Certain elements of it would make it just excusable enough to recommend at a discount, if it weren't for the fatal flaws that make it almost unbearable on the PC. Stay away unless it's fixed in the future.

reviewText:
The Good:
-Beatiful, maticulously crafted pixel art world. Every pixel feels like it was put there by hand.
-Easy to learn, difficult to master controls.
-Intuitive controller mechanism.
-Storytelling without words or dialogue, all imagery.

The Bad:
-The chain-dodge mechanic is unforgiving at best.
-One boss in particular gives zero ♥♥♥♥s and will kill you repeatedly, in an unfair fashion.
-The map is less than intuitive.

The Ugly:
-There is an ridiculous amount of cut content from the game.
-Kickstarter backers who paid upwards of $1000 to support the game were promised their own boss built from their ideas, but it never happened.
-80% of the content that is shown in the first trailer IS NOT IN THE GAME.
-The game feels incredibly short.
-I was expecting metroidvania powerups to unlock secrets/progress in the game. everything can be done with a gun and dodging, which you can do from the beginning.

Conclusion:
-I had high hopes for this game, but its features do not hold up to its beauty.
-It is not worth $20

reviewText:
Ok so I've been watching this game since the preview build came out in 2014, and I can say that it's only gotten better since then. The soundtrack is wonderful, the controls take some getting used to and have the occasional hiccup but otherwise are pretty solid. The story is mostly visual but it's pulled off well and it looks amazing. You can tell that they put all the money they earned in the kickstarter into the game.

Quick Breakdown

PROS:

-Fun gameplay

-Level design is really nice

-Good challenge

-Nice visual storytelling

-Disasterpeace can do no wrong when it comes to soundtracks.

CONS:

-Respawn time is noticeable in tougher areas

-Likes to spawn a lot of enemies in a small area (though it does make it feel so much better when you clear said areas)


Overall it's a great game (even more so knowing that this is this companies first game) and it's definitely worth the money.

reviewText:
On a fundamental level this isn't a good game. Enemies easily blend into backgrounds, the pacing is at a snail's pace, the music is some of the worst I've ever heard this droning annoying sound that makes me rather play it on mute. I say avoid this game.

And you might say I've only played a little bit of it and I suck at games or whatever, but if a game can't catch you within the first hour it's just not a very good game. After dying to the fifth time because the dash attack doesn't have any immunity I realized this title simply isn't for me. This game isn't difficult as it is annoying.

I already read in the comments people making comparisons to this game's difficulty to the Souls Series, well Dark Souls doesn't have enemies warp in from nowhere ready to attack you within seconds. That's just cheap and frankly lazy game design.

I paid $10 for this on Kickstarter, I think anyone is insane to pay $20 (its starting price).

Also 30 FPS Lock? Seriously?

reviewText:
Hyper Light Drifter's biggest selling point is also its biggest weakness. This game was so preoccupied with being art, that it forgot to be an actual game.

I've died countless times because an enemy didn't telegraph properly. A slight change to an enemy's sprite, or an audio cue, isn't going to cut it when there are ten or more of them on screen. Enemies and their attacks are far too often indistinguishable from the level itself, due to blatant overuse of colors like pink and turqoise.

The lush backgrounds and gorgeous scenery are great when exploring by yourself. When in combat, the scenery and set pieces often get in the way, leading to frustrating deaths because of a horribly placed box, or an enemy hiding behind a tree. The scenery shifts colors so drastically, and so often, it feels jarring and uncomfortable. The levels are so cluttered, I've found myself constantly falling to my death, because a set piece wasn't distinguishable from a platform.

The game also fails at giving any sense of direction, Wanting an old school
date: Zelda feel" isn't an excuse for lack of narrative and direction. Expect to get lost a lot
recommended: thanks to constant backtracking and a terrible map.\n\nTL;DR: I really tried to like it
hoursPlayed: but Hyper Light Drifter is art first
voteText: game second. The visuals always come before gameplay
helpfulPercent: and it made itself very clear through every moment of my experience. Can't recommend this to anybody."

reviewText: I really want to like this game.  It harkens back to some old well animated games on Apple II.  This game is fundamentally crippled in two ways.  It's first step on the learning curve is too high for the average gamers.  I'm sure its fine for your basic 12 year old, but for the rest of us older gamers who got tired of 'no docs, no info' as a 'plot device' in 1985 feel that you could have spent more money in your dev cycle on QA, and player instructions.   While playing I can't help but wonder if I stumbled into some high level area of the game and can't get back.   I would LOVE to play this game more, but it just infuriates me.  This is unacceptable for something I paid money for.  Games at their most basic level are supposed to be fun.   This game fails to have a reasonable learning curve.  I read that this game was 'adjusted' to have an easier play, and than hardcore nutjob asshats complained, and it was 'adjusted' back.    I'll tell you what, how about a little dial, or a slider.  It would be in the settings and it would read 'Fun--------------I'm a masochist.'  And you could set it where-ever you wanted.  Those who like to Lord it over others that they completed some nearly impossible amazing game could be happy with their settings, and those who want a fun playthrough could also be happy.    It also seems like one of those games that had one QA guy, they didn't have any housewives on the QA team, and they didn't have any regular old Joes either.   I definitely enjoyed watching the intro movie.  It was spectacular.  The initial ramp up, and 'game training' seemed fine, and then the first encounter I had turned into me dying for 20-30 minutes.  I know I'm not the best gamer in the world, but... yeah, no sale with me.  I'll give it one more chance maybe next week after I feel less angry about wasted money and time.  We'll see how it plays then.

reviewText:
This is a bad game. It looks great, and you'll want to explore it thoroughly. You can't. It doesn't want you to.

What it really wants is for you to have better reflexes than you do. Then you need rythym to master timing based moves, without clear tutorials. While you are trying, it wants you to die.

Who are we kidding? All it wants is for you to die. This is a masocore game, pretending to be an action RPG.

Who am I to judge? Well, I backed this thing, once up on a time. I invested in the artistic vision. I had no idea the designers would be so immature or short sighted, however. Here's some specifics, in case they are reading:

1. Controls are fiddly, and there simply isn't performance to match their fantasy of precise gameplay. I'm on a monster system, before you ask.

2. Save system is a betrayal of basic design principles. If you're going to auto-save, you have to offer resource refills conveniently. The current design requires frequent backtracking to trigger auto-saves, and grinding to replenish your health packs. Note that they had patched this in the weekend I started playing: teleport hubs restored health. Then they patched it back out again, because screw the players.

3. Complete failure to acknowledge that many of us aren't twitchy little buggers any more. I've paid my dues, and at this point all I freakin' want is the ability to lower the difficulty after I've been crushed by a boss for an hour.

4. Unrealistic expectations. In-game challenges for the completionist who wants all items are nuts. Like, hit a button with better than a tenth of a second accuracy for ten minutes straight, while doing challenging steering on a control stick. We're talking 800 reps, here. Nuts.

5. Healing, which only us losers need to do, is too slow to actually use in most contexts. It's more or less a three hit kill system most of the time. You can't really fix this unless you have hummingbird reflexes to heal in between bullets.

I'm tired. I won't even keep going on. I'm deleting and moving on with my life. Be forewarned: this game doesn't want you to play it, unless you're Gud(tm).

reviewText:
Not Recommended but with like five asterisks.

The biggest caveat, I used a steam controller. Maybe that was the worst controller for the game, but I currently don't have any other controllers to really confirm that this was the problem.

I didn't hate the game, but early on, I realized how difficult it was going to be, which was not what I was led to expect (I realize now that this is mostly my fault). It's absolutely gorgeous, the sound and music are incredible, the gameplay is solid, but it is very difficult. Twitchy difficult. Like you have to combine luck and perfect execution for bosses difficult. This would be fine if death were well designed. You have a slow death animation, and a slow revive animation, and it uses a checkpoint system; so if you were screwed before getting into a boss fight, you're still screwed. I quit and returned the game after the fourth time dying in a room of enemies I'd seen before being able to hit me off screen or insta-kill me the moment I dropped in. This is a solved game design problem. There are better systems than this.

I was really excited and hyped for this game, and I am absolutely crushed that I won't be able to enjoy it. If you're into twitchy difficult games, you'll love this one, but I cannot recommend it for filthy casuals like myself.

Edited for clarity, and added some more details on why I actually find this difficulty bs while not finding Souls difficulty bs.

reviewText: Please for the love of gaming; if you are going to make a fast paced precice action game do not, and I repeat DO NOT use a game engine that ties game logic to frame rate or have that frame rate locked at 30. Hell even Stardew Valley runs at 60 and it looks (motion without stutter in the pixel graphics) and feels so much better on a base fundamental level. How have these devs not learned from their dark souls inspiration? I really wanted to like this one.
